Imports into Britain rose from 982 metric tonnes in 1814 to 21 000 tonnes in 1844, levelled off for ten years or so, and then doubled by 1870. France imported an average of 4000 tonnes a year between 1847 and 1856 and 2000 tons in the following decade. She compensated by importing an average of 8000 tonnes of groundnuts a year from Senegal and the Gambia plus 25 000 tonnes of 'tulucoona' nuts for the manufacture of household soap; these imports were worth 35 million gold francs in 1870. Something that had long been an abstract Utopian ideal - an alternative to the slave trade, a substitute for trade in men - had at last materialized. It remained to develop production on an industrial scale; and this took no longer than it had taken the Cuban and Brazilian plantations to reach full production of sugar and coffee. The main producing areas corresponded to the best slave-exporting areas, from Dahomey$^{44}$ to the rivers of the Niger delta and Cameroon. One of the essential features of the changeover was that manpower was mobilized on land that had been internally colonized. This admittedly meant that production was by means of a form of slavery, but within an African social and economic context. In fact the energetic development of this economic novelty did not immediately disrupt the traditional economy: slave trade and oil trade co-existed side by side. A more extensive system of barter began to radiate into the interior. On the coast the same agents for the Western trade still kept their grip on the market: they understood purchasing, gave credit, circulated traditional currencies, and introduced metal coinage. The increase in the number of people competing for trade upset the internal balance and led to a realign› ment of forces.$^{4S}$ These economic changes were accelerated by religious and cultural factors causing distortions, which were never very far removed from politics, which helped, however, to put an end to the trade.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The abolition of the slave trade', 'section_title': 'African reactions', 'content': 'placement of 1000 000 metric tonnes. Of these, most probably 80 per cent were loaded south of the Equator.$^{29}$ Between the beginning of the century and the 1880s, the trans-Saharan trade and the Arab trade exported i 200 ooo and 800 ooo$^{30}$ black Africans respectively, individuals who had been captured in the vast belt stretching from the Bambara country in the west to southern Mozambique.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the world-economy', 'section_title': "From 'luxury' to 'essential' trading patterns", 'content': "It is clear that, at some point, the slave-dealers were no longer 'foraging' for persons to be enslaved but had begun to be engaged in systematic It should also be noted that the total curve for Africa masks a geographic shift. The Sierra Leone coast, involved early, was a significant exporter only as of the middle of the eighteenth century. South-east Africa became a major source only in the nineteenth century. procedures for obtaining their quarry. At some point, therefore, production and political systems in West and Central Africa began to be adjusted as a function of these now continuing economic ties. When such 'adjustment' could be said to have occurred to a significant degree - 1650, 1700, 1750 is hard to say, although I tend to feel a later date is more plausible than an earlier one.$^{5}$ What is true, as we shall argue, is that the very shift of slave-trading from a 'luxury' to an 'essential' trade undermined its economic viability, since it meant that the costs of reproduction had thereupon to be included in the overall profitability calculations of the remuneration of labour services in the capitalist world-economy, since, in all 'essential' trade, production costs include 'opportunity costs'.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]

Scrivelloes (excepting very small, 2lbs. to 3lbs. weight, round solid, which were keenly competed for and brought extravagant prices) were 1l. to 3l. lower.

Ambriz, Angola, Niger, and West Coast African generally met with good competition. Large teeth, 50 lbs. and upwards, went at par to 1l. advance, and smaller sizes, including Bangles, 1l. to 3l. | 13 & 17¾ | small sizes, nearly sound | 42 5 a 48 10 |'}, {'id': 5186, 'article_title': 'Produce Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Produce Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-24', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': 'Liverpool, July 24.

**Sugar.**—Market very dull, and small business reported principally at irregular prices. Low descriptions freely offered at 6d. decline.

**Rum** without animation, holders demanding higher prices than buyers will pay.

**Rice.**—With improved demand for rough, a good business done on the spot at 1½d. advance, and more money is now asked. The sales include Rangoon, 2,700 tons old at 7s. 3d. to 7s. 4½d., the latter price for fine, in store, and 1,800 tons new crop at 7s. 3d. per cwt.

**Sago Flour** very quiet, only about 160 bags sold, at 11s. per cwt.

**India-rubber.**—Market quiet, though offered at easier rates.

**Ivory.**—There was a moderate attendance at the sales, when about 22 tons were offered. Gaboon teeth were in excess of the demand, and prices very irregular, ranging from £2 to £4 per cwt. for medium and large teeth below last sale prices; bangle teeth, with some little irregularity, commanded fully former rates to £2 advance; small scrivelloes declined £1 to £3 per cwt. Prices of Cameroon declined in the same proportion. Angola was in better demand than anything else, and former prices were fully maintained. Niger, Lagos, and common West Coast African brought about former prices. About 5 tons were withdrawn.

**Nitrate of Soda.**—The market steady all week at 10s. 9d. per cwt.; the business is considerable, including due cargoes at 10s. 6d. to 10s. 7½d. for U.K., May sailings at 10s. 9d. to 10s. 10½d., expected October sailings up to 11s. 7½d., U.K. or Continent, July sailing at 11s. per cwt.

**Linseed.**—Market quiet, and fair business done; 6d. decline early in week, of which about half has been recovered.

**Palm Kernels** in fair request at steady prices, and 500 bags sold at £10 15s. to £11 15s. per ton.

**Ground Nuts.**—1,000 bags African sold at £12s. 10d. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—With only a limited supply offering the business has been checked, the sales only amounting to 300 tons, Lagos at £27 15s., Old Calabar at £26 10s., Bonny at £26 5s. per ton, and Irregular at proportionate prices, being about steady rates.'}, {'id': 5412, 'article_title': 'THE IVORY TRADE OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE IVORY TRADE OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1886#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_09_1886', 'content': 'Ivory of the best quality comes from the West Coast of Africa, under the names of Cameroon, Angola, and Gaboon ivory. This is brought down from the interior, and retains a large proportion of the fat or gelatine, from the fact, probably, that it is from the recently living animals. In this state it is called green ivory. It is not so white as the kinds called white ivory, which have been lying a longer time exposed to the heat of the sun until the animal matter has disappeared. The excellence of green ivory consists in its greater toughness and in its growing whiter by age, instead of yellow, as is the case with the whiter varieties. Yet buyers of cutlery, through ignorance of these qualities, usually prefer the whiter kinds, which on that account are more in demand for the Sheffield trade, and have more than doubled in price since 1879.

The sales of ivory occur every three months at London and Liverpool, and sales are also held at irregular intervals at Rotterdam. At Liverpool, only ivory of the best quality is offered. Buyers from Germany and France and agents of American consumers attend these sales; and it is estimated that about one quarter of the whole amount goes to Sheffield, another quarter to London, and the other half to Germany, France, and the United States. There is just now great anxiety as to the future supply of ivory. The stocks in public warehouses are smaller than for many years past, and the rapid increase in prices is causing great anxiety to manufacturers. At a recent sale at Liverpool, the best African ivory sold by the ton at over 12s. 6d. per pound. This will explain the fact that the principal factor in the value of the best table cutlery is the handle. When the ivory comes into the hands of the cutler, much skill is required to make the most of the material, and every scrap is turned to account. After cutting out the scales of all sizes for pocket-knives, and the solid handles for table cutlery, the small pieces are usually sold to the button-makers, or may be made into pearls. These latter are the small pieces of ivory, pearl, or horn inserted into the handles of tea and coffee pots as non-conductors of heat, and are so called because they were originally made of pearl. The fine sawdust is sold for fertilising purposes, for the manufacture of gelatine, and for making a sizing used in the manufacture of lace fabrics. The refuse still remaining goes to the makers of ivory black. The proportion of this residuum is about fifteen pounds to the hundredweight, and sells at from £16 to £20 per ton. Many efforts have been made to devise some method for the solidification of ivory dust, but as yet without success. Great skill is required in the cutting of ivory, as of wood, to bring out the beauty of the grain.'}, {'id': 5961, 'article_title': 'Produce Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Produce Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_02_1890', 'content': '**PALM OIL.**—A moderate business concluded, prices for the week showing a decline of about 5s. per ton in most instances. 500 tons sold; Benin at £21, soft oils at £21 10s., and Lagos at £23 5s., with Irregular at £20 per ton.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 17.**

**SUGAR.**—There has been a fair amount of business done throughout the week, and prices of medium and fine descriptions show an improvement of 3d. per cwt., whilst low qualities are unchanged.

**RUM** is very steady, and 80 puncheons of Demerara sold at previous prices.

**COFFEE.**—There has been a quiet, steady market, and quotations are unchanged. 310 bags African, bold berry, on the spot, and 350 bags, to arrive, at 75s. 6d., 50 bags Jeremie at 87s., and 290 bags Bahia at 77s. 6d. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—There has been a little more doing at steady prices, and 120 bags African sold at 50s. to 55s., and 230 bags Jeremie at 39s. to 40s. per cwt.

**MANDIOCA FLOUR.**—133 bags African at 9s. 3d. per cwt., ex quay.

**GUM.**—About 15 tons Brazilian sold, part at 27s. 6d. per cwt., and small sales of Senegal at steady prices, with 12 bags Lagos Copal at 26s. to 30s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Para quiet and unchanged; about 25 tons African sold at 11½d. to 1s. 8d. per lb.

**PALM KERNELS.**—About 2,000 bags sold at £8 to £11 2s. 6d. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been more pressure to sell, and a further decline of 10s. accepted, at which about 1,000 tons have changed hands; hard oils at £20 5s. to £20, soft oils at £21 5s. to £21, and Lagos at £23 to £22 15s. per ton.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 24.**

**SUGAR.**—The market has been quiet throughout the week, and only a moderate business done, without quotable change in prices.

**COFFEE.**—A moderate business concluded at very steady prices, the sales including 257 bags African, bold berry at 75s. 6d. to 76s., with small sales of Elephant berry at 86s. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—There has been more business doing at very steady prices, and 550 bags fermented Bahia sold at 60s. to 61s., 213 bags African at 42s. to 60s., and 400 bags Jeremie at 39s. to 40s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—The market for Para is dull and easier. About 4 tons African sold at 1s. to 1s. 2d per lb.

**IVORY.**—There was a good attendance at the sales on Tuesday, and the whole quantity offered (about 19 tons) generally sold with good competition at full prices to an advance of £1 to £2 per cwt. on last sales. Bangle scrivelloes, in some instances, were a little irregular.

**PALM KERNELS** are very quiet, and late rates are barely obtainable.

**PALM OIL.**—There is continued pressure to sell, and prices show a further decline of 10s. 1,200 tons sold; hard oil at £19 17s. 6d., soft oils at £20 17s. 6d. to £20 10s., Accra and Benin at £20 5s., and Lagos at £22 15s. to £22 per ton.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 31.**'}, {'id': 6142, 'article_title': 'Produce Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Produce Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-12', 'issue_date': '03_08_1891', 'content': '### LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JULY 24.

**SUGAR.**—A fair demand for the finer descriptions, prices of which show an advance of 3d. per cwt.; low and medium sorts, however, have been comparatively neglected, though values show no appreciable change.

**COFFEE.**—The market for African is quietly steady, and about 200 bags sold, bold at 75s. 6d. and Elephant berry at 87s. 6d. to 89s. 6d. per cwt., chiefly the latter price. There was only a moderate demand for the Jamaica at auction, on Tuesday, and prices rather favoured buyers; 83 packages sold at 80s. to 121s., and 35 bags Jamaica at 83s. per cwt.

**GINGER.**—50 bags new crop African at 23s. per cwt.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—7 bags at 43s. 6d. per cwt.

**GUM** firm, with only a moderate quantity offering. 25 barrels Sierra Leone Copal sold at 3d. to 10d. per lb.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—The Para market has been quiet all week, but at the close there is a little more inquiry; holders of fine quality are very firm at 3s. 4d. per lb., and there is not a great deal on offer even at this figure. About 4 tons of negroheads have been sold at 2s. 3½d. per lb., being a very steady price. African has met with rather more inquiry during the week at slightly easier prices, which sellers, however, do not seem inclined to accept, and consequently there has again been only a moderate amount of business put through. The sales amount to about 20 tons, including Sierra Leone twists at 1s. 6¼d. to 1s. 9½d., fair niggers 1s. 7½d. to 1s. 8½d., Addah niggers 1s. 7¾d., Grand Bassam and Assinee 1s. 2d. to 1s. 5d., Cameroon 1s. 6¼d., and Cape Coast at 11d. per lb.

**IVORY.**—There was a fair attendance at the sales on Tuesday, and more competition than has been shown for some time past. Teeth of all descriptions commanded better prices than at the last sales of April 21. Fine large-sized and medium sold at about par to £2 advance. Medium-sized bangle teeth and scrivelloes and solids, suitable for billiards, were distinctly dearer, say generally £1 to £3, and common scrivelloes showed an improvement in prices of £2 to £4 per cwt.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—About 2,200 bags sold, part on private terms and part at 10s. 8d. to 12s. 3d. per cwt.

**EBONY.**—9 tons Victoria at £5 2s. 6d. to £5 15s. per ton, ex quay.

**BENNISEED.**—50 bags Sierra Leone at 46s. 6d. per 384 lb., ex quay and store.

**PALM KERNELS.**—2,782 bags at £10 17s. 6d. to £11 12s. 6d. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—110 bags Bathurst, in shell, at £13, and small sales of fine decorticated at £15 per ton.

**PALM OIL** has been sparing offered, and the business has, in consequence, been restricted, values generally showing an advance of 10s. to 20s. per ton. The sales include Saltpond at £21 10s. to £21 15s., Grand Bassam at £22 to £22 10s., Benin at £22 15s., Accra at £22 5s. to £23, soft oils at £23 5s. to £23 10s., and Lagos at £23 15s. to £24 5s., and Irregular at £21 per ton all transit.'}, {'id': 6486, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN IVORY', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN IVORY', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1894#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_08_1894', 'content': 'From time to time we hear alarmist rumours of the scarcity of ivory; and we are led to anticipate that in a very few years the world's stock of that most useful commodity will be exhausted, owing to the reckless way in which the African elephant has been slaughtered. Yet we find that the ivory trade with the Congo Free State continues to steadily increase. This ivory comes from the Higher Congo, both north and south of the river. Steamers bring it as far as Stanley Pool, and from there to Matadi, 250 miles, Native carriers—mostly if not invariably slaves—bring it on their backs. An eye-witness lately reported that he had seen in one day 500 carriers go into Matadi, each carrying a tusk 65lb. in weight. When tusks weigh 200lb, which not infrequently happens, four men carry them. Most of the ivory now coming down is known as "dead ivory." Some of the elephants from which these tusks came were killed a century ago, and the Kings of villages have been storing it, placing the last tusks brought in on the top of the pile, and when they required some goods from the coast traders the tusks from the bottom layers were taken. This system has prevailed for many years, and it is estimated that there is yet enough ivory stored up in this manner in the interior of Africa to supply the world's demands for the next century. A State expedition visited a Native King some time ago in the interior. Upon leaving, the commanding officer presented the King with a uniform coat, cocked hat, and a sword. The King in return presented the officer with 150 tusks of ivory, averaging 220lb. each, and provided carriers to take them down to the river. These people do not recognise the value, and laugh at the trader for buying. Some of the Native Kings are said to have stockades of ivory built around their dwellings. It is estimated that there are still at least 200,000 elephants in Central Africa. The only "live," or new, ivory which now comes down is that procured by hunters attached to the different trading-houses. Live ivory commands a better price than the dead.

Many travellers and explorers in the Dark Continent have not scrupled to say that as long as the trade in ivory continues to be one of the staple industries of Central Africa, so long it will be impossible to put down the slave trade. But we may well hope that with the opening up of the Interior country, and its firm administration by the principal European Powers, the days of that abominable traffic are doomed; while ivory will long continue to be almost a necessity of civilised life.'}, {'id': 6755, 'article_title': 'Produce Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Produce Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1896#article-21', 'issue_date': '01_05_1896', 'content': "**COCOA.**—The market continues very quiet, the trade still showing little disposition to operate, and only a small business is understood to have been done, without any material change to notice in values. A small lot of African at 33s. to 36s. per cwt, ex quay.

**GINGER.**—1,120 bags Sierra Leone, including quay parcels, at 20s. to 20s. 3d. per cwt.

**CHILLIES.**—30 bags of Sierra Leone at 30s. per cwt.

**GUM.**—Arabic sorts are firm, and full prices are demanded for the limited quantity offering; sales reported at 100s. per cwt., with 10 barrels Sierra Leone Copal at 8d. to 1s. 3¾d. per lb.

**INDIA RUBBER.**—The Para market has been strong and advancing, with an active demand, and a large business has been done at prices showing an advance of 2d. per lb. on the week. The sales on the spot, which amount to fully 100 tons, include fine Para at 3s. 3¼d. to 3s. 5d., entrefine at 3s. 2d. to 3s. 4d., and Cameta negroheads at 2s. 3d., whilst to arrive 20 tons May delivery of fine have been sold at 3s. 5d. per lb., closing with further buyers at the price in this position, but holders asking more money. There has been a fair amount of business done in African during the week at late rates to in some instances a slight advance. The sales reported, which amount to about 70 tons, include Sierra Leone niggers at 1s. to 2s. 1¾d., Manoh and Sierra Leone twists at 1s. 6d. to 1s. 9d., Lagos biscuits at 1s. 6½d. to 1s. 7¾d., Mayumba ball at 1s. 5½d., flake at 11½d., Cape Const biscuits at 1s. 10d. to 1s. 10¾d., and Grand Bassam kinds at 1s. 5d. per lb.

**IVORY.**—There was a good attendance of buyers at the sales on Tuesday, when about 15½ tons of various qualities were offered. The tone was fairly good, but with rather less animation than at the last sales. Large teeth were in demand for America, and realised extreme prices to a few pounds advance, as also ball scrivelloes. Bangles brought full rates, and small solid scrivelloes were rather dearer. For the rest prices were somewhat irregular, but on the average realised about last sales' rates. Defective lots were again a little lower.

**WAX.**—42 packages Bees' sold; Sierra Leone at £6 15s., Gambia at £7 7s. 6d., Californian at £7 10s., and Chilian at £7 15s. to £8 per cwt.

**CAMWOOD.**—5 tons Grand Bassam at £10 10s. to £10 12s. 6d., ex quay, and £11 per ton in store.

**KOLA NUTS.**—56 packages sold; dried at 4d. to 4¾d., and fresh at 6d. to 7d. per lb.

**PIASSAVA.**—500 bundles Grand Bassam at £11 to £12 5s., and Cape Palmas at £16 10s. per ton, ex quay."}]

To the small supply for these sales must be largely attributed the favourable result to importers; a supply more evenly distributed for the buyers' wants we have seldom seen, but the general improvement in trade also helped to contribute to the advance. The attendance of buyers was large and the bidding throughout animated. The home trade and France bought a larger proportion than usual, America more than for many past sales (notwithstanding the large and increasing quantity of the imports direct, which is partly the cause of our reduced supplies), whilst Germany took less than her usual proportion; Italy was barely represented.

**GABOON.**—The new parcel with colour sold at materially higher prices, showing an average advance of 5l. to 6l. per cwt. for teeth, and 2l. to 4l. for scrivelloes. The old parcel which was re-offered being very dry, was not competed for, and nearly all in consequence was bought in.

Ambriz and Cameroon and West Coast African generally met a good demand, as holders showed a determination to sell. Large teeth of 50lbs. and upwards went at par to 3l. decline, whilst those of smaller average (including bangles) sold at par to 3l. advance. Scrivelloes were generally 2l. to 4l. higher, and the fine small solid even 5l. to 6l.

West Coast, African, Niger, Lisbon, &c., middling to good qualities.

| " | 1¾ to 3½ | defective | 10 0 to 23 5 |', 'last_edit_date': '1876-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1876#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE LATEST DECREES OF THE CONGO FREE STATE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'By that Royal Decree, the export duties from the Congo Free State were increased—For ivory, from 50 to 200 frs. per 100 kilogs.; for rubber, from 20 to 50 frs. per 100 kilogs.; whilst by the next Decree the freedom from export duties on produce from the Upper Congo is withdrawn.

We venture to observe that the levying of a duty solely based on the weight of articles of produce, subject to differences in value through market fluctuations, &c., will be universally condemned.

If this be of less moment when a small duty is concerned, it is indefensible in the case of duties which may be styled extortionate.

Rather than indulging in arguments, we will come forward with figures provable by our books—During 1888 and 1889 we exported 791,064 kilogs. rubber (thimbles), which produced 1,466,649,71 f.; at the exchange of 100 Dutch guilders to 208 frs., 3,050,631,39 frs.; making per 100 kilogs. 385,63 frs.

Now if an export duty of 50 frs. per 100 kilogs. be levied, then this is about 13 per cent. on the price free on board, leaving no margin for interest or profit.

Of ivory, we exported during the same years 128,225 kilogs., which produced 1,406,714,10 f.; being in francs, 2,925,965,32 frs.; per kilogram, 22,82 frs.

Calculating on the above—License duty at 2 frs.; export duty at 2 frs.; total, 4 frs., or about 17½ per cent. Or, license duty at 4 frs.; export duty at 2 frs.; total, 6 frs., or about 26⅓ per cent.

Who will not call such duties exorbitant?

This becomes the more apparent, as ivory is very divergent in value, regulating itself according to the weight of each tusk.

The tusks weighing over 20 lbs. English, are generally the dearest, then follow those of from 10 to 20 lbs., whilst the cheapest are less than 10 lbs.

During the last two years we sold in eight successive sales in London: Tusks of over 20 lbs. English, from 30 frs. to 23 frs. per kilogram; on this a duty of 4 frs. per kilogram is 13½ to 17½ per cent.; on this a duty of 6 frs. per kilogram is 20 to 26 per cent. Tusks from 10 to 20 lbs. English 27,75 frs. to 21,74 frs. per kilogram; on this a duty of 4 frs. per kilogram is 14⅓ to 18⅓ per cent.; on this a duty of 6 frs. per kilogram is 21⅓ to 27⅓ per cent. Tusks below 10 lbs. English 19,75 frs. to 10,80 per kilogram; on this a duty of 4 frs. per kilogram, is 20 to 37 per cent.; on this a duty of 6 frs. per kilogram, is 30 to 55½ per cent.

It requires no argument to prove that, with such burdens, the ivory trade is impracticable to the Congo trader. The buying is done in small lots at a time. He who purchases a lot of small ivory is by no means sure of securing large ivory later on. The negro will no longer be able to barter the article for goods. The contact with Europeans will decrease, and the trader will find a fresh field for his operations, and will acquire his ivory on easier terms and find other means of cheap transit to the East Coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1890#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.697, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## GINGER.—25 bags Cochin at 36s. 6d., and 100 bags Monrovia at 25s. per cwt., in store.

## CHILLIES.—200 bags good Sierra Leone at 35s. per cwt.

## GUINEA GRAINS.—25 bags at 17s. per cwt.

## GUM.—Arabic descriptions meet with a moderate inquiry, and small sales made at late rates; 17 packages Lagos Copal sold at 34s. 6d. to 37s. 6d. per cwt., and 50 barrels Sierra Leone at 7¾d. to 1s. 0¾d. per lb., with Gold Coast at 9½d. per cwt., both in store.

## INDIA RUBBER.—Business in Para during the week has been on only a very moderate scale, and values are steady and unchanged, Island fine being held for 3s. 1d., and up river fine for 3s. 1¾d. per lb. Only small sales of African have been made at steady prices, and the sales include small Gaboon Ball at 1s. 4d., medium Sierra Leone niggers at 1s. 10d., medium Sierra Leone twists at 1s. 9½d., Lome niggers at 1s. 7¾d., and Grand Bassam at 1s. 5d. per lb.

## IVORY.—The quarterly sales, which took place on Tuesday, comprised about 15½ tons of various qualities of African; buyers were very indifferent, and showed but little disposition to operate, except at lower prices, owing to large stocks at Antwerp. The sales were consequently slow and dragging, with prices irregular, and registering a decline of £2 to £3 for medium sized teeth and bangles; large teeth were even lower, especially if at all defective. Small scrivelloes were £1 to £2 lower, but balls brought full rates. The small quantity of Lisbon Ivory sold was at full prices.

## EBONY.—18 tons Old Calabar at £5 10s. per ton, ex quay.

## PALM KERNELS.—2,000 bags sold at £9 2s. 6d. to £9 12s. 6d. per ton, ex quay, transit.

## GROUND NUTS.—A small lot of decorticated Congo at £9, and 100 bags undecorticated Bathurst at £11 10s. to £12 10s per ton, ex quay.

## KOLA NUTS.—45 packages dried at 6d. to 7d., and 10 baskets fresh at 5d. per lb.

## PIASSAVA.—2,000 bundles Grand Bassa at £19 to £20 per ton, ex quay.

## PALM OIL.—Holders having submitted to a further decline of 5s. to 10s., there has been an improved demand, and a good business done at the quotations, the market closing firm, with buyers at an advance. The sales include Accra at £18 quay, and at £18 to £18 5s. transit, Benin at £18 10s. to £18 5s., soft oils at £18 15s. to £19, and Lagos at £20 to £20 5s. per ton, transit.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1895#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REPORT ON THE IVORY TRADE OF 1879', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**REPORT ON THE IVORY TRADE OF 1879.**

**Mincing Lane, London, 9th January, 1880.**—Of 444 tons imported in 1879, about 100 tons went to Liverpool over and above the quantity sent thence to London for sale in this market. 112 tons were brought to auction in Liverpool in the course of the year; and of the stock in importers' hands on the 1st instant, not submitted to auction, 22 tons are at Liverpool.

The deliveries from the Dock Warehouses in London in each of the last 16 years was as follows: In 1879, 402 tons; 1878, 489½ tons; 1877, 506 tons; 1876, 478½ tons; 1875, 470 tons; 1874, 514½ tons; 1873, 464 tons; 1872, 610 tons; 1871, 549 tons; 1870, 457 tons; 1869, 441 tons; 1868, 431 tons; 1867, 518 tons; 1866, 396 tons; 1865, 556 tons; 1864, 620 tons.

The striking and important fact (to which we would call special attention) brought out by the statistics for the past year, is the very great falling off in our supply of Ivory. The deficiency amounts to nearly 200 tons—about 30 per cent. compared with the receipts of 1877-78; and we must go back as far as 1855 to find a year of parallel importations. No doubt this large reduction is to be accounted for in some measure by shipments from Zanzibar to this country, which were only sent here to be transhipped to the United States, and which did not enter into our stocks; and also by direct shipments to Hambro', Holland, and France, of Ivory, which had previously found its way, directly or indirectly, at any rate to a large extent, to this market. But, after making every allowance for this, the deficiency in the total exports from Africa last year must have been very heavy. This is moreover confirmed by the circumstance that the bulk of our falling off", 'last_edit_date': '1880-01-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1880#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'IVORY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'By a report on the Ivory trade we find there was—

The other 24 tons 4 cwt. being sea horse, cuttings, walrus, and 14 tons mammoth.
