Precisely because the Maghrib served as the transit and transfer nexus of what was in effect an indirect long-distance trade between the Sahelian zones and Europe, there was less pressure on it to create new loci of export-oriented production on its own territory. There are conflicting views on the degree to which the trans-Saharan trade continued to be important in the period 1750-1880.$^{12}$ It is clear, however, that late nine› teenth-century colonization eliminated the economic significance of these ancient trade routes, and simultaneously therefore withdrew the 'protective cover' for the Maghrib of its entrepôt role.
The rise of so-called legitimate trade in West Africa in the nineteenth century has been a central theme of historiography for some time now. What was important was not, however, the increase in the quantity of trade or even its changing content in terms of the items traded, but the transformation of productive structures that followed therefrom and the political consequences of such changes in the relations of production. This was a process that started before the British efforts to abolish the slave trade, since these efforts were themselves a parallel outcome of the expansion of the capitalist world-economy; to be sure the transformation of productive structures in West Africa was accelerated by abolition. 13 The 'classic' and in some ways the most successful of the new products, now amply documented, was that of palm oil in the Niger delta area. This production at first co-existed with the slave trade,$^{14}$ and later flourished on its own, until the boom came to an end in 1861, and finally declined at the end of the century.$^{15}$ The palm-oil trade similarly expanded in the Gold He finds the relevant consideration to be Europe's need of raw materials and points out the 'extraordinary demands on production' involved in the new amounts of palm oil, timber, and rubber exported. 'Many producers became involved in the harvest of the new commodities over wide areas.'", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the world-economy', 'section_title': "From 'luxury' to 'essential' trading patterns", 'content': "The traditional compartmentalization between largely non-com› mercialized agricultural production and the long-distance trade in nonagricultural (luxury) products remained the rule even in those cases where there were small European agricultural settler communities, such as the prazeros in the Zambezi valley or the Boers on the Cape coast.
The one zone in which the economic situation was somewhat different was those parts of West and Central Africa where communities had begun to participate in the slave trade. The slave trade was of course a product of, and a key element in, the construction of the European-centred capitalist world-economy that had come into existence c. 1450. By the seventeenth century this capitalist world-economy included as part of its peripheral production areas the 'extended' Caribbean zone of the Americas. In this zone, the expanding plantation systems (especially sugar, but also tobacco, cotton, and other products) came to depend increasingly for their manpower on slaves who were 'captured' in West and Central Africa and transported across the Atlantic.
Should this long-distance trade in slaves be classified as 'luxury' trade or as trade in 'essentials'? Can it be said to have involved the 'production' of manpower for the capitalist world-economy? And should therefore the 'producing' zones be seen as peripheral areas of this capitalist worldeconomy? There is no simple answer to these queries. In terms of numbers exported there was an upward curve in the slave trade from 1450 to 1800, with a significant increase c. 1650. The numbers by 1750 were about triple those of 1650. 4", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The First World War and its consequences', 'section_title': 'The economic consequences of the War', 'content': 'in 1916-18. 51 But increased demand was not always reflected by increased prices, for often the colonial governments controlled the prices paid to the producers. Certain countries suffered badly throughout the war. To take the example of the Gold Coast, its major export crop of cocoa was not nearly in such demand as, for instance, oil-seeds. Furthermore the buying capacity of the African-based import-export houses was severely hampered by the enlistment, voluntary or obligatory, of so many of the European personnel; in French West Africa some 75% of the European traders had left for the war by 1917. 52 While prices of exports did not always reflect the increased demand for them, because of controlled prices, and while demand for labour, too, was not always reflected in increased wages, the prices of imports, where they were obtainable, rose throughout the war. While the vast majority of Africans in the subsistence sector were not affected by this inflation, those in the wage-earning or export crop-producing sectors were. Thus the Egyptian peasant producing cotton found that the benefit he received from increased prices for his product did not offset the steep rise in the cost of fuel, clothing and cereals. 53 The war witnessed an increased level of state intervention in the economies of the African colonies, whether in the form of price control, requisition of food crops, compulsory cultivation of crops, recruitment of labour for essential projects or allocation of shipping space. Generally such intervention tended to favour the import-export houses of the colonial power controlling the colony concerned. Thus in Nigeria, companies like John Holt and the United Africa Company were used as buying agents and had both priority in shipping space and easier access to loans from the banks, with the result that smaller import-export companies, in particular Nigerian-controlled ones, suffered. 54 Demands for traditionally subsistence crops, including yams, manioc and beans, for the feeding of the Allies in Europe and for the armies in Africa or the Middle Eastern front, added to the hardship of those outside the subsistence sector. And where subsistence crops were requisitioned - as they widely were - or paid for at prices below the free-market price, the producers themselves suffered. Thus by the end of the war the Egyptian fallâhïn were hard put to keep body and soul together, what with inflation, and the requisition of their cereals and animals.$^{55}$ In French West Africa the demands for men for the war conflicted with demands', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The countries of the Zambezi basin', 'section_title': 'The slave trade and incorporation into the capitalist world economy', 'content': 'Viewed from a somewhat different perspective, the unequal value of commodities exchanged reflects the fragile position of the region within the larger international trading system. As E. A. Alpers has noted, 'What Africans received in exchange for ivory, even though it had little intrinsic value in their own societies, were goods that in no way equalled the value placed on ivory by the merchant capitalists of India, Europe and America.' 65 This discrepancy was particularly acute in the sale of captives. In return for the lost labour power, the Central African societies received a variety of inexpensive perishable commodities and weapons of destruction, neither of which compensated for the depletion of the work force. Similarly, when Africans hunted ivory they were exhausting a limited resource and were not receiving capital goods that expanded the productive base of their societies. Recent research suggests that they were not only distorting their economies but also destroying the ecology.
As the region was becoming progressively impoverished, disparities in wealth and social equality became more pronounced. Although more detailed research is needed to determine the character of the production systems and the allocation of surplus in specific Central African societies, it is clear that the dominant aristocracy, often allied with all or a fraction of the merchant class, was the principal beneficiary. The emergence of the powerful Yao chiefs, Makanjila and Mataka, testifies to the growing political and social differentiation within these societies, as do the desperate efforts of the Makua rulers to remain in power.$^{66}$ A similar phenomenon occurred in the sultanates of Angoche and Quitanghona and in the Chikunda and Arab-Swahili conquest states, where a small political-commercial class prevailed despite growing opposition and periodic revolts. The extent to which popular discontent surfaced more frequently during the second half of the century suggests growing class antagonisms as did slave uprisings in Lozi society and on the prazos."
In other instances trading interests, independent of the rulers, were able to dominate commerce and undercut the position of the political authorities.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the world-economy', 'section_title': "From 'luxury' to 'essential' trading patterns", 'content': "As long as Africa was 'outside' the world-economy, the 'cost' of a slave to the slave-owner was the expense of procurement plus maintenance plus supervision (prorated for his/her life as a slave) divided by total work output during his/her life as a slave. The 'benefit' to the world-economy was essentially the surplus value produced by the slave minus the 'cost'. Once Africa was 'inside' the world-economy, that is, was producing on its soil commodities that were part of the division of labour of the worldeconomy, then someone who was a slave was not something else, for example a free peasant producer or a wage-labourer. Therefore, although the 'cost' of the slave remained the same perhaps for the slave-owner, the 'benefit' had to be recalculated from the point of view of the world-economy as a whole. The numerator of the equation had to take into account the 'alternative' accumulation from some other use of the individual. It may be that he/she would have produced still more net surplus value if not enslaved. Furthermore, and crucially, the denominator changed since the years of reproduction, formerly usually outside these calculations, were now part of them. Therefore, the net accumulation from the slave years was reduced while the net accumulation if not enslaved remained the same. Ergo, the calculus was less favourable to slavery, from the point of view of the accumulation process in the world-economy as a whole.
Nonetheless, it was not these changing economic implications of the slave trade that would have the greatest impact on Africa's future develop› ment but a more fundamental process that was occurring within the capitalist world-economy. The first long economic and geographic expan› sion of the capitalist world-economy had occurred between 1450 and 160050. In that period, no part of Africa could be said to have been part of this historical system. The period 1600/50-1730/50 was, for the capitalist worldeconomy, a period of relative stagnation, of taking a breath, of consolidation, primarily within the geographic zones that had already been included in the sixteenth century. It was still largely true at this time that no part of Africa could be said to have been incorporated into this system (with the reservations noted about the changing structure of the slave trade). 6", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: demographic aspects', 'section_title': 'The clashing forces of demographic change up to and beyond 1880', 'content': 'These were the major forces determining population change but there were undoubtedly others. Commerce was one, although whether such activities brought prosperity and the ability to buy food in times of need and perhaps some health care in the few places where it existed to a greater degree than it brought disease arising from increased contact with strangers is debatable. By 1880 cash crops included the cotton of Egypt, cloves in Zanzibar, sugar in Natal and an increasing area of groundnuts (peanuts) in Senegal, while in Algeria a European settler economy largely based on wheat and wine was being established. One aspect of trade almost certainly did have a deleterious effect on health, and that is the flow of strong alcoholic drink into the continent. There were two reasons for the trade: firstly that alcohol could be produced cheaply in Europe and sold for immense profits; secondly, in economies without widely accepted mediums of exchange, there were real problems about what goods would be accepted in return for the produce of Africa.$^{43}$ Mary Kingsley found the trade spirit pure and likely to do less harm than cannabis,$^{44}$ a view shared by a committee that investigated the liquor trade in içoç.$^{45}$ Spirits were distributed on a huge scale, frequently as wages. In 1894 half the total government revenue and 95 per cent of the customs duties of the Niger Coast Protectorate were derived from spirits; by 1894 the governmental income from this source totalled nearly £2 million.$^{46}$ Although the Brussels Act of 1892 tried unsuccessfully to limit the trade in the Congo (now Zaire), it was not successfully regulated in tropical Africa until the eve of the First World War.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the world-economy', 'section_title': "From 'luxury' to 'essential' trading patterns", 'content': "It is clear that, at some point, the slave-dealers were no longer 'foraging' for persons to be enslaved but had begun to be engaged in systematic It should also be noted that the total curve for Africa masks a geographic shift. The Angolan coast was involved in a major way as of the sixteenth century, the Bight of Benin only as off. 1650, the Gold Coast as of c. 1700, the Bight of Biafra as off. 1740. The Sierra Leone coast, involved early, was a significant exporter only as of the middle of the eighteenth century. South-east Africa became a major source only in the nineteenth century. procedures for obtaining their quarry. At some point, therefore, production and political systems in West and Central Africa began to be adjusted as a function of these now continuing economic ties. When such 'adjustment' could be said to have occurred to a significant degree - 1650, 1700, 1750 is hard to say, although I tend to feel a later date is more plausible than an earlier one.$^{5}$ What is true, as we shall argue, is that the very shift of slave-trading from a 'luxury' to an 'essential' trade undermined its economic viability, since it meant that the costs of reproduction had thereupon to be included in the overall profitability calculations of the remuneration of labour services in the capitalist world-economy, since, in all 'essential' trade, production costs include 'opportunity costs'.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig:
[{'id': 87, 'article_title': 'Palm Oil and Cotton', 'full_section_title': 'Palm Oil and Cotton', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1863#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_01_1863', 'content': "Sept. 15—20.—The women failing in their expectation to get any more fents, began to yield gradually in selling small quantities of cotton for cowries; the quantity of clean cotton now collected weighed 120lbs. Just about the close of the day, Saturday, a quantity of seeded cotton, weighing 64lbs., was brought, and sold for a piece of cambric, ten yards, valued at six shillings here at Laird's Town Factory. This was the largest lot sold at once since we began.

Sept. 22.—A lot of seeded cotton, weighing 144lbs., was purchased this morning for two pieces of cambric, at the above-mentioned value; the rate of seeded cotton is now being brought to one penny per pound, at which this lot was readily sold; and with a variety of goods in hand it could be bought much cheaper; but at the commencement a little encouragement should be held out, to induce the people to bring cotton readily and in large quantities, when the rate may be gradually reduced as the supplies increase. When it is known that a piece of cloth sold for six shillings at the factory up the Niger is at the rate of cent. per cent., the English price will be three shillings or three shillings and sixpence; so the cotton may fairly be said to be bought here at one halfpenny per pound in the seed, even at this time, when the people hold out to get what they can. Three pounds seeded cotton make 1lb. clean wool. There are two sorts, the black seeded one, which cleans very readily, and is, I believe, what is called South Sea Island cotton, and the green seeded sort, is..."}, {'id': 210, 'article_title': 'COTTON IN AND FROM EGYPT', 'full_section_title': 'COTTON IN AND FROM EGYPT', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_07_1863', 'content': '### EXPORTATION OF COTTON FROM ALEXANDRIA FROM 5TH OCTOBER TO 15TH APRIL.

| Years | England Bales | France Bales | Austria Bales | Total |
|-------|---------------|--------------|--------------|-------|
| 1856-1857 | 37,016 | 8,974 | 9,795 | 56,385 |
| 1857-1858 | 36,747 | 14,031 | 7,826 | 60,604 |
| 1858-1859 | 56,799 | 17,686 | 9,276 | 83,383 |
| 1859-1860 | 74,842 | 16,141 | 5,573 | 96,556 |
| 1860-1861 | 69,665 | 26,826 | 4,969 | 101,460 |
| 1861-1862 | 91,482 | 19,604 | 4,416 | 115,502 |
| 1862-1863 | 109,146 | 28,953 | 5,130 | 141,229 |

It is interesting to observe how much larger a relative proportion of the increased supply comes to England. While the exportation to France is only doubled since 1857, and that to Austria has fallen off one third, the export to England has trebled during the same period.

On the 3rd of June Messrs. Fairman and Co. write:—

"Cotton has fluctuated greatly during the past fortnight, in...
Page 11

Influenced by the advices received per telegraph. At first we had a decline of about ¾d. per lb., which was afterwards recovered, and followed up by a further advance of ¼d.; and again, owing to discouraging news, prices have declined, with a very dull market. Supplies from the interior are now falling off, and better qualities are very scarce. Prices today are the same as we quoted in our last semi-monthly report—viz.: Ordinary to middling, at 1s. 7¼d. to 1s. 8¾d. per lb. f.o.b.; fair to good fair, at 1s. 9d. to 1s. 10d.; good to fine, at 1s. 11d. to 2s.

"The operations of the past fortnight have been very small, in consequence of the Turkish festivals of the Corban Bairam, and consist of about 20,000 crs. of private hand-cleaned, equal to f.o.b., from 1s. 6¼d. to 1s. 8¾d. per lb.; about 7,000 ditto machined ditto, from 1s. 7¾d. to 1s. 10¼d. per lb.; about 500 ditto Zanat ditto, from 1s. 9¾d. to 2s. per lb.; about 300 ditto inferior ditto, from 1s. 3d. to 1s. 8d. per lb."

By this it will be perceived that a portion of the Egyptian cotton is still cleaned by hand.

Cotton seed, they say, had been very quiet, but was again more active, price 130s. to 140s. per ton. Contracts for December next, 130s. to 135s. per ton.

Cotton seed oil is a very valuable article, and cotton oil cake is extremely nutritious and fattening for cattle. We expect that both our manufacturers and cattle breeders will, in the course of a short time, profit largely by the cotton seed, until lately almost everywhere treated as of no value.'}, {'id': 2085, 'article_title': 'Liverpool Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_09_1871', 'content': 'Palm-nut Kernels.—130 bags at 13l. 5s. to 13l. 7s. 6d. per ton.  
Palm Oil.—The market is quieter, and the sales limited to 400 tons. Irregular at 28l. to 31l.; Accra at 32l. 10s.; Bonny at 33l.; Old Calabar at 33l. 12s. 6d. to 33l. 15s.; Lagos at 34l. 15s.; and New Calabar at 37l. 12s. 6d. per ton.

The cotton market opened this week with a good demand, but on Monday and Tuesday was quiet, and prices were slightly in favour of buyers. Yesterday the business increased, and today has been very large, with an advance in most descriptions. Sales of the week about 118,000 bales.

**August 26 to September 2.**

Palm Kernels.—160 tons at 13l. 10s. per ton.  
Palm Oil continues quiet, and the sales reach 350 tons. Irregular at 26l. to 31l.; Bonny at 32l. 15s. to 33l.; Benin at 33l.; Old Calabar at 33l. 10s.; Lagos at 34l. 15s.; New Calabar at 37l. 12s. 6d.; and Brass at 38l. per ton.

Cotton has been in good demand throughout the week, and yesterday the sales were unusually large, with an animated market. To-day there has been a quieter feeling, but quotations generally show an advance of ½d. to ¼d. per lb. Sales of the week about 137,000 bales.

**September 2 to September 9.**

Ebony.—6¼ tons round wood at 17l., and a small lot of flat at 12l. 10s. to 13l. 10s. per ton.  
Barwood.—15 tons, at 31l. 12s. 6d. per ton.  
Palm Kernels.—340 bags African at 12l. to 13l. 7s. 6d. per ton.  
Palm-oil continues quiet, and the sales are 600 tons; Irregular at 27l. to 31l, Benin at 32l. 12s. 6d. to 32l. 15s., Opobo at 32l. 15s., Bonny at 33l, Old Calabar at 33l. 5s. to 33l. 10s., Lagos at 34l. 10s. down to 34l. 7s. 6d., New Calabar at 37l. 10s., and Brass at 38l. per ton.

Cotton has been in fair demand throughout the week, although the trade have not bought to the same extent as during the previous fortnight. Prices have been fairly supported, and the market closes with firmness.

Sales of the week—about 106,000 bales. Price of African Cotton 7d. to 7¾d., Natal, 8d. to 8¼d.

**September 9 to September 16.**

Indigo.—4 cases Bengal at 7s. 6d. to 8s. per lb.; Gambia, 7l. 10s. per cwt.  
Barwood.—Retail sales, at 31. 12s. 6d. per ton.  
Camwood.—10 tons, at 16l. 15s. to 18l. per ton.  
Benni-seed.—Small sales at 59s. per quarter.  
Ground-nuts.—40 tons and 1,270 bags, &c., decorticated at 19l. to 19l. 2s. 6d. per ton.  
Palm-kernels.—50 tons and 850 bags, at 13l. 2s. 6d. to 13l. 10s. per ton.

Palm-oil continues quiet, and the business amounts to 710 tons; Irregular at 26l. to 31l., Accra at 32l. to 32l. 2s. 6d., Cameroons and Benin at 32l. 15s., Bonny at 32l. 15s. to 33l., Old Calabar at 33l. 10s. to 33l. 15s., Lagos at 34l. 10s. to 34l. 15s., Congo at 37l. 15s., and Nun River at 38l. per ton.

The large business in cotton last week has been followed by an equally active demand during the present one, at gradually hardening prices, and to-day the sales have been very extensive, and the quotations are raised about ¼d. per lb.'}, {'id': 2657, 'article_title': 'LIVERPOOL MARKETS.', 'full_section_title': 'LIVERPOOL MARKETS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_01_1874#article-10', 'issue_date': '29_01_1874', 'content': 'JANUARY 10 to 17.**

*PALM OIL* in moderate request, and 450 tons sold; Irregular at 28l. to 34l., Bonny at 33l. 10s., Old Calabar at 34l., Benin and Lagos at 34l. 10s., New Calabar at 36l. 10s., and Brass at 36l. 15s. per ton.

*COTTON.*—Market firmer, but prices unchanged.

**JANUARY 17 to 24.**

*PALM OIL* in regular and steady request, and about 500 tons sold; Irregular at 27l. to 34l., Bonny and Accra at 33l. 10s., Old Calabar at 34l., Lagos at 34l. 10s. to 34l. 15s., New Calabar at 36l. 10s., and Congo at 37l. per ton.

*COTTON.*—Very moderate demand, and prices lower. Ordinary and middling, and fair and good fair, 5½d. to 6½d. Sales of the week, 60,000 bales.'}, {'id': 3404, 'article_title': 'Liverpool Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1877#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_10_1877', 'content': 'August 24 to 31.**

- **Palm Kernels.**—About 150 tons at 14l. 10s. to 14l. 12s. 6d. per ton.
- **Cotton.**—Good markets and prices firm. Sales of the week, 56,000 bales. African sales 5½d.

**August 31 to September 7.**

- **Ebony.**—40 tons Old Calabar at 6l. 15s. to 8l. 5s. per ton.
- **Palm Kernels.**—About 1,000 tons at 14l. 15s. per ton.
- **Palm Oil.**—The sales will reach 600 tons at steady rates for Hard, and rather improving prices for Soft Oils; Bonny sold at 37l. 15s. to 38l., Benin at 38l. 5s., Old Calabar at 38l. 5s. to 38l. 10s., Cameroons at 38l., Lagos at 38l. 15s., New Calabar at 38l. 10s., Niger at 39l., Accra at 37l. 5s. to 37l. 10s., and other Irregular at 33l. to 37l. per ton.
- **Cotton.**—Fair demand, but large quantities offering. Weakened prices. Sales of the week 58,000 bales. African 5¼d. to 5⅝d.

**September 7 to 14.**

- **Beniseed.**—117 bags at 57s. per quarter.
- **Palm Kernels.**—570 bags at 14l. 15s. to 15l. 5s. per ton.
- **Shea Butter.**—100 tons Niger, to arrive, at 38l. per ton.
- **Palm Oil** continues firm, and a large business has been concluded, on the spot and for early arrival, at a further slight improvement for Soft Oil. 800 tons sold: Accra at 37l. 10s., Bonny at 37l. 17s. 6d. to 38l., Benin at 38l. 7s. 6d. to 38l. 10s., Old and New Calabar at 38l. 10s., Lagos at 38l. 17s. 6d. to 39l., Brass and Niger at 39l., and Congo at 39l. 10s., with Irregular at 36l. to 37l. 5s. per ton.
- **Cotton.**—Better market throughout the week. Sales of the week, 85,000 bales. African sold at 5½d.

**September 14 to 21.**

- **Ginger.**—African 300 bags, at 17l. 3s. 6d. per cwt.
- **Palm Kernels.**—890 bags, at 15l. 5s. per ton.
- **Palm Oil.**—The market is steady. 500 tons sold: Irregular at 36l. 10s. to 37l., Bonny and Cameroons at 38l., Old and New Calabar at 38l. 10s., Benin at 38l. 5s., and Lagos and Niger at 39l. per ton.
- **Cotton.**—There has been an active and sustained demand throughout the week, and prices show generally an advance. Sales of the week, 83,000 bales. African sales at 4¾d. to 5¼d.

**September 21 to 28.**

- **Ginger.**—African, 200 bags at 23s. 6d. to 26s. per cwt.
- **India-rubber.**—40 tons African sold at 1s. 9d. for thimbles, 1s. 0½d. to 1s. 0¾d. for tongues, 1s. 3d. for ball, and 8d. per lb. for flake.
- **Palm Kernels.**—22 bags at 15l. 5s. per ton.
- **Adansonia Fibre.**—90 packages at 13l. 10s. to 14l. 10s. per ton.
- **Palm Oil.**—With larger supplies, and only a moderate demand, the sales are about 300 tons, in some instances at rather easier prices for Soft Oil, the sales including—Accra at 37l. 2s. 6d. to 37l. 6s. 3d., New and Old Calabar at 38l. 10s., Cameroons at 38l., and Lagos and Niger at 39l., with Irregular at 34l. 5s. to 37l. per ton.
- **Cotton.**—Active demand, with prices in some cases a shade higher. Sales of the week, 78,000 bales. African sold at 5¼d. to 5⅝d.'}, {'id': 3507, 'article_title': 'Liverpool Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1878#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_02_1878', 'content': 'January 4 to 11.**

**Ebony.**—40 tons sold: Gaboon at 8£. to 8£. 2s. 6d., and Old Calabar, flat at 7£. 10s., and round at 8£. 17s. 6d. per ton, ex quay.

**Camwood.**—10 tons on private terms.

**Beni Seed.**—750 bags at 57s. 6d. per quarter.

**Palm Kernels.**—100 bags at 13£. 5s. to 14£. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—Has been in more request, and, in some instances, rather better prices have been paid, the market closing firm. 500 tons sold: Irregular at 32£. 10s. to 35£. 5s., Accra at 35£. 10s. to 35£. 15s., Benin at 36£. 15s., Old and New Calabar at 37£., Lagos at 38£. 15s., and Bonny, to arrive, at 36£. per ton.

**Cotton.**—Quiet market, without change of prices. Sales of the week, 59,660 bales; African sales, at 53d. to 63d.

**January 11 to 18.**

**Palm Kernels.**—60 bags Monrovia at 13£. 10s. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—Market firm, and, with short supplies, an advance of 10s. has been obtained for some descriptions. 300 tons sold: Bonny at 36£. 10s. to 36£. 15s., Old Calabar at 37£. 10s., New Calabar at 37£. 10s. to 37£. 15s., Brass at 38£., and Lagos at 38£. 10s. to 38£. 15s. per ton.

**Cotton.**—Market variable, and prices slightly lower. Sales of the week, 61,000 bales. African sales at 53d. to 64d.

**Ship Supposed to be Lost.**—The Alice, s., of London, Off. No. 68,019, from the West Coast of Africa to Liverpool, with produce, left Madeira on Nov. 25 last, and has not since been heard of.

**January 18 to 25.**

**Ebony.**—60 tons at 7£. 5s. to 11£. 15s., as in quality.

**Ground Nuts.**—415 bags at 15£. per ton.

**Adansonia Fibre.**—483 bales at 13£. to 14£. 10s. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—Steady at the advanced rates noticed last week, and 300 tons sold: Irregular at 36£., Bonny at 36£. 15s., Benin at 37£., Old Calabar at 37£. 10s., New Calabar at 37£. 15s., Brass at 38£., and Lagos at 38£. 10s. per ton.

**Cotton.**—Market dull; prices generally lower. Sales of the week, 43,500 bales. African sales at 6d. to 6½d.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '685 bags African sold at 60s. to 64s., 80 bags Bahia at 62s., and 100 bags Jacmel at 73s. to 74s. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—The market has ruled quiet, chiefly owing to the small selection of desirable quantities available, and the business is restricted to 31 bags African at 45s. to 55s. per cwt.

**GUM.**—Small sales of Egyptian Amrad at steady prices, with a steady business in Syrian Tragacanth at late rates.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—56 bags at 27s. 9d. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Market very steady, and considerable business done in fine Para at 2s. 11d. to 3s.; Ceara neglected; Peruvian inquired for; African in fair demand at full rates.

**LOGWOOD.**—There is a steady demand from the quay; and a fair business done at late rates.

**FUSTIC.**—More doing generally, and prices are a shade stronger.

**CAMWOOD.**—10 tons at £13 2s. 6d. to £13 5s. per ton, ex quay.

**RED SANDERSWOOD.**—Stock much reduced, and £4 17s. 6d. per ton asked.

**BENNISEED.**—217 bags at 47s. 6d. per 384 lbs.

**PALM KERNELS.**—In fair demand at steady prices, and 4,244 bags sold at £8 15s. to £10 10s. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been a quiet, steady market during the week, without change in value, and 600 tons sold: New Calabar at £20 5s., Benin at £20 to £20 10s., Bonny at £21 5s., and Lagos at £22 15s. to £23 per ton.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, OCTOBER 26.**

**SUGAR.**—The market opened with a quiet tone, but within the last two days there has been more inquiry for the better descriptions, and steady prices paid; medium qualities, however, continue neglected.

**RUM.**—Owing to the continued absence of supplies of Demerara in first hands, there are no sales to report.

**COFFEE.**—Business is very limited, owing to the small quantity available. The African reported shows a decline of about 2s., but, at the close, the tone is steadier. 90 bags St. Mare sold at 74s., and 210 bags African, to arrive, at 61s. 6d. per cwt., tel quel, ex quay.

**COCOA.**—The trade have shown little disposition to purchase, and the market remains quiet, the only transactions reported being 170 bags Para at 65s., and 120 bags Jeremie at 43s. per cwt.

**GUM.**—The transactions are small, but altogether at steady prices, including Egyptian Amrad at 100s., Ghezirah Siftings at 73s., East India descriptions at 38s. 9d. to 70s. per cwt., and fine Brazilian Arabic at full prices.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—29 bags at 31s. 3d. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Para: Market very firm. Peruvian and Ceara rather inquired for, and African in continued good demand at hardening prices.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—1,300 bags at 4s. 3d. to 5s. 9d. per cwt.

**EBONY.**—About 140 tons Gaboon sold, flat at £4 5s. to £4 12s. 6d., and billet and heavy wood at £6 to £6 7s. 6d. per ton; all faults, ex quay.

**PALM KERNELS.**—1,909 bags sold at £8 to £9 18s. 9d. per ton.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-11-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_11_1888#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, AUGUST 31.

SUGAR.—The market has been very quiet throughout the week, with little disposition to operate, either on the part of buyers or sellers, and only a moderate business concluded, without material change in prices.

RUM.—About 320 puncheons of Demerara and 13 puncheons of Jamaica sold at very full prices, the market now being bare of supplies in first hands.

COFFEE.—The market is quiet, and there is very little demand, except for African, which has moved off freely at steady prices. 394 bags African, elephant berry, at 57s., bold berry at 50s., with 950 bags of the latter, to arrive, at 50s. per cwt., tel quel, ex quay.

COCOA.—A moderate business passing, without change in prices, and 159 bags African (St. Thome) sold at 52s. to 58s. per cwt., ex quay and store.

RICE.—The market very firm, with buyers at late rates, but no sellers.

COCHINEAL.—A small lot of black at 11d. per lb.

GUM is very steady, but the sales are limited to Senegal at 172s. 6d. per cwt., with small lots of Brazil at steady prices.

INDIA-RUBBER.—Market quiet and unchanged.

MYRABOLAMS.—1,850 bags sold at 4s. 6d. to 7s. 6d. per cwt., chiefly the latter price.

FUSTIC is rather dearer, the cheapest parcels having been disposed of.

EBONY.—Sales of fine at £5 10s. and of Old Calabar at £5 per ton.

PALM KERNELS continue firm, and 2,100 bags sold at £8 11s. 3d. to £10 6s. 3d. per ton.

PALM OIL.—The market is quiet, but steady, with a moderate business passing at late rates, including Old Calabar and Bonny at £17 15s., and Lagos at £19 10s. to £19 15s. per ton.

LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7.

SUGAR.—The tone of the market has been quiet, but, with some inquiry for suitable descriptions for export, a fair amount of business has been done at steady prices.

RUM remains firm.

COFFEE.—With more demand a fair business has been done during the week, and closing rates mark an advance of fully 2s. per cwt. 471 bags bold berry African, on the spot, at 50s. to 52s. 6d., with sales of Casenga at 50s., and 450 bags bold berry, to arrive, at 50s. to 52s., tel quel, ex quay; 54 bags Bahia at 56s.; 1,260 bags Hayti at 55s. for Aux Cayes, 56s. to 59s. for Jeremie, and at 61s. to 62s. for Jacmel, with 50 bags of the latter at 61s. per cwt., floating, landing for the Continent.

COCOA in limited request, and 97 bags African sold at 50s. to 61s. per cwt.

RICE.—There has been a good speculative demand, and a considerable business done, both on the spot and for arrival, at prices establishing an advance of 1¼d. to 3d. per cwt. To arrive, 1,545 tons Necransie, per Urania, off the coast, sold at 6s. 3d., open charter, 1,200 tons Rangoon, per Scottish Dale, and 500 tons Bassein, both at 7s. 3d. per cwt., ex quay.

GUINEA GRAINS.—20 bags at 24s. 6d. per cwt.

GUM.—About 80 packages of Amrad and Brazil sold at steady to full prices, with sales of Syrian Tragacanth at £8 per cwt.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1888#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 9.

**SUGAR.**—Although the demand continues moderate there is comparatively little offering, and for the small business done steady prices have been obtained.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been quiet all week, and the demand has been principally for African at easier prices. 40 bags Jacmel sold at 82s. 6d., and 875 bags African, bold berry, at 76s. 6d. to 77s. per cwt., ex quay.

**COCOA.**—The market has been very quiet all week, and about 100 bags African sold at 50s. to 52s. per cwt.

**GINGER.**—Small sales of old import African at 20s. per cwt.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—A small lot at 6½ per lb.

**GUM.**—More doing in Niger Arabic, and 1,200 cases sold at 37s. 6d. to 60s., with sales of Arabic sorts at 160s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—The market for Para is weaker, and business in fine and negrorlahas been very limited during the week, the nearest value of fine being 3s. 2d. per lb. at the close. At the auctions of African, on Tuesday, about 80 tons were offered, but, with a poor attendance of buyers, only 9 tons sold at a decline of about ¼d. per lb. On Thursday about 30 tons were brought forward, and only a few tons of tongue sold at 1s. 5½d. During the week about 60 tons have been sold at auction and by private, including Gambia niggers at 2s. 3½d. to 2s. 2d., Sierra Leone twist at 1s. 10d. to 1s. 11½d. and niggers at 1s. to 1s. 10d., Accra biscuits at 1s. 5½d. to 1s. 11½d., Assinee, Axin, and Grand Bassam at 1s. 7d. to 1s. 8½d., Cameroon at 1s. 9½d., Old Calabar niggers at 1s. 10d., Cape Coast and Saltpond at 1s. 1d to 1s. 1¼d., and tongue at 1s. 5½d. per lb.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—About 750 bags sold at 9s. 6d. to 11s. 6d. per cwt., being steady prices.

**WAX.**—Sales of Gambia at steady prices, and 50 sacks Chilian Bees' at £6 2s. 6d. to £6 10s. per cwt., closing firmly at the higher price.

**EBONY.**—20 tons Cameroon at £5 15s. to £7 15s., 331 billets Old Calabar at £5 2s. 6d., and 37 tons Victoria at £5 to £5 7s. 6d. per ton.

**BENNISEED.**—209 bags Niger at 45s. 6d. per 384 lbs., ex quay.

**PALM KERNELS.**—1,279 bags at £10 10s. to £11 12s. 6d. per ton.

**COPRA.**—Small sales of inferior African at £13 10s. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market remains steady, without any change in values, for, whilst there has been very little offering, the demand has been limited, owing to the closing up of some of the Continental ports. The sales include soft oils at £23 10s., quay, and Lagos at £24 to £23 10s., with irregular at £21 5s. per ton, transit.", 'last_edit_date': '1891-01-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**EBONY.**—191 tons Victorian at £5 to £6 5s., 13 tons Old Calabar at £5 10s. to £6 5s., and 30 tons Bibundi at £5 15s. per ton, all ex quay.

**LIMAWOOD.**—Sales at £8 to £8 5s. per ton.

**CAMWOOD.**—8 tons Half Jack on private terms, ex quay.

**PALM KERNELS.**—3,500 bags sold at £9 to £10 5s., being a further decline of 2s. 6d. per ton, the market closing quiet.

---

**GROUND NUTS.**—About 330 bags undecorticated Bathurst at £9 2s. 6d. for common up to £14 per ton for fine.

**COPRA.**—117 bags African, part at £11 15s. per ton, but chiefly on private terms.

**PIASSAVA** is rather firmer in tone, but only a moderate business has been done in African at £36 to £38 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been a fair amount of business concluded during the week at late rates to, in some instances, 5s. decline. The sales include Grand Bassa at £17 15s., Monrovia and Lahou at £18, Grand Bassam and Half-Jack at £18 15s. to £18 10s., Accra-Addah at £19 to £18 15s., Benin at £19, Bonny at £19 2s. 6d., and Lagos at £20 to £19 15s. per ton, all in transit.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**Gum.**—There is some inquiry for different descriptions, and the sales include 60 packages Amrad and Brazilian at 40s. to 66s., sales of Ghezirah Siftings at 73s. to 80s., and 35 packages Brazilian Copal at full prices.

**India-rubber.**—Market very quiet, but Para holders are firm. Ceara and Peruvian still neglected. African only in very retail demand.

**Myrabolams.**—1,465 bags at 3s. to 7s. 6d. per cwt., as in quality.

**Logwood** meets with rather more inquiry.

**Camwood.**—Sales of Grand Bassa at £11 5s. to £15 10s. per ton, as in quality.

**Palm Kernels** have been irregular, low and medium qualities being 5s. to 10s., and fine descriptions about 5s. cheaper on the week; 7,070 bags sold at £7 10s. to £9 12s. 6d. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—There has been a good demand during the week, and all regular oil offering at current rates cleared, with buyers over at the close, whilst sellers are asking, and in some instances refusing, 5s. per ton advance. The sales will reach nearly 1,500 tons, including Operta at £17 10s., Bonny and Old Calabar at £17 5s. to £17 10s., Benin at £16 7s. 6d. to £16 15s., Brass and New Calabar at £16 5s. to £16 15s., and Lagos at £18 to £18 10s. per ton, with Irregular and others at proportionate prices.

**LIVERPOOL, Friday, June 29.**

**Sugar.**—Fine descriptions have been in good request, and realized rather higher prices; medium qualities are unchanged, but low kinds continue difficult of sale at slightly easier rates.

**Molasses, &c.**—American Treacle steady.

**Rum** has been quiet, and 70 puncheons of Demerara sold at late rates.

**Coffee.**—There has been rather more disposition on the part of buyers to operate, but at prices below the views of holders, and the business is restricted to 40 barrels Jamaica at 67s. to 84s., and 100 bags African at 52s. per cwt., in store.

**Gum.**—Brazil continues in request, and a fair business is doing at previous rates; small sales of common Amrad at low prices, and 21 barrels Sierra Leone Copal at 44d. per lb.

**India-rubber.**—Small sales of fine Para during the week at 3s. Ceara and Peruvian continue in disfavour, and African only meets a very limited demand.

**Myrabolams.**—2,030 bags at 6s. 6d. to 7s. 9d. per cwt.

**Logwood** is steady, with a fair demand.

**Palm Kernels.**—2,311 bags at £7 10s. to £9 5s. per ton.

**Ground Nuts.**—155 bags hand-picked, in the shell, at £15 to £15 2s. 6d. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—The demand has been good; the sales during the week will not be far short of 2,000 tons, and, arrivals being inadequate, a large business was concluded at the close yesterday at fully 10s. per ton advance. The transactions include hard regular oils at £16 5s. to £16 15s., Benin at £16 12s. 6d. to £17 5s., soft oils at £17 10s. to £17 15s., and Lagos at £18 5s. to £19 per ton, with Irregular at proportionate prices.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1888#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JUNE 8.

**SUGAR.**—Market very depressed, and only a moderate amount of business done at a further decline of 3d. per cwt.

**COFFEE.**—Early in the week a slight advance was paid for African, but the market closes quiet. Small sales of Ceara at 82s. 6d., store, and of elephant berry, on spot, at 80s., and 180 bags bold berry African, to arrive, at 71s. per cwt., transit.

**COCOA.**—The market continues very quiet, and, to effect sales, easier prices would have to be submitted to. 32 bags African sold at 56s. ex quay, and at 57s. in store, with 49 bags Jeremie at 47s. per cwt., also in store.

**GINGER.**—250 bags Sierra Leone at 35s. to 36s. per cwt., as in quality.

**CHILLIES.**—500 bags Sierra Leone at 30s. per cwt.

**GUM.**—Business in Arabic Sorts is rather small at 40s. to 41s. per cwt. for ordinary quality, being steady prices.

**INDIA RUBBER.**—A rather better feeling is noticeable in the market for Para, and sales of old Bolivian fine have been made at 2s. 10¾d., with an outside parcel of Island fine at 2s. 9¾d. per lb. At the close there are buyers of Island and up river fine at 2s. 9¾d., but no sellers under 2s. 9¾d. per lb. There was very little bidding at the usual Tuesday's auction of African, when about 45 tons were offered, out of which only small sales were effected. During the week the demand has been on a moderate scale at steady prices, and the sales amount to about 20 tons, comprising Grand Bassam at 1s. 1d. to 1s. 4d., Cameroon, 1s. 5d., Accra and Cape Coast biscuits 1s. 10¾d. to 1s. 10¾d. and strips 1s. 11¾d. to 1s. 11¾d., Sierra Leone twists 1s. 9¾d. and niggers at 2s. 0¾d. per lb.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—350 bags second Bombay on private terms.

**CAMWOOD.**—Small sales Grand Bassa at £10 10s. per ton.

**EBONY.**—20 tons Gaboon sold at £8 10s. to £9 15s. per ton, principally the latter, being full prices.

**PALM KERNELS.**—After declining 2s. 6d., have recovered 1s. 3d., and 5,803 bags sold at £10 5s. to £10 16s. 3d. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—200 bags decorticated at £9 to £9 5s. and 330 bags undecorticated Bathurst, common on private terms, medium at £13, and fine at £16 per ton.

**COPRA.**—7 tons African at £13 5s. per ton.

**KOLA NUTS.**—10 packages African at 6d. to 7d. per lb., ex quay.

**PIASSAVA.**—950 bundles African sold at £12 to £15 12s. 6d., with a small parcel of Bereby at £24 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—A moderate business has been concluded at late rates to a partial 5s. decline for some descriptions, and the market closes quiet. The sales include Half-Jack and Grand Bassam at £19 15s., Accra at £20 2s. 6d. to £20, Benin and New Calabar at £20 5s., Bonny at £20 10s. to £20 5s., Old Calabar at £20 10s., and Lagos at £21 5s. to £21 per ton, all in transit.", 'last_edit_date': '1894-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1894#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'PALM OIL.—Early in the week a good business was done, since when, however, the demand has fallen off, and at the close the market is quiet, with only a limited inquiry. Sales 900 tons; Benin at £20 15s., Old Calabar at £21 5s., Openta at £21 7s. 6d., and Lagos at £23 10s., with Irregular at previous prices.

LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 22.

SUGAR.—The market has been very inanimate throughout the week, and only a limited business done, without quotable change in prices.

COFFEE.—There has been considerably more demand during the week, and a good business has been done at full prices to 1s. advance. The market has been affected by decreased crop estimates and the revolution in Brazil. 56 bags fine Central American at 84s., 45 bags Gonaives at 86s., 100 bags African, bold berry, at 78s. 6d. in store, and, to arrive, 1,850 bags at 71s. 6d. to 73s. 6d. per cwt., tel quel, ex quay.

COCOA.—Owing to the paucity of desirable quality offering business has been moderate, and prices show no material change. 70 bags Jeremie sold at 40s. to 41s. per cwt., the latter price ex quay.

GUM.—There is considerably more inquiry for Brazilian Arabic, and 200 bags sold, part at 27s. 6d. per cwt., and part on private terms, with small sales of Senegal at steady prices.

INDIA-RUBBER.—A fair business concluded in African at steady rates. Para steady, but little passing.

MYRABOLAMS.—About 2,000 bags sold at 5s. to 9s. 9d. per cwt.

CANARY SEED.—About 1,600 bags Turkish sold, on the spot and to arrive, at 33s. 3d. to 31s. per 464 lbs., as in quality.

ALGARROBILLA.—112 bags at £16 5s. per ton.

PALM OIL.—A good business done for forward delivery at late rates to 5s. decline on some descriptions. 1,000 tons sold: hard oils at £20, soft oils at £20 15s., Accra at £20 10s., Benin at £20 15s., and Lagos at £23 10s., with Irregular at £19 12s. 6d. per ton.

LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 29.

SUGAR.—There has been an improved demand for fine descriptions, partly for export, at an advance of 3d. to 6d. from the recent lowest point; medium kinds are unchanged, but low qualities are 3d. per cwt. dearer.

COFFEE.—There has been a continued good inquiry, and considerable business has been done, both on spot and to arrive, at prices showing 1s. to 1s. 6d. advance. 300 bags African at 74s. to 75s., ex store and quay, 1,000 bags, to arrive, at 74s. to 74s. 6d., 1 tierce 8 barrels Jamaica at 95s. to 106s., 62 bags Jacmel at 86s., ex quay, 25 bags Savanilla at 87s. 6d, 200 bags Bahia at 78s. 6d., and 34 frazils of New Granada at 85s. to 96s. per cwt.

COCOA has been in moderate request at late rates, and 47 bags African sold at 45s., and 143 bags of Jeremie at 40s. to 42s. per cwt., ex quay.

GUINEA GRAINS.—22 bags at 26s. 6d. per cwt.

GUM.—Sales of Brazil at 27s. 6d. per cwt., with small sales of Tragacanth at steady prices.

INDIA-RUBBER.—Para is very steady, with a moderate business passing. Of African, large sales have been concluded on private terms.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "## LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MAY 1.

**SUGAR.**—Importers having submitted to a decline of 3d. per cwt. for fine descriptions, the trade has purchased more freely, and a good amount of business has been done; low and medium descriptions continue to support previous values.

**RUM.**—Recent arrivals of Demerara have been placed on the market, but, so far, only a small quantity has been disposed of at prices showing an advance on late rates, as anticipated.

**COFFEE.**—There is only a small inquiry, but holders are firm, and do not press sales. 100 bags African at 80s. 9d. per cwt., ex quay.

**COCOA.**—Cocoa has met with only a limited demand, but prices are well maintained. 42 bags of African sold at 32s. 6d. to 46s. per cwt.

**GINGER.**—A good business has been done in African, and about 850 bags have changed hands at an all-round advance of fully 6d. per cwt., the prices being from 21s. 6d. to 23s. for new crop, and up to 24s. per cwt. for old crop.

**GUM.**—There is a fair inquiry for Brazilian at steady rates, but the little offering checks business.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Para has been in active demand during the week, and about 50 tons of fine quality have been sold at 3s. 8d., and at the close sellers are asking 3s. 8½d. per lb., but, so far, the advance has not been paid. African has also met with rather more inquiry, and, holders in some instances being firm, business has been rather restricted; about 30 tons sold at steady prices, including Sierra Leone twists at 1s. 11½d. and low niggers at 1s. 0½d. to 1s. 3½d., Accra biscuits 1s. 6d. to 2s., pressed Cape Coast 1s. 5d. to 1s. 7½d., and ordinary Cape Coast 1s. 1d. to 1s. 2d., Cameroon 1s. 9½d., Addah niggers 1s. 9½d. to 1s. 10d., and low Grand Bassam at 1s. 7d. per lb.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—Very firmly held on spot, and only 159 bags reported at 7s. 3d. to 12s. per cwt.; nothing offering to arrive.

**EBONY.**—Small sales of Half Jack at £11 per ton.

**PALM KERNELS.**—There has been little offered at auction, owing to the absence of arrivals, but there is a better tone in the market, and buyers can be found at a slight advance on last week's rates. 440 bags sold at £10 10s. to £12 7s. 6d. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—100 bags Gambia at £12 10s. to £12 15s. per ton, ex quay.

**KOLA NUTS.**—20 bags at 2d. to 5½d. per lb., as in quality.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been a marked improvement in the demand, and a large business done, chiefly in Lagos, to arrive, at £24 5s. to £25, the market closing generally very firm, with little offering at the moment. The sales include Saltpond at £22 10s., Congo at £23, Benin at £23 15s. to £24, Accra-Addah at £23 10s. to £23 15s., Cameroon at £24 5s., Bonny at £24 10s., and Lagos at £24 5s. to £25 per ton, all transit.", 'last_edit_date': '1891-05-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1891#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, NOV. 4.**

**SUGAR.**—There has been a good demand, and large business done, prices of fine and medium showing an advance of 6d., whilst low sorts may be quoted 3d. per cwt. dearer, and transactions would have been more extensive but for the limited selection offering.

**COFFEE.**—The market for African closes quieter, and late rates are with difficulty obtainable. About 350 bags African, medium at 63s. to 63s. 6d., in store, bold (at auction) at 63s. 9d. to 64s. 3d., ex quay, and elephant berry at 78s. to 82s. per cwt.

**CHILLIES.**—70 bags of Sierra Leone have been sold at 45s. per cwt., ex quay.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—20 bags at 1¾d. per lb.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—There has been a fair amount of business done in fine Para, of recent import, during the week at again rather easier prices, closing with sellers at 2s. 9¾d., being a decline of ¼d.; scrappy negroheads are firmly held for 2s. 2d., and Island negroheads for 1s. 10½d. per lb. There has been a good business done in African during the past week at prices showing a decline of ¼d. to ½d. per lb. The sales, which amount to about 60 or 70 tons, include thimbles at 1s. 6½d., Loango ball 1s. 6¾d., Cameroon ball 1s. 6d., Old Calabar 1s. 4¾d., Manoh twists 1s. 10d., Sierra Leone niggers 1s. 6d., Accra and Cape Coast biscuits 1s. 8d. to 1s. 9d., Grand Bassam 1s. 2½d. to 1s. 4¾d., and soft Cape Coast at 1s. 2¼d. per lb.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—About 1,500 bags sold at 5s. 3d. to 8s. 6d. per cwt., as in quality.

**EBONY.**—About 30 tons Old Calabar at £6 2s. 6d. per ton, ex quay, being steady prices.

**BENNISEED.**—1,540 bags Akassa at 40s. per 384 lbs., ex quay.

**PALM KERNELS.**—350 bags Cameroon at £10 17s. 6d. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—100 bags common undecorticated Bathurst at £11, and 270 bags fine at £14 per ton, ex quay.

**COPRA.**—Small sales of African at £11 10s. per ton.

**PIASSAVA.**—About 2,000 bundles of African sold at £25 10s. to £27 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market continues steady, with a limited quantity offering on spot and near at hand, and values in these positions are again about 5s. dearer on the week; distant arrivals quiet and unchanged. The sales include Benin, Cameroon, and New Calabar at £20 10s., Accra-Addah at £20 10s. to £20 15s., Bonny at £20 15s., and Lagos at £23 5s. per ton, all in transit.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, NOV. 11.**

**SUGAR.**—Fair inquiry, but only a moderate amount of business reported at full prices, and transactions would have been more extensive but for the limited quantity offering.

**COFFEE.**—The market is only poorly supplied, and the moderate sales reported are at about steady prices. 67 barrels Jamaica at 85s. to 127s., and 112 bags African, on spot, at 57s. for low, 63s. 6d. for medium, in store, and 80s. for elephant, ex quay, with 350 bags bold berry, to arrive, at 63s. 6d. per cwt., tel quel, in transit.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—23 bags at 1¾d. per lb.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—18 bags at 22s. 6d. per cwt.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1892#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**CHILLIES.**—16 bags African at 40s. per cwt.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—Small sales at 24s. per cwt.

**GUM.**—Further sales of Brazilian Arabic at 28s. (and higher prices now asked), of Niger Arabic at 35s. to 55s., and of fine Arabic Sorts at 90s. per cwt.

cwt. A small parcel of Sierra Leone Copal met with extreme competition at auction at 7d. to 1s. 9½d. per lb.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—The Para market has been dull and inactive since our last, and no business of importance reported in fine new import, the nominal value of which is still given at 2s. 11d., but sales of negroheads have been made at 1s. 11½d. per lb., being an easier price. There has only been a moderate demand for African during the week, and between 15 and 20 tons sold at a slight decline from the highest prices recently paid. The sales include Congo ball at 1s. 7½d. to 1s. 8d., Manoah 1s. 6d., Accra biscuits 1s. 7d. to 1s. 8d., Old Calabar 1s. 3½d., Sierra Leone twists 1s. 9½d. and flat 1s. 4¾d., ordinary Cape Coast 1s. 3d., and Liberian at 1s. 5d. per lb.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—250 bags at 8s. 6d. to 10s. per cwt.

**EBONY.**—70 tons Gaboon at £6 10s. to £6 17s. 6d., and 2 tons Old Calabar at £6 10s. per ton, all ex quay.

**CAMWOOD.**—7 tons Grand Bassa, ex quay, at £27 5s. per ton.

**LIMAWOOD.**—Sales of Altata at £8 5s. per ton.

**PALM KERNELS.**—3,760 bags sold at £10 to £10 7s. 6d. per ton, ex quay, being 2s. 6d. decline.

**COPRA.**—210 bags African at £11 15s. to £12 per ton, ex quay.

**PIASSAVA.**—400 bundles African at £38 to £40 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market has been weak and depressed, and a further decline of fully 5s. has had to be accepted to effect sales. The business includes soft oils at £19 10s. to £19 5s., Fernando Po and Cameroon at £19, Lagos at £21 to £20 10s., Accra-Addah at £19 5s. to £19, Saltpond and Winnebah at £19, Dixcove at £18 15s., Half-Jack at £18 5s., and Benin, spot and forward, at £19, all transit, and Benin, ex quay, at £19 10s. per ton.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, APRIL 22.**

**SUGAR.**—Business has been generally interrupted by the holidays, the market opening dull, with little disposition on the part of the trade to operate, and the small business done shows a further decline of about 3d. per cwt.

**COFFEE** has been steady all week, and a fair amount of business done, without change in price. 38 barrels Jamaica at 95s., 220 bags Ceara at 68s. 6d. to 70s. 6d., and 1,240 bags African bold berry at 58s. 9d. to 59s. tel quel, ex quay, and 59s. 6d. to 59s. 9d. per cwt. tel quel ex quay in transit.

**COCOA.**—There has been rather more general inquiry, and fair sales made at fully late rates. 258 bags Jeremie at 45s. to 50s., 300 bags African at 51s. to 54s., and 100 bags fermented Bahia at 60s. per cwt. ex quay.

**GINGER.**—50 bags African at 27s. 6d. per cwt., and sales on private terms.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—18 bags at 2½d. per lb., ex quay and store.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—5 bags at 25s. per cwt.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**GUM.**—There is rather more disposition to meet buyers of quantity; cheap qualities are inquired for, but no supplies are available. Small sales of Brazilian and Egyptian Amrad reported on private terms.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—A fractional decline in the value of Para has caused more demand for the article, and about 85 tons sold at 2s. 8¾d. to 2s. 8¾d. per lb. for fine. Only a small business done in African at late rates.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—200 bags sold at 4s. to 11s. 3d. per cwt.

**LOGWOOD** is in steady demand at late rates.

**CAMWOOD.**—Sales of Grand Bassa at £14 10s. per ton.

**PALM KERNELS** steady; 2,967 bags sold at £7 2s. 6d. to £10 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market opened flat, but sellers having met buyers freely, a large business has been done, about 2,000 tons; soft oils at £19 to £19 10s., Lagos at £21 to £21 5s., New Calabar at £18 5s. to £18 10s., Benin at £18 to £18 10s., hard oils at £18 to £18 5s. per ton, and Irregular at proportionate prices, the market closing with a firmer tone.

#### LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 22.

**SUGAR.**—There has been an active demand throughout the week, both on the spot and for arrival, and a large business concluded at prices showing an advance of fully 3d. per cwt.

**COFFEE.**—The market has ruled very quiet, and, to effect sales, easier prices would have to be accepted. 92 bags African, Elephant berry, sold at 81s., 200 bags Aux Cayes at 82s. 6d. to 83s., and 150 bags Jacmel at 85s. per cwt.

---

**COCOA.**—The market is quiet, with little disposition to operate, the only sales reported being 20 bags African at 57s. 6d. to 59s., with small sales of Para at 63s. per cwt., ex quay.

**CHILLIES.**—100 bags African at 25s. 6d. to 26s. 6d. per cwt.

**GUM.**—The business continues very limited, and the sales are chiefly confined to Brazilian at 40s. to 72s. 6d., as in quality, with 60 bags Lagos Copal at 22s. 6d. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Para is quiet, and prices slightly in buyers' favour.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—500 bags at 7s. 9d. per cwt.

**BENNISEED.**—100 bags at 37s. per 384 lbs.

**PALM KERNELS** steady; 3,600 bags sold at £9 7s. 6d. to £10 1s. 8d. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been a good demand, and, with only a moderate supply offering, an advance of 5s. to 10s. has been obtained. 1,100 tons sold; Benin at £19, soft oils at £19 10s. to £19 15s., Old Calabar and Bonny at £19 15s. to £20, Cameroon at £19 12s. 6d., and Lagos at £22 5s. with Irregular at £17 12s. 6d. to £18 per ton.

#### LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 29.

**SUGAR.**—There has been a strong market throughout the week, and a large business done, both on the spot and to arrive, at prices showing an advance of 6d. to 9d. per cwt.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been very quiet during the week, and the small business done shows a decline of 6d. to 1s. per cwt. 100 bags African sold at 75s. 6d., ex quay, 51 barrels and bags Jamaica at 84s. to 92s., and 190 bags Aux Cayes at 82s. 6d. to 83s. per cwt.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1889#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**GUINEA GRAINS.**—Small sales at 18s. per cwt.

The sales, which amount to about 12 tons, include up river fine at 3s. 2d., Island fine at 3s. 1¾d., new Island negroheads at 2s. 0¼d., and scrappy negroheads at 2s. 4¼d. per lb. Of Ceara scrap about 150 bales have been sold at 1s. 10¾d. to 1s. 11d. per lb. At auction 1½ tons of Peru sheet changed hands at 2s. 11¼d. to 3s. 0¾d. per lb. There has been a fair amount of business done in African at fully steady prices. The sales, which amount to between 50 and 60 tons, include Cameroon ball at 1s. 5½d., Cameroon clusters at 1s. 6½d., Half-Jack, Grand Bassa, Assinie, and Bayin at 1s. 4d. to 1s. 5¾d., Sierra Leone niggers at 1s. 10d. to 2s. 0¾d., and twists at 1s. 10d. to 1s. 10¾d., pressed Accra at 1s. 4¼d., paste Accra at 5d. to 6¾d., Gambia at 1s. 3¼d. to 2s. 2d., ordinary Saltpond at 1s. 1d. to 1s. 1¼d., and Mavumbah ball at 1s. 5½d. per lb.

**WAX.**—9 packages Sierra Leone Bees' at £7, in store, and 25 bags Carnauba, grey on private terms and yellow at 130s. to 132s. 6d. per cwt.

**EBONY.**—85 tons Old Calabar on private terms.

**PALM KERNELS.**—398 bags sold at £9 15s. per ton, ex quay, transit, being the turn in buyers' favour.

**COPRA.**—72 bags African at £12 10s. per ton, ex quay.

**KOLA NUTS.**—32 bags dry sold at 5¾d. to 10d., with 16 baskets fresh at 6¾d. per lb.

**MEXICAN FIBRE.**—Little remains firm. Sisal is easier at £12 to £12 5s. per ton, c. i. f. terms.

**PALM OIL.**—The demand has continued slow, and a moderate business done at 5s. to 10s. per ton, decline, the market closing with a very quiet tone. The sales include soft oils at £19 12s. 6d., ex quay, and £20 2s. 6d., transit, Grand Bassa and Half-Jack at £19 to £18 10s., Lahou at £18, hard oils at £19 10s., Benin at £20, Accra at £20 to £19 10s., and Lagos at £21 to £20 10s. per ton, all transit.", 'last_edit_date': '1895-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1895#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**SUGAR.**—There has been a very firm tone in the market throughout the week, but, with only a limited selection offering, for which holders ask extreme rates, business has been restricted.

Spot business, under the circumstances, is demoralised, and quotations are nominal.

**COCOA** has continued quiet, and only a small business done at about late rates; 124 bags African sold at 50s. to 58s. 6d. per cwt.

**GUM.**—The business continues very limited, and only 10 bags selected Brazil sold at 60s. per cwt., being a full price.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—African has been in fair demand, and steady prices paid, whilst Para remains quiet.

**BENNISEED.**—218 bags sold at 44s. per 384 lbs.

**PALM KERNELS** are steady, with a fair business passing; 93 tons and 9,878 bags sold at £8 12s. 6d. to £10 8s. 9d. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—77 bags fine undecorticated at £13 10s. per ton.

**COPRA.**—68 bags at £12 5s. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—A good business has been done, and the decline noticed last week has been partially recovered. 1,000 tons sold; Accra and Addah at £19, Benin at £19 5s., soft oils at £19 15s., and Lagos at £21 to £21 10s. per ton.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JUNE 28.**

**SUGAR.**—There has been an active demand, and a good business done, both on the spot and to arrive, prices of medium and fine qualities having advanced 9d. to 1s., and low sorts 6d. per cwt., the market closing strong.

**RUM** continues steady, and 130 puncheons Demerara sold at firm prices.

**COFFEE** still continues very depressed; quotations are more or less nominal, in the absence of demand, and the only sales are 145 bags African at 70s., 25 packages Jamaica at 76s. 6d. to 130s., and 50 bags of Gonaives at 83s. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—The tone continues dull, and, with little or no disposition on the part of the trade to operate; there are no sales to report beyond a small parcel of African at 40s. to 54s. per cwt.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—A small lot sold at 6d. per lb.

**GUM.**—Only a very small business continues to be done, the demand being quite of a retail character.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Para is still very quiet, and prices have a downward tendency. Only a limited business done in African at rather easier prices.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—Small sales at 8s. 9d. per cwt., in store.

**PALM KERNELS.**—1,500 bags sold at £8 3s. 9d. to £9 15s. per ton.

**COPRA.**—40 bags at £6 to £12 10s. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—A moderate inquiry has been experienced, and a fair business has resulted at steady prices. Only small sales of African have been made at steady prices, and the sales include small Gaboon Ball at 1s. 4d., medium Sierra Leone niggers at 1s. 10d., medium Sierra Leone twists at 1s. 9½d., Lome niggers at 1s. 7¾d., and Grand Bassam at 1s. 5d. per lb.

## IVORY.—The quarterly sales, which took place on Tuesday, comprised about 15½ tons of various qualities of African; buyers were very indifferent, and showed but little disposition to operate, except at lower prices, owing to large stocks at Antwerp. The sales were consequently slow and dragging, with prices irregular, and registering a decline of £2 to £3 for medium sized teeth and bangles; large teeth were even lower, especially if at all defective. Small scrivelloes were £1 to £2 lower, but balls brought full rates. The small quantity of Lisbon Ivory sold was at full prices.

## EBONY.—18 tons Old Calabar at £5 10s. per ton, ex quay.

## PALM KERNELS.—2,000 bags sold at £9 2s. 6d. to £9 12s. 6d. per ton, ex quay, transit.

## PIASSAVA.—2,000 bundles Grand Bassa at £19 to £20 per ton, ex quay.

## PALM OIL.—Holders having submitted to a further decline of 5s. to 10s., there has been an improved demand, and a good business done at the quotations, the market closing firm, with buyers at an advance. hh: During the colonial period, Africa's integration into global trade networks was characterized by complex economic interactions with Europe, driven by mutual demand for African products and European goods.
result: During the colonial period, Africa's integration into global trade networks was characterized by complex economic interactions with Europe, driven by mutual demand for African products and European goods. The "General History of Africa" textbook highlights how pre-colonial trade networks and Africa's participation in the world economy influenced the establishment of the colonial economy. European colonizers preferred areas with existing trade relations, and African communities were more susceptible to adopting colonial economic innovations, such as cash-crop cultivation for European markets. European commercial firms played a crucial role in connecting Africa with Western markets, emphasizing the exploitative nature of these interactions through unequal exchange. The significant increase in imports of European manufactured goods, particularly textiles, displaced some local manufacturing. The transformation of Africa's economic relations with Europe is evident in the shift from the slave trade to legitimate trade in products like palm oil and groundnuts, although this integration was often exploitative and disadvantageous, leading to dependency on monocrop production. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight the trade in palm oil and palm kernels, significant exports from West Africa to Europe, facilitated by European merchants who provided loans and goods to African chiefs. The import of European goods such as cotton, hardware, and alcohol into Africa indicates a reciprocal demand. The development of infrastructure, such as steamers and railways, further enhanced trade. However, challenges such as the exhaustion of natural resources and the need for improved agricultural practices suggest that the integration was not without difficulties. Both sources align in illustrating the mutual economic interests and intricate trade relationships between Africa and Europe during the colonial period, while also acknowledging the exploitative and challenging aspects of this integration.
gha: The paragraphs from the "General History of Africa" textbook provide several details that support the claim that Africa's integration into global trade networks during the colonial period was characterized by complex economic interactions with Europe, driven by mutual demand for African products and European goods. The text highlights how pre-colonial trade networks and Africa's participation in the world economy influenced the colonial economy's establishment. European colonizers preferred areas with existing trade relations, and African communities were more susceptible to adopting colonial economic innovations, such as cash-crop cultivation for European markets. The text also discusses the role of European commercial firms in connecting Africa with Western markets, emphasizing the exploitative nature of these interactions through unequal exchange. Additionally, the text notes the significant increase in imports of European manufactured goods, particularly textiles, into Africa, which displaced some local manufacturing. The transformation of Africa's economic relations with Europe, driven by the demand for African raw materials and European manufactured goods, is evident in the shift from the slave trade to legitimate trade in products like palm oil and groundnuts. However, the text also highlights the exploitative and disadvantageous nature of this integration, with African economies becoming dependent on monocrop production and vulnerable to international trade conditions. Overall, the textbook aligns with the claim by illustrating the complex and often exploitative economic interactions between Africa and Europe during the colonial period.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that Africa's integration into global trade networks during the colonial period was characterized by complex economic interactions with Europe, driven by mutual demand for African products and European goods. The articles highlight the trade in palm oil and palm kernels, which were significant exports from West Africa to Europe, particularly to the United Kingdom and Germany. This trade was facilitated by European merchants who provided loans and goods to African chiefs to encourage the exchange of native products. The articles also mention the import of European goods such as cotton, hardware, and alcohol into Africa, indicating a reciprocal demand for European products. Additionally, the development of infrastructure, such as steamers and railways, is noted as a means to enhance trade, further supporting the claim of complex economic interactions. However, the articles also point out challenges, such as the exhaustion of natural resources and the need for improved agricultural practices, which suggest that the integration was not without its difficulties. Overall, the articles align with the claim by illustrating the mutual economic interests and the intricate trade relationships between Africa and Europe during the colonial period.

[{'document_title': 'The colonial economy', 'section_title': 'Conquest and new production relations, i88o-¿\ 1910', 'content': "The most decisive variable affecting the implanting of the colonial economy was the extent to which various parts of Africa had already been participating in the world economy. This was partly because Europeans preferred jurisdiction over areas with which they were already familiar, and partly because pre-colonial foreign trade orientation caused African communities to be more susceptible to colonial economic innovations, such as the cultivation of crops specifically for sale to Europeans. The slaving zones from Senegal to Sierra Leone, from the Gold Coast (now Ghana) to Nigeria and from the Congo river to Angola were the stretches of coast› line first encroached upon by the European colonizers. In these localities, features of the colonial economy emerged before the formal advent of colonial rule, because of mutual African and European attempts to stimulate export commodities which served as 'legitimate' replacements to slaves. Rulers, professional traders and other sectors of the population in western Africa perceived advantages in maintaining the foreign trade nexus and access to imported goods. Of course, African propensity to trade with Europeans was not always restricted to the coast. Europeans knew that their trade with West Africa had its roots inland. Indeed, they overestimated the amount of wealth which could be readily made if they penetrated to these sources. This accounts for the commercial attention paid to the countryside above the Niger/Benue confluence during the 1880s and 1890s.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.725, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the world-economy', 'section_title': 'The West African pattern', 'content': 'who went into the interior and shipped them overseas, and vice-versa. 23 New export-oriented production necessarily implied new imports. The firm bought produce in and exported it from Africa. They also imported and sold a variety of manufactured goods, mostly textiles. McPhee, Bauer and Hopkins have rightly emphasized the firms' role in expanding the traders' frontier and the cash sector as a whole, but they say very little about the exploitative tendencies of these firms.$^{76}$ Traders - Europeans, Indians, Lebanese, and to a limited extent, Africans - appropriated the surplus generated by peasant production, especially through unequal exchange. They paid little for produce and charged relatively high prices for imported goods. The experience of Latin American peasants is quite relevant here.
A further obstacle to the commercial development of the smallholders' economy is the marketing mechanism. On account of the contractual inferiority of the peasant, and the usual concentration of three com› mercial functions in the hands of single individuals (purchaser of produce, supplier of credit and vendor of consumption goods), any surpluses developed by the little economy tend to be transferred to the middleman rather than remain available for reinvestment. 77 In settler-dominated areas, for example Southern Rhodesia, it 'became customary for European landowners to market their tenants' produce, and often that of neighbouring peasants as well',$^{78}$ a practice which minimized African competition and assured the settler of a semi-monopolistic position.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.72, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the world-economy', 'section_title': 'The West African pattern', 'content': "Coast (now Ghana), though to a lesser degree,$^{16}$ and in Dahomey (now the Republic of Benin) where the slave trade had been of such great importance that the local population might be said to have been effectively incorporated already via the slave trade. 17 A second major new product was groundnuts (peanuts), whose exportoriented production began on the Upper Guinea coast in the 1830s, and spread out westward to Senegambia.$^{18}$ Rubber was a third major product, although trade in it started much later and in part to compensate for the decline in the demand for palm oil.$^{19}$ The late slave-trade period and the subsequent expansion of cash-crop production in coastal or near-coastal zones in turn stimulated an economic expansion in the Central Sudanic zone of West Africa (livestock, potash, agricultural products, leather goods). 20 To be sure, not all attempts at creating new forms of cash-crop pro› duction succeeded. In particular it seems that direct European involvement was counterproductive, as in the failed efforts at agricultural colonization in Waalo between 1819 and 1831,$^{21}$ and in the various efforts in Senegal, the southern Gold Coast, and Nigeria later on.$^{22}$ It was not that European personnel began to loom larger on the African scene; rather, the important change was that Europeans were largely displacing African merchants from The shift from the slave trade to palm oil strengthened the hand of private as against royal merchants (R. Law, 1977) and increased the importance of the northern savanna trade, as it did for Asante (Ashanti). See J. F. Munro, 1976, p. 46. But most of all, it caused fundamental changes more in the production than in the commercial arena. 'The bulking up, transporting and storage of commodities like palm oil and groundnuts, and the breaking down of imported goods into the quantities needed for many small producers, required more manpower than the trade in slaves'. See J. F. Munro, 1976, 47. the role of those in the port areas who purchased bulk items from traders who went into the interior and shipped them overseas, and vice-versa. 23 New export-oriented production necessarily implied new imports.
