Coastal Makua chiefs and aspiring merchants, for example, began', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Peoples and states of the Great Lakes region', 'section_title': 'Trading circuits', 'content': 'There was, in the nineteenth century, another extensive exchange network centring on the general Bunyoro area, extending to the north and north-west into the Acholi region and West Nile, to the east through the Lake Kyoga area to the slopes of Mount Elgon, and to the south-west through the salt lakes into the Kivu area. Ironware and salt were the evident mainstays of this trading circuit, yet foodstuffs and livestock were probably crucial to the elaboration and maintenance of the system. In one zone north of Lake Kyoga, the Langi produced planned surpluses of food, particularly sesame, for trade.$^{26}$ In the nineteenth century, this sesame was destined for Bunyoro to the west, for exchange for iron hoes, which in turn con› tributed to the expansion of sesame production in the Lango area. Careful study has shown that such surplus production probably involved an array of innovations and refinements in production, land use, cropping, planting and sowing cycles, and labour, in order to maximize output.$^{27}$ Here was something of an agricultural transformation, in some ways comparable to that evolving nearly simultaneously in Bukerebe and still another in the Ijwi Islands of Lake Kivu. 28 One might postulate that individuals and groups participating in the exchange circuit of western present-day Uganda saw the readiness of the Langi to increase sesame output for the market in the nineteenth century as a means of, first, stimulating the trade in ironware to the east - over› coming the precedence in that area of the ironware produced in Samia near the Lake Victoria coast (close by the present Kenya-Uganda border) and thereby stimulating further growth of iron production in Bunyoro; second, forging deeper inter-regional relations between Bunyoro and Lango, relations, perhaps, of dependence or unequal exchange; and, third, creating wealth through the expansion of such commerce, which would in the second half of the nineteenth century pull in valuable ivory from the north-western foothills of Mount Elgon.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Peoples and states of the Great Lakes region', 'section_title': 'Trading circuits', 'content': 'and Usukuma looked to the Bukerebe surpluses and the Bukerebe marketeers as means of resolution of periodic shortfalls in the local food supply. Occasionally, it seems, this dependence led to accusations against Bukerebe traders of profiteering from the misery of Usukuma farmers by simply raising the prices of Bukerebe food transported to Usukuma during famines. 23 If Bukerebe traders held a predominant middleman position in the south, Basuba intermediaries dominated transport and exchange along the more northerly reaches of this eastern lake trade circuit. With exceptional skill and courage, the Basuba navigated the Lake Victoria waters, trans› porting salt, slaves, dried bananas, grain, beans, livestock, fish, and iron over a great area, connecting the Bukerebe markets in the south to the south Busoga and Buvuma markets in the north. 24 The monopoly of exchange that the Basuba developed over the northern sectors of the eastern lake system in the nineteenth century rather paralleled the monopolies developed by Bagabo and Bashingo traders in the region of the salt lakes in western present-day Uganda.$^{25}$ Each of these groups constructed a well-organized exchange diaspora encompassing political control over production and marketing of salt under the remote licence and protection of the Nyoro and Toro courts. In both the salt lakes and eastern lake circuit, the exchange diaspora evolved its monopoly away from the regular purview of the Lakes Plateau state, did not utilize the model of the state in evolving its marketing network, and only came to accom- modate the demands of states of the region when, occasionally, their regions of production, their markets, and their fleets came under attack.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The countries of the Zambezi basin', 'section_title': 'The slave trade and incorporation into the capitalist world economy', 'content': 'The intensified competition among the traders and their virtual mon› opoly of modern weapons thus dramatically altered the character of the slave trade in the period after 1840. Whereas most slaves had probably been obtained through legal commerce in the preceding period, raiding and conquest replaced it as the dominant mode of acquisition. According to Chikunda traditions; for example, in the earlier phase of the slave trade they were able to purchase Nsenga, Chewa and Tonga slaves, many of whom were originally criminals, social outcasts or strangers. Subsequently, however, they used coercive tactics to satisfy the coastal demand. 34 Similarly, Yao itinerant traders initially exploited their access to cheap cloth and iron hoes to achieve a pre-eminent commercial position, but external pressures during the second half of the century motivated them to exert military pressure in the Shire valley in order to ensure their economic hegemony.$^{35}$ Makua participation in the slave trade underwent a parallel transformation while force had always been a component of the Arab-Swahili strategy. 36 To ensure a constant supply of captives and ivory, a number of trading groups carved out sizeable conquest states. Although differing in detail, these polities shared common characteristics that shaped their historical development. All these alien overlords relied heavily on European weapons to impose their hegemony and maintain their pre-eminence. These soph› isticated weapons were acquired in exchange for captives in an updated version of the gun-slave cycle. Once firmly entrenched, the alien ruling classes expanded the frontiers of their empire; while the amount of force varied, coercion was the dominant mechanism of incorporation. The new acquisitions provided additional sources of slaves and ivory, which were used to increase the size of their arsenals, thereby enabling further expan› sion. Although politically independent, these conquest states were an indirect, or secondary, extension of European economic and military power into the interior.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 125, 'article_title': 'SHERBORO', 'full_section_title': 'SHERBORO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1863#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_03_1863', 'content': 'His Excellency Major Blackall, Governor of Sierra Leone, has been here. He issued a proclamation by which Her Majesty's Government declares that the territories known as Quia, Bendoo, and Char, the Bargroo, and Sherboro and Turtle islands, are formally annexed to Sierra Leone, their limits are defined, and the laws of Sierra Leone are declared to be in force.

Taxes are to be collected, and all goods imported direct to the Sherboro are to pay the same duties as at Freetown, Sierra Leone. The amount of cotton exported is greater than during any previous year.

The Early Dawn informs us that "there was a raid on the 11th January by a war party made up of several marauding bands from the different rivers that flow into the Sherboro, and some of them from York Island, and other parts of British Sherboro, attacked and captured without resistance the village of Dumbuco. The people fled in all directions, but were pursued and captured, together with all their property; women and children, not less than men, being taken and divided among the different war men as their lawful slaves. Nor was it alone the people of this village, but strangers stopping on this part of the island, and whoever was helpless and defenceless, shared the like fate. Late in the afternoon of the same day Lieutenant Walsh, commanding the British forces in the Sherboro, came over from Bendoo and interposed for the protection of the people, and the arrest of the marauders. But in the meantime several canoes had left, carrying captives and plunder. Some of them, however, were met by the boats, captured, and brought back to Dumbuco. The party in one of them making resistance, was fired upon, and, as we understood, four persons were killed, and four others wounded. Of the remainder of the party, most of them fled to the bush and escaped; but quite a number were captured, and fifty-four, including some liberated slaves, have been sent to Freetown. Much credit is due to the commanding officer for the promptness and energy manifested in this affair."

We find a repetition of the complaint that persons who reside within the limits of British territory, and who ask the protection of British law, are taking part in these country wars, in which they have no rightful interest whatever, and which are waged, for the most part, for the sake of plunder, and especially to capture slaves. It is to be hoped that the British authorities will severely punish all such offenders, who add the crime of man-stealing to that of murder.

We are glad to learn that a treaty has been signed by the

principal chiefs engaged in the late "Kittam war," by which there is to be free trade in all the rivers, except that the traders who sell spirituous liquors are to pay a tax to the native chiefs.'}, {'id': 2362, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST REVENUE, ASHANTI, &c.—LATEST INTELLIGENCE.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST REVENUE, ASHANTI, &c.—LATEST INTELLIGENCE.', 'last_edit_date': '01-03-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-3', 'issue_date': '30_01_1873', 'content': 'Revenue.

Dear Sir,—In reply to yours, it is pretty generally understood that the revenue for 1872 has amounted to nearly 50,000l. For 1873 it will certainly be near, if it does not exceed, the sum you have repeatedly estimated it would yield,—viz., 60,000l. The duties on spirits alone during 1872, including ale, beer, wines, &c., amounted to nearly 40,000l., and the increased tariff did not come into operation until the 12th April last.

Lagos.

We are now lending money to the Lagos Government.

Ashanti.

Ashanti continues to give trouble. The German captives have not yet been delivered up to us. We spend so much money on Ashanti that it would be a wise measure to tax those goods they specially trade in, such as brass and copper rods, scarlet cloth, red twills, &c., ten per cent. all round, ad valorem. Any duty less than ten per cent. would not answer, as it would not compel the merchants to charge it to the customers, but would be a tax on the importers.

Yours sincerely,'}, {'id': 3924, 'article_title': 'Extension of British Rule on the Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Extension of British Rule on the Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': '12-09-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1880#article-4', 'issue_date': '02_02_1880', 'content': '“The King of Agbosome’s headman and chiefs met the Lieutenant-Governor of the Gold Coast at Quittah on the 2nd Dec., and ceded, under pressure, their seaboard territory, extending two miles inland. In consideration of the concessions made, the King and chiefs are to have divided amongst them a sum of 252l., and to have the privilege of landing duty free 20 puncheons of rum and 60 cases of gin, representing a further sum of 251l. The adjoining territory of Afflowhoo has been secured to the Government on similar terms. But news reached Quittah on Saturday to the effect that the people would not sanction the action of the chiefs, and on no account would they allow the Government officials to hoist the flag on the previous day. Nothing has yet transpired as to what the Governor will do in this case. It is understood that negotiations are pending in regard to Bagedah and Porto Seguro territories; but no proclamation up to the time of writing has been issued with respect to them. Danoe has always been an eyesore to our Government, owing to its close proximity to the Quittah jurisdiction. Large quantities of spirits have been landed there during the past two years, and have been mostly smuggled into British territory. Recently American trading ships have been putting out large cargoes of spirits; and so jealous had these people become of our Government, that they made a compact with the King of Agbosome, and leased the land at an annual rent of S.300 (675l.). This no doubt has moved our Government to take immediate possession. Speculation is rife as to what the upshot may be in the event of the American Government having authorised these traders to secure the land on lease. Should the Government extend their boundary as far as Porto Seguro, it will, to a certain extent, enhance the revenues of Quittah; but they never will be able entirely to stop contrabandism till they acquire the whole seaboard between Quittah and Lagos. The chiefs and native traders will never submit to paying half a crown per gallon duty so long as they can send their slaves three or four days’ journey to where it can be procured free.'}, {'id': 5584, 'article_title': 'The Liquor Traffic with Native Races', 'full_section_title': 'The Liquor Traffic with Native Races', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1887#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_09_1887', 'content': '

Sir G. Taubman-Goldie, Deputy-Governor of the Royal Niger Company, has also drawn up a document on this subject. The title of the paper is "Alcohol and Civilization in Central Africa." In estimating the services done by this Company to civilization, the writer mentions two as undeniable—the substitution of a considerable degree of peace for incessant intertribal wars, and the gradual suppression of slavery. With regard to their dealings in the matter of alcoholic liquors, he points out that they were confronted with these facts: (1) That traffic in European spirits had been carried on within the territories for half a century; (2) that the natives had, long before any importation by white men, manufactured their own intoxicating liquors; and (3) that the European spirits were consumed principally by the chiefs and more powerful classes, who would have driven out of the country any house which refused to meet their requirements. If the Company had refused to supply alcohol, commerce and political influence would probably have fallen into the hands of petty traders, who would have flooded Africa with European spirits, and yet not have carried on the great work of civilization. The Company adopted a middle course, and endeavoured to restrict the sale of liquors as much as possible. In 1886, the import of liquors had decreased by more than one-half in two years. Heavy duties were imposed on imported spirits. Smuggling was checked, the payment of wages in spirits was forbidden, and importation was altogether forbidden in the Benue districts. In a letter to Lord Salisbury, dated May 3, 1887, the writer summed up the case as follows: "The Company would be equally willing to prohibit the importation of spirituous liquors into another third of its territories—namely, that lying on either side of the main Niger, above its confluence with the Benue, but for the fact that, owing to the very low duty on spirits levied in the British colony of Lagos, such a measure on the part of the Company would be rendered nugatory by the smuggling of spirits from Lagos into the province of Nupe through Illorin. The Council of the Company are aware of the difficulties attending the raising of the spirit duties at Lagos to the heavy rate levied on the Gold Coast and in the Niger territories—difficulties which arise from the adjacent French and German settlements levying no duties whatever upon spirits, which are chiefly exported from France and Germany. It may at first sight appear hopeless under these circumstances to approach their respective Governments with the view of inducing them to impose a tax on the import into Africa of spirituous liquors, but the Council think they might be convinced by the same arguments which have induced the Company—not merely from philanthropic, but from sound business motives—to discourage the importation of spirituous liquors; firstly, by means of heavy duties throughout the territories, and now by actual prohibition as regards one-third of those territories. I would venture to point out to your lordship that the evils of the spirit traffic have been exaggerated, and that all colonizing nations have an interest in extending and developing their general trade with West Africa, and that no business mainly based on the liquor traffic can be sound or permanent, or can lead to fresh requirements on the part of the natives, who are gradually becoming, through the trade in useful articles, more civilized, and leading more complex existences. While it is certain that the manufacturers of spirits in Germany and France would strain every nerve to induce their Governments to maintain the present system, the Council hope that public opinion in those countries would recognize the folly of sacrificing to the interests of a small clique the prospects of a large colonial development and of permanent and growing trade in useful articles. The Council feel that they may be liable to the accusation of stepping beyond their province in laying this matter before your Lordship, but hope that the great importance of the subject may be considered sufficient excuse. An arrangement with France and Germany such as is suggested above would admit of a uniform duty on spirits being levied from Senegal to the Cameroons, inclusive. Such uniform duty might be fixed at the highest rate, which would not make the inducements for smuggling so great as to defy preventive precautions. I submit, that with a uniform system extending over 2,500 miles of coast, a duty four times as high as that now levied in the Gold Coast Colony, and 20 times as high as that now levied at Lagos, might safely be imposed."'}, {'id': 5849, 'article_title': 'Banquet to Governor Moloney', 'full_section_title': 'Banquet to Governor Moloney', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_06_1889#article-5', 'issue_date': '03_06_1889', 'content': 'His Excellency C. A. Moloney, C.M.G., Governor of Lagos, and the author of "The Forestry of West Africa," was entertained by the Liverpool Incorporated Chamber of Commerce. The chair was occupied by Mr. Henry Coke, president, and there were present Mr. G. Stallard (his Excellency's secretary), Mr. C. M'Arthur and Mr. L. Bowes (vice-presidents of the Chamber), Sir James Marshall, Sir James Poole, Mr. Henry Lee (president of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce), Mr. Henry Higgins (colonial secretary, Sierra Leone), &c., &c.

The Chairman, in proposing the health of Governor Moloney, said the trade of Lagos amounted to about £1,000,000 per annum, which, considering that it was collected in small quantities, meant employment for a great number of people. The duties on spirits last year amounted to £45,000, of which foreign nations paid £35,000; whilst on the import of fruits, iron work, and other commercial articles £10,000 out of £11,000 was paid by the United Kingdom.'}, {'id': 5954, 'article_title': 'The Royal Niger Company and its Critics', 'full_section_title': 'The Royal Niger Company and its Critics', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_02_1890', 'content': 'THE  
NATURAL CARLSBAD  
SPRUDEL-SALT  
contains all the essential ingredients of the "SPRUDEL" MINERAL WATER, is alkaline, and readily soluble in water. In small and frequent doses it is an efficient diuretic, but as an aperient it should be taken before Breakfast, in doses of from 1 to 2 teaspoonfuls, dissolved in water. To increase the aperient action of the Carlsbad Mineral Water, a teaspoonful of the Natural Salt, previously dissolved in a little water, should be added.  

Sole Consignees: INGRAM & ROYLE,  
LONDON, LIVERPOOL, & BRISTOL,  
AND OF ALL CHEMISTS THROUGHOUT THE WORLD.  

NOTICE.  
WE have much pleasure in intimating to all our correspondents that we have appointed Mr. F. C. GRANT, Hamilton House, Chapel Square, Cape Coast Castle, our Agent for Elmina, Cape Coast, Anamaboe, and Salt Pond. From Mr. GRANT's long experience of the Gold Coast trade, we have every confidence that he will be able to greatly facilitate our already rapidly increasing business. We take this opportunity of thanking all our correspondents for the hearty support they have accorded to us in the past, which we trust they will largely increase and extend to Mr. GRANT.  

KINLOCH, CAMPBELL & CO.,  
GENERAL MERCHANTS & AGENTS, GLASGOW.

**FEB. 1, 1890.**

Page 19

told the Hamburg deputies in the Reichstag that the most effective way to attack the Company was through the English press, and the two attacks are undoubtedly bound up together. The whole attack has come from the Hamburg deputies, who want to put pressure upon the German Government. The German interest in the West Coast trade is centered in the spirit traffic, and the attitude of the Niger Company is naturally resented. From a third of the territories under our control spirits are absolutely excluded; we have expressed the intention of prohibiting them in another third; and in the third near the coast where it is impossible to prevent smuggling through the creeks, there are high duties and licenses. The present import of spirit is insignificant; in former times it was four or five times as great. Pray remember that in this connexion, we don't claim to be philanthropists or moral reformers, or teetotalers, or even advocates of temperance for its own sake. What we do is on economic grounds. The liquor traffic tends to hinder the development of progressive trade and agriculture and the introduction of industries, and so we restrict it, and hope ultimately to abolish it. We represent shareholders of varied ideas, and it is not our business to put forward any other view than that."

"Hence you would favour its prohibition over the whole country?"—"Yes; and if France, Germany, and Portugal agreed with Great Britain it would be possible to prohibit the importation of liquors into West Africa from Senegambia to the Cape of Good Hope. The alternative course is that these Powers should agree to impose uniform high duties and require retail licenses."

**THE DUTIES LEVIED.**'}, {'id': 6548, 'article_title': 'IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.', 'full_section_title': 'IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1895#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_04_1895', 'content': "HOUSE OF COMMONS, FEB. 28.**

**THE OUTBREAK AT BRASS.**

In answer to Sir C. Dilke and Mr. Johnston, Sir E. Grey said: The whole question of the outbreak—who was responsible for it, how the arms of precision were supplied to the Natives, and how just grievances can be remedied—will be fully considered when details are received.

**MARCH 11.**

**THE NIGER COMPANY AND THE DRINK TRAFFIC.**

In answer to Mr. Caine, Sir E. Grey said: I am informed that if proof can be adduced of any agent of the Niger Company having, in defiance of the regulations, paid wages in spirits, such agent will be dismissed. This applies equally to Kroomen. When treaties were originally made the Natives insisted, according to the then existing practice, on receiving their subsidies partly in spirits, but three years ago instructions were given that in all such cases the Natives were to be induced to accept other goods in place of spirits. In nine-tenths of the Company's territory the sale or barter of spirits is absolutely forbidden; in the remainder the sale is restricted by a system of licenses.

**MARCH 28.**

**FRENCH EXPEDITIONS IN NIGER COMPANY'S TERRITORY.**

Sir E. Ashmead-Bartlett asked the Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether it was a fact that two large French expeditions had arrived within the Niger Company's territory or sphere, the one at Bagibo and the other at Boussa.

Sir E. Grey: The Niger Company have informed us that they have received information to this effect, and a communication will be made immediately to the French Government.

Sir E. Grey subsequently stated in his speech on Foreign Affairs: I pass on to deal with the two French expeditions which are reported to have entered a British protectorate on the Niger. I have not much to say on that. The Niger Company is informed that two French expeditions have entered territory which for some years has been known as a British protectorate. The statement that two French expeditions have entered such territory standing by itself, uncontradicted and unexplained, is undoubtedly most serious. (Hear, hear.) But the more serious it is, standing unexplained, the more important it is not to make any comment upon it before the reply of the French Government to the communications addressed to it is known. But I have to say this, that undoubtedly the Committee will be right to bear in mind that there are two points of view in regard to those questions—the point of view of their local importance and the much more serious point of view of their effect on the relations of two great European Powers."}, {'id': 6662, 'article_title': 'Liverpool and the West African Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool and the West African Trade', 'last_edit_date': '11-15-1895', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1895#article-0', 'issue_date': '02_12_1895', 'content': 'resolved that a letter should be sent to Messrs. Miller expressing their concurrence with the views of that firm, but saying that in the opinion of the committee it would be futile to memorialise against the decision of the Government. In reply to a letter addressed by the committee to the Colonial Office on the subject of the incidence of the increased duty on spirits at Lagos, Mr. Chamberlain had said that the committee's inquiries as to certain effects of the ordinance raising the duty on spirits imported into Lagos had been referred to the officer administering the Government of the Colony. A further letter from the Colonial Office enclosed a copy of an ordinance of the Colony of Lagos "to amend the Customs Tariff Ordinance, 1892." This ordinance, after enacting the recent advance to 2s. per gallon on under-proof spirits, has the following proviso and statement as to the abolition of drawbacks, viz.: (Proviso) provided always that the section shall not apply to spirits, other than liqueurs or cordials, which have been shipped to the Colony or Protectorate, and are at the same time of the passing of this ordinance actually at sea, or which have been imported into the Colony or Protectorate before the passing of this ordinance, but upon which duty has not been paid; such spirits shall be liable only to the duties imposed by the said Customs Tariff Ordinance, 1892. (Drawbacks) 2. From and after the passing of this ordinance no duties shall be drawn back, or any drawback allowed, upon spirits exported, or to be exported from the Colony or Protectorate. A discussion followed the reading of the ordinance on the subject of the lately existing transit duty and drawback system, and it was resolved to adjourn the discussion to a special meeting to be called for the purpose.'}, {'id': 6699, 'article_title': 'Liverpool and the African Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Liverpool and the African Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_02_1896#article-2', 'issue_date': '03_02_1896', 'content': 'Referring to the removal of Sir Augustus Hemming from the head of the African Department of the Colonial Office, it was unanimously resolved, on the motion of Mr. Jones, seconded by Mr. Holt, "that the members of the African trade section of the Incorporated Chamber of Commerce of Liverpool have heard of her Majesty's appointment of Sir Augustus Hemming to the Governorship of British Guiana, and although they are pleased to know of his well-earned promotion, they cannot but feel that they are losing a valuable official, who, during the many years he has been on the permanent staff of the Colonial Office, has rendered important service to Africa. They take this opportunity, therefore, of thanking Sir Augustus for his services, and desire to express the hope that he may be long spared to continue his career of usefulness to his country and to British commerce," and it was ordered that a copy of this resolution should be sent forthwith to the Governor-Elect of British Guiana.

At a further meeting on Jan. 17, presided over by Mr. Alex. Sinclair, it was reported that the deputation nominated to confer with the African Section Committee of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce on the subject of schemes for a railway or railways at Lagos had done so a few days previously, when the conference had resolved that it was desirable that both Chambers should express to the Secretary of State for the Colonies their approval of a certain group of lines, estimated to produce traffic of about 100,000 tons per annum, and which would accommodate Abeokuta and Ibadan, with a population of at least 400,000. A report on the subject of the decision of the conference had been promised by the Manchester committee, and it was agreed to postpone further action pending the receipt of the communication.

A letter was read from Mr. Chamberlain saying with respect to the request that he would receive a small deputation from the section on the subject of the transit and export trade of Lagos, that he was much occupied just now, besides which he was expecting to receive reports from the Governor of Lagos very shortly with regard to the trade in question, and that under these circumstances he thought it would be advisable to postpone the deputation until the arrival of the reports. A further letter was read from the Colonial Office saying (1) that the duty chargeable on spirits which were in bond at the date of the passing of the Lagos Ordinance No. 3, 1895, is 1s. per gallon; and (2) that by Section 2 of the same enactment all drawbacks on spirits exported from the Colony since the passing of the Ordinance are abolished, and that there is no exemption in favour of spirits ordered, or at sea, with or without a through bill of lading, or already landed in Lagos.'}, {'id': 6796, 'article_title': 'BEFORE THE LAW COURTS.', 'full_section_title': 'BEFORE THE LAW COURTS.', 'last_edit_date': '01-04-1897', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1897#article-4', 'issue_date': '04_01_1897', 'content': '**VISITORS from the Colonies, &c., will find home comforts by residing at "SEA GRANGE," WESTGATE-ON-SEA—an establishment replete with every necessary (including sea and other baths). It has a great advantage over most seaside resorts, being quiet and select. The buildings are all modern, and are constructed with every attention to sanitation. "SEA GRANGE" is conducted by the Widow of the late Mr. FERDINAND FITZGERALD, whose extensive labours for the good of Africa are widely known and much appreciated. Terms, strictly moderate. Particulars to be had from Mrs. FITZGERALD, Sea Grange, Westgate-on-Sea.**

**EXPORTATION OF SPIRITS FROM LAGOS.**—The following has been received by the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce from the Colonial Secretary: "Downing Street, Dec. 15, 1896. Sir,—I am directed by Mr. Secretary Chamberlain to inform you that an ordinance has been passed in Lagos under which a drawback of duty will again be allowed on spirits exported from Lagos to the French colony of Dahomey, so that the amount paid in Lagos on spirits in transit will, as formerly, be only 1½d. per gallon.—I am, &c., **John Bramston.**"

**CHAMBER OF COMMERCE EXHIBITS.**—Continuing the policy of the London Chamber of Commerce, several provincial bodies are adopting the plan of exhibiting samples of manufactures from the colonies and other countries, with the object of furnishing information to merchants and manufacturers as to the sources of competition with British trade, and the character of the foreign goods consumed to which preference is given over British manufactures. An exhibition of West Indies, Victoria, Lagos, and other samples has been on show at the Manchester Chamber of Commerce.

**GERMAN EAST AFRICA.**—Captain Ramsay, of the German East African Forces, has just reported on his march to Lake Tanganyika and the state of trade in that region. All the Sultans but two have submitted, and the slave trade has almost ceased. The ivory trade is in a bad way, since the Congo authorities do their utmost to prevent the transport of ivory to the East Coast. The famous salt of Uvinza is becoming an important article of trade. Captain Ramsay placed a garrison in Ujiji, took possession of the salt springs for the Government, and stationed a small force with orders to levy a salt tax, and send its proceeds to head-quarters.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'THE GOVERNOR'S REPORT for 1891, just lately issued, contains the figures relating to the trade of Lagos for the year, with a summary of the imports and exports from the date of its establishment as a Colony. In 1862 the imports amounted to £77,932, and the exports to £61,933; last year (1891) the imports were £607,718, and the exports £716,642. Lagos trade is subject to fluctuations, among other reasons, owing to the eccentric conduct of the middlemen from the interior, whose arbitrary demands and exactions have from time to time blocked the routes upon which the trade of the Colony depends.**

"It is evident that in a trade which has its foundation on the barter system the value and quantity of the imports must vary directly with the exports. There is of late years a growing tendency on the part of the native, even in the remote interior, to employ silver currency for his transactions in place of direct barter or the cumbrous method of transporting vast quantities of cowrie shells from market to market. Hitherto the carrying powers of a slave and his intrinsic value have been in strict relations, but it is probable the less perishable metallic currency will oust him from the commercial field. In other ways the gradual adoption of specie payments has modified the methods of trade in the Colony, and such firms as have adhered to the old barter system have had to remove to less civilised regions. This is very noticeable in the case of the French firms, who were at one time the leading merchants of Lagos. There are at present few traces of their existence in the Colony, except the large factories which were built by them in the days of their prosperity. The establishment of a branch of the African Banking Corporation Limited, which took place towards the close of the year, will have a very remarkable effect on trade by increasing specie transactions, and even more by encouraging shipments by small traders, to whom money is advanced on the security of insured produce or invoiced European goods. The attention of the natives has been directed lately to the importance of developing minor industries. Among these may be mentioned the cultivation of cocoa and coffee, which has been taken up both by the natives and, in one

For instance, on a large scale, by European enterprise. Even more importance is now attached to cotton, which is cultivated in large quantities in the interior of Yoruba for home manufacture. During the current year one of the obstructing tribes who prevented direct communication with the "hinterland" has been forced to open its roads, and it is to be hoped that the shipments of cotton, which amounted to 379,300lb., of a value at the port of shipment of £4,825 6s. 10d., during the past year, will in 1893 be very largely increased. Yoruba cotton is of fair quality, and competes at an advantage in price with most Indian cottons."', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.709, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Spirit Trade with West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It has been thought necessary to array the facts of the liquor trade as known by merchants, by their agents residing on the West Coast, and by the official classes. It now only remains for the committee to make suggestions (1) for safeguarding the Native, and (2) the trader. It is recommended that an inquiry should be instituted by Royal Commission, or by competent authorities, of whom the Government have many at their command, into statements which have been made respecting the trade in spirits with West Africa and its effects. These statements were made at meetings held at home and abroad in the reports of which, by the Press, it was noticed that hardly one substantial fact appeared supporting them: 1. That the Native races of Africa are deteriorating through excessive consumption of spirits. 2. That drunkenness is increasing in Native villages to an alarming extent. [Suggestion—That surprise visits should be paid to the principal villages and Native markets.] 3. That the drunkenness is due to imported spirits, and not to those of Native manufacture, such as palm wine. 4. That the imported gin and rum, &c., are vile and poisonous liquids. [Suggestion—That bottles be purchased and sent home for analysis.] 5. That the importation of spirits is excessive in proportion to population. And the Committee would recommend further: That the criminal statistics and reports on crime from the colonies should be investigated with the view of seeing whether they furnish evidence of such a state of things as described. The Committee deem it most essential for the present maintenance and future development of British trade with West Africa that there should be a more complete understanding and uniformity of practice amongst all the European powers ruling on the coast as to the duties levied on merchandise, including spirits. The inner boundaries of the colonies and protectorates, not to speak of those of mere spheres of influence, are ill-defined and generally unprotected. Merchandise of a portable kind can be carried from foreign ports where lower duties are charged and exchanged in the hinterlands of British colonies, in which colonies the duties are on a higher scale, to the detriment of the colonial revenues and British traders, including carriers by sea. Before a Customs Union was effected this applied to Togoland and the Gold Coast, and it may still apply to the northern rivers and to Liberia in relation to Sierra Leone, to French Benin in relation to Lagos, and to the Cameroons and Niger Territories in relation to the Niger Coast Protectorate. The committee therefore recommend: (1) That the duty lists of the British and foreign colonies and protectorates on the West Coast of Africa be carefully collated, and that an endeavor be made to effect an International Customs Union.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1895#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE PROGRESS OF LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'By the mail just to hand from the West Coast we have some particulars of the statistical returns of the Colony of Lagos for the four years 1886-89. From these we learn that the exports exceed the imports for every year but the last by over £100,000. The imports for 1889 exceed the exports by £6,610. This is explained by the returns, which show that the year 1889 was an exceptionally bad one for trade. The previous year had been a very good business one, and merchants were induced to increase their importations, in the belief that the succeeding year would prove as good as its predecessor; but the closing in the early part of the year of a principal exit for cotton goods completely disappointed their hopes, and left heavy stocks on their hands. The total excess of exports above imports for the four years is £338,437. The Customs revenue has during the last two years maintained an average of something over £48,200. This is due to the increased importation of spirits, which exceeds the two former years by 262,115 gallons. The revenue derived from these spirits—which only include gin and rum for home consumption—exceeds £27,000 per annum. Palm oil shows a decided, steady decline in production. The heaviest decline was in 1887, when it fell 591,392 gallons below the quantity exported the previous year, and has continued to decrease ever since. The difference between the quantity exported in 1886 and 1889 is 788,527 gallons—equal to a local value of £39,426—a very material decrease in four years of one of the principal exports. Palm kernels show a gradual increase from 1886 to 1888, but in 1889 fell considerably below the quantity exported during any of the three previous years, and was less than 1888 by 10,810 tons. The total decrease in oil and kernels for 1889, as compared with 1888, was £90,661 at the local market value. Benniseed and cotton show a continued increase in the quantity exported for the four years, which is a very hopeful sign for these products. The total increase in value of these products in 1889 above 1888 is £5,840, which acts somewhat as a set-off against the decrease in oil and kernels. Cocoa shows a decrease of nearly 700 lbs. in 1889 upon the quantity exported the year previous.—*Colonies & India.*', 'last_edit_date': '1890-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1890#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Spirit Trade with West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A report has lately been drawn up by the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, and forwarded to the Secretary for the Colonies, in compliance with his request in August last for information on the subject and for suggestions to aid him in dealing with the matter, in view of statements made, to the effect that the promotion of trade in West Africa meant the promotion of trade in liquor. Under the head of remarks and recommendations the report says:—', 'last_edit_date': '1895-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1895#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GOVERNOR OF LAGOS IN LIVERPOOL.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'His Excellency Sir Gilbert Carter, K.C.M.G., the Governor of Lagos, was present at an informal meeting of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce held on Thursday, Sept. 10. Mr. John Holt presided in the absence of Mr. Alfred L. Jones, and welcomed Sir Gilbert warmly as a model West African governor, full of energy and determination, and far-seeing enough to have at heart the interests of the merchants, on whom primarily the existence of the colony depended. Naturally there were many points on which the authorities of the colony and the merchants were not entirely of one accord; and the trade were greatly indebted to Sir Gilbert for allowing them the opportunity of placing before him their views on many matters coming under his jurisdiction.

The chief subjects discussed were the recent increase of spirit duties, and the question of drawback on spirit imported for transit and transit dues; the construction of the new railway, its progress, the route chosen, &c.; the construction of costly bridges at Lagos, concerning which the Chamber had been in correspondence last year with the Colonial Office; the practicability of dredging the Lagos Bar and Lagoon; the question of the hinterlands of Lagos, and the result on the trade of the colony from the blockade of Ilorin; the possibility of establishing colonies of Kroo boys at Lagos, similar to that of Sierra Leone; the very important question of the water supply, the sanitation of the colony, and its health; also many other subjects that suggested themselves. Several of those present gave their views of the subjects in which they were interested, the questions of spirit traffic and issues raised thereby, folded woven goods, and adulteration of produce calling for much discussion. Mr. Holt said great credit was due to Sir Gilbert for originating the trade in rubber, which in two or three years had risen to above a quarter of a million sterling in value.

His Excellency, whose remarks were received with close attention, touched on all the subjects which had been brought before his notice, and gave much interesting information. He described the rise of the rubber trade in the colony, which had a somewhat curious history. It appears that a political prisoner from the Gold Coast was a most intelligent native, and thoroughly conversant with the rubber industry. This man, at his suggestion, procured experts from among his own countrymen, who went into the interior and found a wealth', 'last_edit_date': '1896-09-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'False Measures in Piece Goods and Spirits', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'now sell to them, containing scarcely 12 per cent. of spirit, i.e., pretended spirit, of which seven-eighths is water, and to get 30 yards of cloth instead of only 25 yards, as now, from those unscrupulous intermediaries. That these trading malpractices should be thus justly chargeable with the guilt of a devastating war, that must greatly injure the trade and revenue of Lagos, justifies us in repeating and intensifying our denunciation of that organized system of fraud, by which some of the Lagos importers play into the hands of those intermediaries, and assist them (as by their 25 yards of cloth folded to represent 30 yards) in their nefarious plunder of the interior people. Lagos is necessarily the seaport of a vast and populous interior, and it is deeply to be deplored that the development of the natural and industrial resources of that interior, should be hindered by practices which rob the producers of the fair and legitimate reward of their labour. If Lagos, enjoying the advantages of that security which is guaranteed by British power and British laws, is to rise to that commercial eminence which, from its advantageous situation, it is entitled to expect, it can only be by the full development of interior resources. All malpractices, therefore, which impede that development are criminal attacks on its prosperity, and ought to be repressed, as far as may be possible, by the Lagos Government. British law, we repeat, ought, and may be made, to offer a full protection against systematic fraud. It must be powerless, of course, as regards the malpractices of the Ijebu and Egba traders with goods which they may have removed beyond Lagos jurisdiction, but it may repress them within its limits, and thus inculcate commercial morality beyond those limits. This may be done, as already pointed out, by local enactments that, at least in so far as regards measures, goods shall be what they profess to be, having legibly and clearly stamped upon them, by ticket or otherwise, the measures and contents of pieces and cases on pain of fines and forfeiture. The Egbas and Ijebus are so strongly represented in Lagos, have so systematically inculcated the belief that they, and they only, are the producers upon whom Lagos must depend for its supplies of produce, and have so systematically held up the Ibadans to commercial reprobation as being entirely non-producers, mere armed plunderers, kidnappers, and slave-dealers, that Abandawaki has done good service in giving us the other side of the picture; and showing that Ibadan has already made considerable progress in industrial pursuits; that respectable Lagos native traders have established themselves, with their cotton gins, at Ibadan; that others, as Beckley and Robin, draw supplies of cotton and kernels from the same country; and that all that is required for putting an end to the old warlike pursuits of the Ibadans as a people, and turning them into a nation of producers is, that they should have full protection for the passage of their produce to Lagos; and be enabled to obtain its fair and legitimate value in those European commodities which are already objects of desire, and would be irresistible incentives to industrial labour. In view of so vast a field of resources for the trade of Lagos, we feel that, in addition to the enforcement of such regulations as we have already pointed out, it ought to be a settled and active policy on the part of the Lagos Government to do all within the fullest scope of its pacific powers, to bring about such an amicable understanding between the Ibadans, Egbas, and Ijebus, as may remove all impediments and hindrances to the spread of industrial pursuits throughout the entire interior territory, between the Lagos lagoon and Rabba, on the river Niger. Unless such an amicable understanding be arrived at by a legitimate and pacific exercise of British influence, there cannot be that permanent peace and security in those countries, which is an inseparable condition of industrial progress; and we may, therefore, we trust, be excused, even by the most sensitive official dignity, in pointing out to the Lagos Executive this path of honourable administrative exertion—in insisting that the most vital public interests require that the Administrator of Lagos and the Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony, should not be mere apathetic guardians of existing trade, but active instruments for the pacific promotion of industrial development in all the countries within the range of their legitimate influence. The civilization of the West African countries must depend greatly on this, and the increasing wants of the industrial population of Great Britain demand it as an imperative duty on the part of those who are entrusted with power in the settlements and colonies of the British Crown.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1878#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.718, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Depression in all Branches of African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'During the last twenty-five years England has acquired the sovereignty over portions of the Gold Coast which did not before belong to her, and Lagos has come into existence as a flourishing port, owing to the opening up of the Niger trade. With the benefits of British rule trade should have improved in this section of the West Coast, but with the exception of the growth of Lagos, which has been due to the opening up of the trade of the Niger, we fail to see any real improvement in the whole of the colony. The colony is dependent on customs dues for its revenue, and to pay the cost of administration, it is necessary that imports should be taxed. Foreign nations have trumped up claims to trading stations, to which a few years ago they attached no importance, and established ports close to our territories, even at times dividing one portion of the colony from another, whereby difficulties are thrown in the way of the British merchant, and his rival is enabled to land goods duty free, which, by a system of smuggling, compete with those which have to pay the dues of the British colony. The increased means of communication incident on the introduction of steam have largely increased the competition and enabled a fresh class of trader to enter into the business, so that profits have been cut down still more. The want of means of small native traders, and the laxity with which inexperienced merchants give credit, have led to many bad debts, which seriously affects trade. The English merchant without regular correspondents on the coast, and who supplies goods to those who write to ask for credit, should remember that many a man without any more capital than an envelope and a sheet of paper can write a business letter. A favourite "dodge" of these adventurers is to write for quantities of samples of all sorts and kinds, from a needle to a sewing-machine, from a biscuit to cases of wine or spirits, and thus gradually establish themselves as traders. The remedy lies in the hands of the English merchant, who should never ship a single article to any person in the colony unless he receives satisfactory references.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"As a civilizing agent: commerce is the mother of civilization, and has been, both in our days and in the earliest times, the grand engine by which the blessings of civilization and the treasures of knowledge and science are diffused. By bringing us into contact with the inhabitants of other countries, it produces moral and intellectual effects of the greatest importance. It gives us new tastes, at the same time that it affords the means for their gratification; it enables us to compare our own laws, institutions, and manners with those of the Europeans, to profit by their example, or to take warning by their fate. Let us compare Lagos thirty-five years ago with Lagos today, and we have a striking instance of the potency of commerce as a civilizing agent. Lagos thirty-five years ago—ruled over by a despot, at whose nod a soul could be hurried into eternity; Lagos with its idolatry, its slave barracoons, its bush and miserable mud huts. Lagos of today—an emporium of legitimate commerce, a place of refuge for slaves, a centre of civilization; law, order, and justice, the rule and not the exception; the bush substituted for roads; in place of mud huts, with their thatched roofs, that fall so easy a prey to fire, we are having substantial brick buildings, with iron or slate roofs; the churches, the schools; the moral and mental improvement of the natives—are not these proof enough of the good wrought by commercial intercourse with Europe? Well, I will give one more instance. In 1873, domestic slavery was abolished on the Gold Coast. By force of arms? No! During the Ashantee Expedition, the English lost so many men that reparation was demanded and granted—namely, the abolition of domestic slavery. This took place when the Gold Coast was only a British protectorate.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Parcel Post with the Oil Rivers Protectorate', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"It is evident that in a trade which has its foundation on the barter system the value and quantity of the imports must vary directly with the exports. There is of late years a growing tendency on the part of the native, even in the remote interior, to employ silver currency for his transactions in place of direct barter or the cumbrous method of transporting vast quantities of cowrie shells from market to market. Hitherto the carrying powers of a slave and his intrinsic value have been in strict relations, but it is probable the less perishable metallic currency will oust him from the commercial field. In other ways the gradual adoption of specie payments has modified the methods of trade in the Colony, and such firms as have adhered to the old barter system have had to remove to less civilised regions. This is very noticeable in the case of the French firms, who were at one time the leading merchants of Lagos. There are at present few traces of their existence in the Colony, except the large factories which were built by them in the days of their prosperity. The establishment of a branch of the African Banking Corporation Limited, which took place towards the close of the year, will have a very remarkable effect on trade by increasing specie transactions, and even more by encouraging shipments by small traders, to whom money is advanced on the security of insured produce or invoiced European goods. The attention of the natives has been directed lately to the importance of developing minor industries. Among these may be mentioned the cultivation of cocoa and coffee, which has been taken up both by the natives and, in one', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.7, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Abeokuta and Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—We, the undersigned, humbly and respectfully beg to bring before your notice the following facts:—

That for many years past, and previous to the cession of Lagos, we have in common with many others been resident in this place in pursuit of our lawful trade.

That up to this time we have seen no reasonable cause whatsoever for leaving this place and the commerce we are engaged in, arising from the conduct of the native chiefs or Governments of the country, but; to our great consternation, the Government of Lagos has passed a law which in effect prohibits our residing out of Lagos for the purposes of trade. This appears to us the more strange as whilst we are excluded from the advantage of our position here, the natives are allowed to trade freely with Lagos, in fact we are prohibited trading with Lagos, whilst the road to Lagos is opened to the natives.

We would also observe that our being obliged to leave would be a breach of agreement made between the British Consul in Lagos and native authorities, and to us a great loss, in being

obliged to abandon houses, connexions, and debts—in fact, all our stock-in-trade.

We beg to state that we have had no part in the causes of the disturbances between this place and Lagos, and it has been both our interest and desire to see the differences amicably and honourably settled.

We feel it is our best course to address you, Sir, and most respectfully to beg you to use such means as your wisdom may suggest to make lawful trade free and unrestricted here. Praying your interference in our behalf.—We are, Sir, your most humble and obedient servants,

HENRY ROBBIN, ISAAC COKER, F. RUBENO, S. J. PETERS. ISAAC PEARSE.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-10-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1866#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS AS A BRITISH COLONY', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"It is not forgotten how great an improvement has taken place in Lagos during these last ten years," and "Lagos cannot improve as it has done without proving a stimulus in the same direction to Abeokuta. One of the improvements here is, that not only is there an increasing trade done, but there is now an increased means of judging of the amount of it, since it is the duty of one department of the Government* to keep an account of produce that is sent to Lagos for exportation. We have now the returns of the Custom-house for the first six months of this year. They are as yet very imperfect as a means of showing the entire amount of the produce that has been sent away, as will be gathered from the remarks which follow; but we are led to expect that they will approach much nearer to completeness in future."—Abeokuta "Iwe Irohin."', 'last_edit_date': '1867-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1867#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I cannot say whether your powerful and able article about the absurdity of the financial system that had been established here—viz.; of a double system of duties, export and import—has anything to do with the change I am now about to communicate. But a change—the principle of which you will certainly approve of—has been made by the Governor and Legislative Council. All export duties have been abolished, and the revenue will be derived from import duties. The import duties have, therefore, of course, been increased. Instead of a general import duty of 2 per cent., the following has been substituted:—

- Cotton and silk, and all other manufactured goods, 3 per cent.  
  _Ad valorem_, with 18 per cent. added to amount of invoice.  
- Rum, 6d. per imperial gallon (about 30 per cent., instead of 2 per cent.).  
- Gin, liqueurs, and wines in cases, 1s. per case of one dozen.  
- Brandy 1s. per gallon.  
- Guns, 1s. each.  
- Tobacco, roll, 10s. per roll.  
  ", Leaf, 2d. per pound (30 per cent.).  
- Timber for building purposes, bricks, caskage, and hooping, _free, as before_.

This, you will admit, is a great change for us. There can be little doubt that with this tariff the revenue of Lagos will be greatly increased, should peace be established in the interior. At present, however, I am sorry to say, the war between Abeokuta and Ibadan continues, and the Ikorodus have become mixed up in it. Kidnapping is now being reciprocally carried on by the Egbas and Ikorodus. Captures have been made and villages been destroyed on both sides.

We do not hear of any movement on the part of the Dahomans. Commodore Wilmot and his company are still at Abomey; and whatever may be the result of their mission, it does not seem probable that any warlike expedition would start while they are at the capital. In addition to which, as you have very properly said, the Dahoman excursion, though announced for November, generally takes place in February.

As yet, no great improvement has been effected in our Bar. The surf rolls heavily as heretofore upon it; and as a general rule there is not water enough for vessels drawing more than ten or twelve feet. Considerable detention has been experienced by others of greater draught.

But we have one real step in advance. Copper money has been introduced. It is not yet much used by the natives, but there can be no doubt that it will soon supplement cowries for all purchases from one farthing upwards. Those of less value than a farthing must necessarily continue to be made in cowries, which are now about thirty-one or thirty-two for a farthing.

On Christmas-day his Excellency the Governor gave a large entertainment to the principal inhabitants of this place who can speak English. There were nearly sixty Europeans, and others of European descent, present. On a similar occasion, some five years ago, before Consul Campbell went to England, there were only sixteen such persons; and of these only three were present on both occasions.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-01-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH TRADE WITH WESTERN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'One was not calculating wildly when estimating the increase to the trade of the colony to be expected were the interior thrown open to commerce at not less than £800,000. He need not say that this increase was dependent on the success of the efforts of the Lagos Government to open the Ijebu roads to the interior. It might be objected that if this vast amount of trade was waiting to pour down from the interior it would find its way by other channels. There were strong political reasons which had prevented this in the past, and it was to be feared that they were difficulties of a permanent nature. The British Government had done much in the past to ameliorate the condition of the Yorubas; English trade had gained considerably by the transaction, and mutual improvement and gain would increase to a very large extent if a carefully planned and moderate policy of native affairs was continued in the future as it had been so prudently carried out in the past.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Colony of Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': '| Year | United Kingdom | Colonies | Foreign | Total |
|------|----------------|----------|---------|-------|
| 1887 | £247,764       | £1,933   | £58,351 | £308,038 |
| 1888 | 190,529        | 1,211    | 58,407  | 250,147 |
| 1889 | 210,800        | 1,110    | 65,871  | 277,781 |
| 1890 | 295,012        | 1,627    | 93,269  | 389,908 |
| 1891 | 345,031        | 2,145    | 106,202 | 453,378 |

Of the imports in 1891 that entered for home consumption was £298,137, merchandise warehoused amounted to £146,553, and £8,688 worth of goods was transhipped. The increase in the value of importations in 1891 over those of 1890 was £63,470. The principal articles imported were—cotton goods, £139,954; spirits, £27,991; haberdashery, £23,679; tobacco, £22,253. The value of imports from the United Kingdom was thirty-four times that from France and ten times that from Germany.

**Exports.**

| Year | United Kingdom | Colonies | Foreign | Total |
|------|----------------|----------|---------|-------|
| 1887 | £120,188       | £15,695  | £197,634| £333,517 |
| 1888 | 166,569        | 17,651   | 154,823 | 339,043 |
| 1889 | 131,077        | 23,992   | 164,650 | 319,719 |
| 1890 | 147,436        | 21,043   | 180,840 | 349,319 |
| 1891 | 218,294        | 32,177   | 227,185 | 477,656 |

The value of produce exported was £329,751, and of European goods £137,905. The increase in the exports of 1891 over those of 1890 was £128,837, which was more than the total exports to the United Kingdom in 1887. Articles produced or manufactured in and exported from the Colony in 1891 were valued at £6,177, against £5,394 in the previous year. The chief exports were palm kernels £157,457, rubber £77,738, kola nuts £43,004, specie £36,231, palm oil £14,370, gum copal, £9,241, rice £8,291, and hides £7,112. The exports to the United Kingdom in 1891 was four times that to France, five times that to Germany, and twenty-five times that to the United States of America. These figures afford evidence that the trade of the Colony is expanding, a satisfactory feature in a community in which about one-sixth of the resident inhabitants is engaged in trading. Probably the large importations of recent years are not altogether the outcome of increased local consumption, as nearly one-half the imports find their way into the interior countries, and should more properly be classified as transit trade, the few ports in the Colony being mere commercial depots, where are landed the merchandise brought by vessels from different countries, whose manufactures find a market in this part of West Africa. Therefore the stability of the trade of Sierra Leone rests on the pacification of the producing areas which border upon it.

Freetown has become noted as a coaling station, and as it possesses an admirable harbour, a good provision market, and plenty of pure drinking water, it is much frequented by ships, as such supplies cannot be so readily obtained elsewhere on the coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1893#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Efforts to open Central Africa to trade were driven by a combination of commercial, philanthropic, and missionary interests, aiming to integrate the region into global trade networks and enhance economic ties with South African colonies and Western India.
result: Efforts to open Central Africa to trade were driven by a combination of commercial, philanthropic, and missionary interests, as evidenced by insights from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook highlights the role of European commercial firms in connecting Africa with Western markets, emphasizing the expansion of trade networks and the integration of Central Africa into the global economy. It also notes the involvement of Protestant missions aiming to create a middle class and facilitate trade, supporting the claim of missionary interests. Additionally, the influence of Arab and Swahili traders in establishing commercial routes aligns with the idea of integrating Central Africa into broader trade networks. However, the textbook does not specifically mention enhancing economic ties with South African colonies and Western India. In contrast, The African Times articles provide substantial evidence of the intertwined commercial, philanthropic, and missionary interests, highlighting the involvement of missionaries, merchants, and government officials in promoting trade and civilization. The articles emphasize the commercial potential of Central Africa, the need for improved infrastructure, and the strategic importance of connecting the region with South African colonies and Western India. They also underscore the British government's role in establishing trade routes and suppressing the slave trade, further integrating Central Africa into global trade networks. Together, these sources illustrate a multifaceted approach to opening Central Africa to trade, driven by diverse interests and motivations.
gha: The paragraphs from the "General History of Africa" textbook provide several insights that align with the claim that efforts to open Central Africa to trade were driven by a combination of commercial, philanthropic, and missionary interests. The text highlights the role of European commercial firms in connecting Africa with Western markets, emphasizing the expansion of trade networks and the integration of Central Africa into the global economy. The involvement of Protestant missions, which sought to create a middle class and facilitate trade, also supports the claim of missionary interests in the region. Additionally, the text discusses the influence of Arab and Swahili traders in establishing commercial routes, which aligns with the idea of integrating Central Africa into broader trade networks. However, the text does not specifically mention enhancing economic ties with South African colonies and Western India, which is a notable difference from the claim. Overall, the textbook supports the notion of a multifaceted approach to opening Central Africa to trade, driven by commercial and missionary interests, but lacks explicit references to connections with South African colonies and Western India.
tat: The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that efforts to open Central Africa to trade were driven by a combination of commercial, philanthropic, and missionary interests. The articles highlight the involvement of various stakeholders, including missionaries, merchants, and government officials, in promoting trade and civilization in Central Africa. For instance, the Oxford and Cambridge Mission's efforts to establish a Christian influence in Central Africa and the discussions at the Royal Geographical Society emphasize the philanthropic and missionary motivations. Additionally, the articles discuss the commercial potential of Central Africa, citing the region's natural resources and the need for improved communication and transportation infrastructure, such as railways and steam navigation, to facilitate trade. The involvement of the British government and companies in establishing trade routes and suppressing the slave trade further underscores the integration of Central Africa into global trade networks. Moreover, the articles mention the strategic importance of connecting Central Africa with South African colonies and Western India, aligning with the claim's focus on enhancing economic ties. Overall, the articles corroborate the claim by illustrating the intertwined commercial, philanthropic, and missionary interests in opening Central Africa to trade.
topic2: Global Economic Integration of African economies
gha_sources:
[{'document_title': 'The Congo* Basin and Angola', 'section_title': 'Central Africa in the fluctuating world economy of the nineteenth century', 'content': "During the centuries that saw the gradual establishment of a system in which agriculture, stock-breeding, fishing and gathering were the main productive activities, a trade sector always existed in Central Africa, playing a more or less important role according to historical circumstances. Gen› erally speaking, the difficulty and cost of transport restricted trading transactions for a long time to a few major products that were much in demand, such as salt, iron, prestige goods (copper, raffia fabrics, etc.), whereas agricultural produce was rarely carried over great distances.
The rise of a world-wide market economy, which began in the sixteenth century, gradually affected the organization of economic life in everwidening areas of Central Africa. Here again, the nineteenth century is part of a continuous process, that of unequal trade relationships with the capitalist world. However, from the 1850s, great changes began to take place. Slaves gradually ceased to be Central Africa's principal 'export' to the outside world. Trade expanded in the main products obtained from a gathering-based economy: ivory, wax, copal, oil and coffee. The growth of this market economy is undeniable: the value of goods passing through Angolan ports increased sevenfold between 1844 and 1881; the cash turn› over of the Luanda branch of the Banco Nacional Ultramarino increased tenfold between 1865 and 1876. In the early 1870s, however, the value of exports derived from these products was still only twice that derived from the export of slaves in the 1820s. 14 The volume of these major African products reaching world markets was dependent on the way in which communications and trade networks functioned within the continent. These networks, with their staging posts, trade conventions and currencies, in turn defined the major economic zones on the nineteenth-century map of Central Africa, amounting to new 'frontiers' that overlaid and modified the former political and economic divisions of the region.
These new economic zones were dominated by the demands of the nerve centres of the nineteenth-century world economy. Each of them had its own historical traditions and political and social characteristics. Nonethe¬ less, they all had one thing in common, namely that they transformed important aspects of the old African economic system, linking it more or less loosely to the world economy.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Congo* Basin and Angola', 'section_title': 'Economic zones and trading networks', 'content': "They set up trading centres (e.g. Lukolele), went down the river as far as the Tio markets on the Pool, travelled upstream into the interior, collecting ivory and slaves, especially from the Mongo.
