[{'id': 157, 'article_title': 'EAST AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'EAST AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '05-23-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_05_1863', 'content': 'We had intended entering fully this month into the important question of the obstructive Portuguese influences in the East African rivers. Commerce, civilization, and missionary effort are paralysed there by the ineradicable slave-trade propensities of the unworthy representatives of Europe on the coast. The Zambesi stations of the Oxford and Cambridge Mission, abandoned to themselves by the withdrawal of the Government grant for the Zambesi expedition, have now a strong claim to our active sympathy and support. We shall do all that lies in our power to aid the mission, as well as our enterprising colonial brethren in Natal, in obtaining the release of East Africa from the slave-trade depopulating and debasing thraldom in which it is held, through the claims of Portugal, upon a long line of coast, including the embouchure of the principal rivers.

Meanwhile, we hope it will not be deemed impertinent in us by the distinguished men at the head of the Central African Mission to remind them there are other entrances into Central Africa than those from the East Coast. Why not strike at the interior of Africa from both sides of the continent at once? A secure and most important access is to open them from the West Coast. Rabba, on the River Niger, which will, in some way or other, soon be opened to organised commercial enterprise, is the western outpost of the great Mohammedan error in Central Africa. An able, earnest, prudent, active bishop at Rabba might lay the foundation of a Christian influence that would spread throughout Central Africa, and overthrow that dominant mixture of Mohammedanism and heathenism which now prevails. We feel certain that within no very long period a Bishop of Rabba might be followed by a Bishop of Kano. This is a work too important to be longer neglected, and one that is particularly suited to the ecclesiastical organization of the Oxford and Cambridge Mission. Its efforts in this direction touch us nearly.

[MAY 23, 1863.

would rest upon the influential basis of British presence and occupation, at Lagos only 180 miles from Rabba, and at the British establishments that must soon permanently occupy the Niger. Intelligence would come to England by every monthly mail, and the zeal and interest of the supporters of the mission would thus be kept alive. We must, with all deference, beg leave to submit that only by such an action from the west, as well as up the Zambesi from the east, can it have a just claim to retain its present title of Central African Mission. If it confine itself to the Zambesi effort, the East African Mission will be its most fitting designation. In our earnest anxiety for the civilization of Africa throughout, we cannot conceal our conviction of the widespread benefits that may result from an immediate action in the direction we now presume to suggest and recommend.'}, {'id': 481, 'article_title': 'PARLIAMENTARY PAPERS.', 'full_section_title': 'PARLIAMENTARY PAPERS.', 'last_edit_date': '05-04-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': "We seek no exclusive privilege, but have offered to carry goods and passengers for others on fair terms. The subsidy is applied for, not on account of trading operations, but to assist in establishment of steam communication on the river for the general benefit—for British merchants, native traders, liberated Africans, missionaries, Government officers, and all who may wish to avail themselves of it. Whatever arguments may be used against subsidising steamers, where a large trade already exists, I submit they are not applicable to a case of this kind; and it should be borne in mind that, while we ask for a five years' subsidy, we contract to keep open the steam navigation for the same period, which has not yet been done. Further, I may remind your lordships, as was stated yesterday, that if any other existing Company is willing to undertake the enterprise and can satisfy Her Majesty's Government that they possess the means, and will engage to embark the same capital in steamers and trading stations, and bind themselves to keep steamers on the river for five years, we are willing to stand aside and follow in their wake.

Enclosed is a copy of the prospectus, the full capital of which, 400,000l., has been subscribed. The main objects of the Company are to carry on the ordinary trade of the West Coast of Africa. The proposal to open Central Africa to commerce by the rivers Niger and Chadda embraces philanthropic and national objects as well as commercial; and as it will assuredly be attended with a considerable loss during the time necessary for establishing and developing trade, the directors feel they would not be justified, as regards the shareholders, to embark so large a sum as 80,000l., unless Her Majesty's Government will consent to share the preliminary risk and expense by means of a subsidy for maintaining steam communication on the rivers. In the event of the enterprise ultimately failing, the total loss would scarcely be less than double the subsidy.

The subsidy applied for is 35,000l., spread over five years, with an undertaking to return the amount out of profits after 6 per cent. on the capital embarked. But understanding that it might be more agreeable to Her Majesty's Government to grant 25,000l., spread over five years, without any stipulation for return, we would not decline the service on such terms. For several reasons, I consider the first proposal more satisfactory for both parties; but rather than forego this great enterprise, we will accept the latter.—I have, &c.,

(Signed) A. HAMILTON.

To the Right Hon. Viscount Palmerston, K.G., &c., &c."}, {'id': 3395, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1877#article-23', 'issue_date': '01_09_1877', 'content': 'A public meeting in aid of the African Exploration Fund of the Royal Geographical Society has been held in the Egyptian Hall of the Mansion House. There was a good attendance, and amongst those present were the Archbishop of York, Mr. Samuel Morley, M.P., Sir Fowell Buxton, Dr. Moffat, Sir Henry Barkly, Colonel Grant, Lord Cottesloe, Sir Alexander Milne, Sir Harry Verney, Captain Cameron, General Rigby, Captain Foot, R.N., Mr. Donald Currie, Mr. R. N. Fowler, and Professor Tennant. The chair was taken successively by Sir Rutherford Alcock, President of the Royal Geographical Society, and the Lord Mayor.

Sir RUTHERFORD ALCOCK, on taking the chair, said there had been several papers read before the Geographical Society on the subject of African Exploration. The advance of religion, of civilization, and of commerce were all involved in the opening up of Central Africa, and it was on that account that they appealed to that meeting, and to the greater public beyond, to take into serious consideration how much had been done in that direction in the last twenty-five years, and how great was the promised harvest if they joined in the great movement which was now going on. He moved, "That the commercial interests of this country are to a large extent involved in the development of intercourse and legitimate trade with the outports to the fertile but little known regions of Central Africa; and, therefore, that the scheme of thorough exploration proposed by the African Exploration Fund Committee deserves the warmest support of this meeting, as powerfully tending to secure that end."

Captain CAMERON seconded the motion. He said Africa was the most fertile country in the world. They had heard of the Spice Islands, but here was a spice continent. In Africa there was a great deal more produce than the people could possibly consume. As an illustration of how a trade might grow, he might mention that in 1875 the exports of India-rubber were of the value of 40,000l., in 1876 100,000l., and this year it was expected they would be 250,000l. The great difficulty was the means of communication, but all difficulties might be removed by systematic exploration, and the establishment of stations. The slave-trade was more horrid in its effects than any one who had not witnessed them could conceive. He had known whole villages destroyed, and 500 or 600 people driven into the jungle to perish of starvation or be destroyed by wild beasts, in order to procure 50 or 60 slaves. The slave-trade might be put down by opening up roads and systematic exploration, but it would require a long time to induce the people to abolish domestic slavery, which was so rooted in their habits that if a slave were freed to-day he would complain to-morrow if he were not allowed to have a slave of his own. He hoped that in the course of a few years we should see tramways up to the great lakes, and by using that unparalleled system of lakes the whole of Central Africa would be opened.'}, {'id': 3395, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1877#article-23', 'issue_date': '01_09_1877', 'content': 'Sir H. BARKLY moved: "That the opening up of Central Africa by geographical exploration, especially on its eastern side, is of great importance to our South African colonies and our possessions in Western India, as having for one of its prospective results a large development of commercial activity between the respective countries."

Colonel J. A. GRANT seconded the motion, and Mr. CAREY NICHOLS having addressed the meeting on the importance and practicability of laying down a telegraph line from Khartoum, in Egypt, overland to the Cape of Good Hope, the motion was put and agreed to.

On the motion of Sir RUTHERFORD ALCOCK, a vote of thanks was given to the Lord Mayor; and on the motion of Mr. DONALD CURRIE, a similar compliment was paid to Sir Rutherford Alcock, which brought the proceedings to a close.'}, {'id': 3745, 'article_title': 'AFRICA—OUR SECOND INDIA.', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICA—OUR SECOND INDIA.', 'last_edit_date': '02-22-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1879#article-13', 'issue_date': '01_03_1879', 'content': 'Sir,—Mr. Joshua Whalley, of Blackburn, writes me that the principal trade societies of that district have decided to take up my scheme for opening out Central Africa as the quarter from which relief may be most speedily expected for our languishing industries. They have had a preliminary meeting, when resolutions were passed to hold a ratepayers' meeting as soon as possible, and then to bring off a mass meeting in the Town Hall, Blackburn, for the purpose of agitating the subject. A similar meeting, I understand, is being organised in Rochdale. This is travelling in the right direction, and I now appeal to the working men of Lancashire, Yorkshire, Birmingham, and other places to hold similar meetings in their own towns. A fortnight ago, Mr. Hutchinson, the Lay Secretary of the Church Missionary Society, informed me that the torrid or equatorial zone of Africa, according to recent calculations which they had made, based upon information supplied by their missionaries, contained a hundred million of inhabitants. This is the region which I have all along been advocating we should tap, partly by means of rivers, and partly by means of railways. The broad facts cannot longer be denied—population, great natural wealth, the value of which the African is ignorant of up to the present time willingness on his part to take our manufactures in exchange for the natural products of cotton, gold, ivory, hides, gums, oils, and India-rubber, spices, and many other things. What more can a commercial community want than this? They contain all the elements of a grander mercantile future for England than we have yet seen. Our great men have hitherto thought scorn of this modern grander land of promise, but let us hope that now, from the monarch on the throne to the humblest scavenger in the cotton mill, our eyes will no longer be closed to the good things waiting for us in the long-neglected "dark continent."—Yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 3842, 'article_title': 'A Railway from Algeria to Senegal', 'full_section_title': 'A Railway from Algeria to Senegal', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1879#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_09_1879', 'content': 'We are enabled to publish the following translation of a letter addressed by the Minister of Public Works to the President of the French Republic, who has issued a decree for the appointment of the Commission recommended:—

Monsieur le President,—During late years the discoveries of various travellers have shown that Central Africa is very different from what people imagined. Formerly we believed that there were only huge deserts and barren land, while now, on the contrary, it has been proved that large tribes of human beings exist there, who are more or less in a state of semi-civilization. Important towns with many inhabitants are built upon the shores of the lakes and the banks of the rivers. The Sahara itself is not at all what has been described in unfinished and superficial observations. The movable sands, too, which were considered an impassable barrier, extending far and wide, are in reality only local; and generally the soil has a consistency and firmness which does not differ much from the soil of Europe. Soudan appears to be the most important part of this huge continent. Some travellers reckon the population at over one hundred millions. There is a large river, the Niger, which spreads over half its extent. The inhabitants are industrious, and the elements of an international commerce seem to be in existence there to a very high degree. Again, in surmounting difficulties, more or less considerable, this country can be approached from two sides, by Algeria and by Senegal. This problem has for the last twenty years filled the minds of many, and the time seems come to solve it practically. Two years since M. Dapouchel, one of our principal civil engineers, obtained permission from the Government to go to Algeria to collect all possible information about the nature of Soudan, as well as of Sahara. He was assisted by the wonderful narratives which had been published by several travellers, especially those of M. Daveyrier, by the accounts of chiefs of caravans, and by information he received from distinguished officers, who had frequently made expeditions in the South of Algeria; also by undertaking himself an exploration on the borders of the Great Desert. M. Dapouchel has been able to publish a very interesting memoir, which shows the possibility of uniting ourselves to the Niger by an unbroken line of railroad of 1,250 miles. However bold such an idea appears, we must not...
**101**'}, {'id': 5074, 'article_title': 'Bechuanaland—The Trade Gate to Tropical Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Bechuanaland—The Trade Gate to Tropical Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1885#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_04_1885', 'content': "This movement in Bechuanaland is the beginning of a great and new development for Cape Colony, for it is nothing less than giving that colony command over the trade to the interior of Southern Africa. Already there is a trade by wagon and natives estimated to exceed £1,000,000 per annum; but this new advance presupposes an enormous development of commerce; although it also forebodes the difficulties of guarding a trade route a thousand miles in length; and if the railway is soon to follow along this route, a great task will have been undertaken, which calls for the most careful consideration at its first inception. It is true that in magnitude and practical difficulties it is altogether thrown into the shade by such enterprises as that of the Congo International State, but it is none the less a really big problem, and one well worthy the close attention of English exporters; for a trunk line from Kimberley to the Zambesi would undoubtedly tap the trade of an enormous, rich, and a very populous area. That line is the crowning step in the undertaking, of which the first step is the present expedition to Bechuanaland, and the second the proclamation of the Queen's supremacy up to the 22nd parallel of latitude. The first step is to cost the British taxpayer one million sterling. If he will consent to leave matters to regulate themselves as heretofore, he will see Sir
**55**

Warren and his army come and go and leave not a wrack behind of permanent effect. He will see his million sunk and lost in the sands and bush of the interior. But if he awakes to the true nature of the case, takes good counsel while yet there is time, and combines with the Cape colonist to secure tangible, material, and lasting results, he will find that his million is not expended, but invested most profitably. — *Times.*"}, {'id': 6513, 'article_title': 'The African Slave Trade', 'full_section_title': 'The African Slave Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_12_1894#article-3', 'issue_date': '03_12_1894', 'content': "

The coasts was ineffective, they met in council and drew up a general Act of the Brussels Conference with the intention of attacking the African slave trade in the heart of the Continent. A great share in this work fell to Great Britain, and there were signs that the nation had now awoke to a sense of its responsibilities and was prepared to spend a moderate amount of money in the regeneration of Africa. As the result of treaties concluded in 1889-90, a portion of Central Africa was declared to be the British protectorate, and the remainder was described as a British sphere of influence, and placed under the charter of the British South Africa Company. That Company, indeed, had saved the situation. Through the action of Mr. Cecil Rhodes it came forward in 1890 and offered to assist in the administration of Central Africa by contributing towards a police force to put down the slave trade. In 1893, the sums supplied for this purpose amounted to over £20,000, and in previous years they were never less than £10,000. Almost all this money was spent within the British Protectorate, where the Company had few interests and no rights or privileges. In 1891 he (the speaker) was despatched by the Government to form an administration of the Protectorate, and was appointed to administer the British South African Company's territories under the charter. The Navy placed two light draft gunboats on the Zambesi and Shire, and later on a gunboat for the Upper Shire and two vessels of deeper draft for use on Lake Nyassa. But the most efficient and important aid was the recognition of a great principle—the association of the Indian Empire with the affairs of Africa. Her Majesty's Government sanctioned the appeal to the Commander-in-Chief in India for the loan of Indian soldiers to fight against the slave traders; and Lord Roberts allowed the late Capt. Maguire to form a contingent of seventy men for service in British Central Africa for two years. On July 16, 1891, he (the speaker) arrived at Tshioromo, at the junction of the Ruo and the Shire, and two days afterwards the first troubles with the slave-trading chiefs began. During the autumn of that year they fought several battles with the Yaos, and after a series of victories a great disaster befell them. Capt. Maguire had endeavoured to destroy the last two slave dhows belonging to Makanjira, but was killed in the attempt together with three of his men. Two other white men also lost their lives, and this misfortune was followed by the defeat of another portion of the police force by a Yao chief called Zarafi, when six Sikhs were killed and two white officers severely wounded. After this, however, the tide began to turn in their favour. The support they received from the mass of the Natives prevented the Yaos from following up their success, and ultimately the British force had a series of successes, culminating in the route of Makanjira, and the capture and occupation of his country. All this time the civil administration had gone forward. In three years the Trade had increased from £30,000 to £100,000, the number of European settlers from 57 to 265, the local revenue from £1,700 to £13,000. British coinage and weights and measures had been introduced, the acreage under cultivation by Europeans had increased from 1,000 to over 8,000 acres, and valuable coffee plantations were growing. A most marked result of the suppression of the slave trade was the release of an enormous amount of locked-up labour, thanks to the Natives having taken to regular work, finding that they were well paid by the European settlers. Much praise must be given to the Christian missionaries working in Nyassaland, who were assiduous in giving industrial training to the Natives attending their schools. The missionaries taught printing, joinery, brickmaking, cooking, and other useful trades, and if this good work is continued with prudence and assiduity the societies now working in British Central Africa would soon raise the negroes to a much higher level of civilisation. The speaker next referred to the part to be played by India in the development of Central Africa, and remarked that he had chosen three years ago black, white, and yellow as the typical colours of the protectorate—black representing the Negro, white the European, and yellow the Indian. He believed that the welfare of Central Africa could only be attained by the co-operation of those three races. The negro was endowed with magnificent muscular development and physique, but was clumsy and dull-witted; the white man was destined to be the governor and teacher of Africa, and must be at the head of all great departments and the initiator of all great enterprises; but between the Zambesi and Lower Egypt he could not hope to constitute himself a colonist, or to form an appreciable element in the indigenous population. He believed Africa, south of the Zambesi would some day be a white man's country; that pure-blooded white people would form the bulk of the population and the same of Northern Africa. But tropical Africa would never be the home of a white race, though it might be dotted over with little settlements on high mountains and elevated plateaux. He believed the Asiatic to be of equal importance with the white man in the regeneration of Africa. He could stand a hot climate better, he was clever with his hands and wits, though he lacked the initiative and the power of government. The results of the mingling of the Arab with the negro was in certain respects good, but he was so bound up with the principle of slavery, and so bigotted an opponent of European civilisation, as to be eliminated as a useful factor in tropical Africa; in fact, the result of European domination must be to drive the Arabs back to Arabia, and he looked to India to furnish the yellow element so indispensable to Africa. For centuries the trade with east Africa had lain in Indian hands, and they were now commencing to develop the commerce of Central Africa, and were well fitted for the work, being peaceable and law-abiding folk, industrious, modest in their demands as to pay, and able to work hard in a hot climate. As soldiers, he could not speak too highly of the Sikhs, and their chief value was in the way in which they had been able to infuse their own military qualities, training, and discipline into the negro mind. Wherever the Sikhs went the negroes would now follow, and in conflict with a foe white officers no longer found themselves abandoned by black soldiers. The development of trade with India would involve the employment of an increasing number of British Indian subjects, tracts of land now uninhabited might be offered to Indian emigrants, and the increased use of coinage and the absorption of rupees, might, in the course of time, assist in solving the silver question. In conclusion, Mr. Johnston spoke of the market to be opened up for British manufactures. The demand in Africa for British cotton goods was daily increasing, and with patience and timely expenditure the British Government had managed to retain vast districts which, if they had come under the control of another European Power, would have been placed under disadvantageous conditions as regards British trade."}]
tat_extra: [{'document_title': 'The Congo and the Conference in Reference to Commercial Geography', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Now, I wish to show you how this reflects on commercial geography. In commercial geography we have to study how all the rivers, lakes, and all possible roads and canals may be made to lead to the benefit of commerce. Commercial geography means the study of geography in such form that commerce may be benefited. If Mr. Stanley had simply gone down the Congo, and said it was a great river running towards the Equator, and had never done anything towards bringing its commercial capabilities into view, that would not have been commercial geography. But the great work of the International Association was the establishment of stations to be ports of refuge for traders, explorers, and missionaries at different positions in Africa. Owing to the work of Mr. Stanley, this became the International Association of the Haut Congo, and now is developed into the Congo Free State. The whole gist of the establishment of this Congo Free State has been to develop civilization and commerce in Central Africa. I might say commerce and civilization, because if legitimate commerce goes on, we may be sure that civilization will accompany it. It is by the discoveries made by Mr. Stanley and the officers of the International Association, that we can see how this great area of territory may be opened. When I was at Nyangwe, nobody had gone more than few miles west of it, and it was practically cut off from the West Coast. Now Mr. Stanley and M. de Brazza have found routes which, when opened up, will bring trade into the navigable portions of the Congo. When once you are on the navigable portions of the Congo, you can go up to Stanley Falls, and on to Stanley Pool, or you can go on to Lake Moero, and to Lake Bangweolo. You can actually get into the Chambesi, and, with very few breaks, this great water system is open. The Lualaba and other rivers there will all be opened to small steamboats, and it is by those that the commerce and manufactures of Europe will be spread over an area which is one of the biggest areas to conceive as a new market. Commercial geography finds that we have got this great system, and commercial geography says, How is this water system to be utilized? How do people carry now? Everything is carried on men's shoulders.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMANDER CAMERON ON CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Jan. 14th, Commander Cameron, in the Rooms of the Incorporated Chamber of Commerce at Liverpool, delivered an address on "The Commerce of Central Africa." Colonel Paris presided, and there was a large attendance of members and others interested. Commander Cameron, who, on rising, was loudly applauded, said: What he wished to speak about was the commerce of Africa, and what would come out of the Berlin Conference, and other events which were now happening; for the Conference could not fail to be of great importance to British trade. Tropical Africa, except in a few cases, on the shores of great water-ways, was scarcely known. From the interior the difficulties of transport prevented any profit except on the most valuable products. The first idea of the trader seemed ivory. India-rubber was coming into use, and before he left the West Coast over £20,000 worth had been exported from Zanzibar in one year. Many valuable gums and spices were found in Central Africa. Africa was to all appearance, until a few years ago, the happy hunting ground of Englishmen; it was only those who voyaged who could really compete with us. Now all these things were changed, and on every side they saw a scramble for Africa. It was our duty to know as much as possible about the resources of this continent, and how the future of Africa was to be controlled by the Congo Free State, which promised to be the outcome of the Berlin Conference. Very great results were to be expected, and he might mention that, north-east of Victoria Nyanza, there was a plateau which might be colonized by Europeans, and whence trade might be put into some of the great producing centres of Africa. The trade of the Arab at Zanzibar was carried out by a system of advance. On the west coast there was a trade carried on by a few Europeans. In the last century the Portuguese had an enormous trade up the Zambesi, and in Zumbo Town there were the ruins of a cathedral and a university which had at one time 370 students. There were two other towns of equal importance. The great difficulty in this trade was the climate. At a conference in Brussels in 1876, the idea of an International Association was sketched, and the King of the Belgians had set himself steadfastly to work to further this great idea of promoting the civilization of the "Dark Continent." Nearly all the people of Africa were traders; the cultivation of the soil was relegated to the women. At Nyanza there were enormous assemblies of people, some of whom came to market 15 or 20 miles, travelling against the current of the Congo. From this locality he had brought home nutmegs that were of the greatest use in commerce. From the same region there came wild coffee. There were enormous districts where any amount of rice could be grown; you had only to "scratch the earth," and it smiled at you. At some of these interior stations whole caravans were supplied by small villages with wheat sufficient for a week\'s journey. The people of those villages were able to produce for from ten to twelve times their number with scarcely any labour. On the Niger we had utilized water traffic, and the Congo had a number of miles of water carriage which could be utilized. There was, at the same time, the great difficulty of getting from the coast to this system on the Congo. Various schemes had been proposed to connect Stanley Pool with the Congo by railway, and he believed that after the settlement of the dispute between France and the International Association, the French would construct a railway to Stanley Pool, or the Association from the left bank of the Congo, and they would then be able to have instant communication with the centre of Africa. Further south, the Portuguese were beginning to wake up to the value of their territories. They were now making contracts to construct a railway into the interior. It was their duty as Englishmen to look after that scheme. The region he was speaking of produced ivory, gum, cotton, and spices. The Powers at the Berlin Conference had recognized the International Association as practically a sovereign State. What they must strongly insist upon was free trade, and permission to reside and trade in the Free State. Another point was as to the mode in which future annexations were to be made. Annexations had been going on rather fast lately, and the Conference agreement was to the effect that when a place was annexed notice was to be sent to the other countries, and that people trading at such a place were to continue trading under the same guarantees as formerly. He fancied that would be simply that there might be equal rights to all nations, and people already trading in places which had no European sovereign might find their positions injured by annexation on the part of European Powers. In this matter, also, he thought that great care had to be exercised. Then they had to think of the great trade which used to pass down Egypt from the Upper Nile. The Suakin and Berber Railway was contracted for at one time by Ismail Pasha, but he was compelled to give up the idea. If that railway had been built, we should have had none of the difficulties in the Soudan which we had at present. He mentioned as a sign of the times that an Ambassador from Timbuctoo was at Paris treating with the President of the French Republic. We had the trade of the Lower Niger in our hands, but in the Upper Niger a great portion of the trade might be diverted from us if the proposed railway were completed. There was one thing which he must say, and that was that if we wanted outlets for our goods we must send proper and suitable goods for the people. The establishment of the Congo Free State would prove a benefit to English trade, but we must watch the constitution of that State, and, if there were any objectionable features in it, get them removed. In conclusion, Commander Cameron remarked that in a very large portion of Africa cotton of very good quality grew. He had specimens at home of cotton goods which had been made by the natives in the interior, and he believed that, as communication improved they would see cargoes of cotton coming to Liverpool from Central Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The trade between this country and West Africa is capable of almost infinite development. It is now announced that the British Government will recommend Parliament to grant a subsidy to a contractor who is prepared to lay and work a cable between St. Vincent and the chief places on the West Coast. We are sure our readers will rejoice at this further step towards bringing West Africa into closer connexion with England. At present, the three weeks taken by even the fastest postal communication is a serious drawback to the commerce of Lagos, Sierra Leone, and the other West African ports, and the proposed cable will do much to simplify and develop commercial relations between Great Britain and the ports and towns in her West Coast possessions. Further south, we have the still more important district of the Congo. Mr. H. M. Stanley, than whom no greater authority upon the subject exists, seems never to tire of pointing out the advantages which must result from the formation of new markets in the Congo territory; and the decision of the European Powers at the Berlin Conference that Free Trade principles should be established at least for a term of years in the territory of the African International Association will do much towards the development of trade with parts not hitherto reached by commerce. The British Congo Company (Limited), the prospectus of which our readers will find in another column, which may be aptly described as the practical outcome of the Conference's decision, is now announced, with a capital of £500,000, divided into shares of £5 each. The Board of Directors contains many names well known in the African trade. Even under no very favourable circumstances a considerable trade has been for the past few years conducted between this country and the Congo. Last year, the imports into this district amounted to considerably over £880,000, and the exports to nearly £2,000,000—so that in round numbers the present trade may be roughly estimated at between two and a-half and three million pounds per annum. Though only just formed, the British Congo Company (Limited) will scarcely commence as an entirely new undertaking, for, in order to avoid the delays and disadvantages inseparable from an entirely new business, a provisional agreement has been made with the Congo and Central African Company (Limited), of Liverpool, which possesses several factories and stations along the river, and at Ambriz and Ambrizette on the coast, by which the Congo and Central African Company agrees to transfer its stations, factories, and buildings, stores and plant, its steamers, cargo, surf and other boats, to this Company at a valuation, to be paid for by fully paid-up shares in this Company, and to sell its stock of goods, merchandise, and produce to this Company at cost price. No payment will be made for goodwill, the shareholders in that Company being satisfied that they will make a larger profit by becoming interested in a more powerfully-constituted undertaking. This agreement will provide the new Company at once with a favourable basis for its operations, and enable it to enter immediately upon a profitable business in the Lower Congo district, and give great facilities for opening up trade as communications with the Upper Congo are established. Thus we are assured of a speedy increase of an already existing trade in the districts placed under the International African Association, and the British Congo Company (Limited), by possessing stations upon the coast as well as along the course of the river, will be well prepared to participate in the trade which is constantly developing among the peoples in the interior.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMANDER CAMERON AGAIN ON CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At a quarter past 12 a crowded audience assembled in the small Concert-room to hear an address from Commander Cameron, R.N., the distinguished African traveller, on "Trade with Central Africa." Mr. Shaw Lefevre, M.P., presided, and briefly introduced the speaker. Commander Cameron said that the trade of Central Africa is now virtually confined to two things—ivory and slaves; and, owing to the difficulties of transit, the whole of the ivory is carried to the coast by porters. Owing to this, the Arab traders and others were compelled to buy slaves to carry their goods. Central Africa was naturally capable of becoming one of the greatest producing countries in the world, and, as such a producer, of taking a large quantity of the manufactured article in return for the raw material. At present the Arab traders from the east had penetrated about half-way across the continent till they were met by the Portuguese traders on the west. The cost of carriage of ivory to the coast was now so great as to absorb nearly all the profits, although a hundred dollars worth of ivory could be bought in the interior for a pound weight of beads. The mineral resources of Central Africa were very great, including coal in large quantities, iron, copper, gold, silver, and others. The oil palm existed over the entire continent to the height of 2,600 feet above the sea; and nutmeg trees grew wild. He had walked for 200 and 300 yards at a time through nutmeg groves, the ground being literally covered with the nuts—all going to waste. At present nobody knew their value; they sought only for ivory, and thought of nothing else. In order to develop trade in these rich districts, one thing was essential—proper means of communication must be established. There were already three great water highways—the Nile, the Congo, and the Zambesi. Of these the most important was the Congo, by far the largest river in Africa. Its mouth did not now belong to any civilized country, like the Nile or Zambesi; and whilst the journey by the Congo to the heart of Africa would be only 500 to 600 miles, the like journey by the Nile would be 3,000 or 4,000 miles, and on the route they would everywhere find the Egyptian traders in conflict with the natives. In fact, no expedition could now make its way into Africa from the north by means of the Nile except by means of armed force. From the Congo to the head waters of the Zambesi a canal of twenty to thirty miles in length across a level country would connect the two systems, and provide an uninterrupted water communication across the entire continent. (Hear, hear.) By means of the northern affluents of the Congo they would afford easy water carriage to the coast from other extensive districts. The mouth of the Congo had no bar, and was not difficult of approach. There were some rocks in the stream, but such as steam navigation would easily deal with. At one place there were cataracts, but a porterage of about thirty miles would enable travellers to reach the upper waters of the Congo. The Lualaba, which nobody, he thought, now doubted was the upper Congo, was a splendid stream. At one place he measured it, and found it 1,080 yards across, with an average depth of one fathom, but with three channels of over three fathoms\' depth; and as this was the dry season, it was clear that the stream was navigable all the year round. By sending out steamers to be taken to pieces at the rapids, and put together again above them, they could force their way right into the continent, and get access to Lake Tanganyika. Of course human porterage could not compete with steam carriage; goods would be brought to the coast cheaply, and thus one great blow would be struck at the slave-trade. Already on Lake Nyassa the Scotch missionaries had a steamer, and if they could only get steam on to Tanganyika, they would get command of the whole of that splendid water to its southern extremity. The King of the Belgians had been talking of getting up an international scheme for exploring and civilizing Africa. His idea was to form stations right across the continent, and so form a great trunk road; and as the continent at that part was only 1,600 to 1,700 miles across, it was quite possible to establish such a line of communication. Having ridiculed the arguments of those who would let Africa alone, through a sentimental reluctance to interfere with the liberty of the native races, remarking that there was little liberty under the rule of despots who in a drunken freak would cut off the ears and noses of their subjects, Commander Cameron advocated the establishment of a great company which should be upon the model of the East India Company, because no capitalists would risk their money unless protected from the inroads of others who would otherwise reap the benefits of their first labours and expenses. He described the climate of the highlands of Central...', 'last_edit_date': '1876-10-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1876#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist\'s point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist\'s point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PORTUGAL AND CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "LISBON, Thursday.—At the last meeting of the Commercial Association reference was made to the importance of Portugal obtaining information respecting Central Africa. It was proposed to ask the Government to send an expedition to carry out Lieutenant Cameron's projects, starting from Angola. The suggestion was made that scientific men should accompany the expedition, and that relations should be entered into with the neighbouring tribes with a view to the development of the resources of the country.", 'last_edit_date': '1876-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1876#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Commercial Outlook in the Congo Basin', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In view of increased interest in the Congo question, the vigorous resistance to any interference with the freedom of trade in those regions, and the feeling that the condition of trade makes the opening of new markets for the staple manufactures of this district a necessity, the Congo basin affords a suitable region for attempts to carry into effect the idea suggested at the annual meeting of the Manchester Guardian Trade Protection Society. One of the speakers suggested that as trade appears to be suffering from the fact that production exceeds consumption, it would be a good thing if capital was more systematically devoted to the work of distribution. We must conclude that some impulse to the distribution of wealth is needed; and a wider distribution of mercantile profits would doubtless be a consequence of the application of the joint-stock principle to mercantile enterprise.\n\nThere is a well-founded belief that the economic development of Africa will be a work of time, and that it is not at all likely to advance by "leaps and bounds." The fact is, that so far as the West Coast is concerned, experienced authorities have pointed out that the black man must be interested in cultivation if trade is to be permanent and African communities are to become large consumers of European manufactures. At the present rate of indiscriminate collection, the supplies of ivory must eventually be exhausted, the India-rubber and other plants be destroyed, and the whole country be converted into a waste. It is upon the interior that the interest of the trading and investing public is concentrated, because it is the region of untried possibilities. But the prudent ask whether, assuming the existence of vast stores of produce and favourable conditions of development and progress, markets can be found at paying prices for the produce which Central Africa may yield. It is a question of cost as well as of productiveness. African rivers are interrupted by cataracts from which the great rivers of other continents still only partially developed are free. It is true that the construction of railways is hinted at, but questions arise as to what will be the cost of such railways, who will provide the capital, how long before they become remunerative, and how many transhipments will be required; for it is conceivable that the mere cost of transporting produce to the consuming markets might prove greater than the price obtainable for them.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1885#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa at the Meeting of the British Association', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the recent meeting of the members of the British Association, in the Geographical Section, Major Darwin, the Chairman, had a good deal to say about the development of Central Africa by means of railways. The great barrier, Major Darwin said, to the progress of colonisation was the belt of fever-stricken forest near the coast; and the problem was how to cross those malarial regions quickly into the healthy interior, where the higher type of Native was to be found. The slave-raiding in the interior also tended to impede progress; and the opening up of main trunk lines of communication would be the most effective means of counteracting the slave trade. To develop the traffic along the rivers and in the lakes was the first stage in the commercial evolution of a continent like Africa. But the rivers were obstructed by cataracts, and the construction of railways must, therefore, be the second stage. Taking the East Coast first, the first region to attract attention was the valley of the Nile and parts of the Central Soudan. The sooner this region was connected with the civilised world the better, and it was only as to the method of opening it up and as to who was to undertake the work that any question would arise. Below Berber the Nile was interrupted by cataracts for several hundred miles, while above that town it was navigable for 1,400 miles. The importance of a railway from Suakim to Berber was thus evident, and there was perhaps only one other place in Africa where an equal expenditure would open up such a large extent of country to European trade. Passing further south, the lines of communication next considered were those leading to the Victoria Nyanza, and on to the regions lying north and west of the lake. Two routes for railways had been proposed, one running through the British and the other through the German sphere of influence. The German route would be shorter, but the British line would open up more country to the east suitable for prolonged residence by white men. If the Germans wished to launch out on great railway projects in Africa, let them make a line from the south end of Lake Tanganyika to the northern end of Lake Nyassa, and thence on to the coast. Such a line of communication would be most valuable in putting an end to the slave trade, for it would erect a great barrier across the roads traversed by the raiders. Further south they came to the Zambesi River. This line had many faults. The whole valley was unhealthy, and white men would prefer a route which would bring them to high land more quickly. The Upper Zambesi valley was likely to be more attractive to white men. The Beira Railway would form a much better line of communication to this region than the river itself. The Congo afforded a grand opportunity of opening up the interior. From the coast there was 150 miles of navigable waterway, and afterwards there were 200 miles of cataracts, round which a railway was being made. From Stanley Pool there were 7,000 miles of navigable waterway, so they might predict a grand future for this route to the interior. The next great navigable waterway met with was the Niger. There was no area of equal size so densely inhabited, or where trade offered greater inducement to open up a commercial route. Little had to be done in this respect, for the Niger was navigable for light draught steamers 550 miles from the sea. The only drawback was the unhealthy nature of the coast districts which had to be traversed. At Lagos, a survey of a railway running in the direction of Rabba had been made, the objective being the towns of Abeokuta and Ibadan; and surveys had also been made for a railway to connect either Kormantin or Apam with Insuian. It was possible that those who selected this route were too much influenced by a desire to reach Coomassie, which was a political rather than a commercial centre. It was to be hoped that the merits of a line from Accra to Odumase would be considered before it was too late. For connecting the Upper Niger with the coast, the best commercial route would be a line running in a north-easterly direction to the Upper Niger. Such a line would connect the longest stretch of navigable waterway in this region with the best harbour on the coast. But the fact that it crossed the Anglo-French boundary was a bar to this project at present. The proposal to connect Algeria with the Upper Niger would be simple madness. The idea was thus to unite the French spheres of influence, but he was sure the French would not waste their money on such schemes. Concluding, the President said his object had been to prove that, notwithstanding the strides geography had made in past years, there was yet an immense amount of work ready for anyone who would undertake it.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The West Coast of Africa and the Congo', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following letters appeared recently in the Manchester Guardian:—\n\n"Sir,—During a recent visit to Manchester I found the members of the Chamber of Commerce engaged in considering the question of trade at the above places. I had some conversation with some of the Manchester merchants and manufacturers, and I found that there was a very great desire to open up trade in the River Congo. I asked, why? The general reply was that the natives on the West Coast were getting to know too much; one or two others said that the trade was so bad on the West Coast that it was thought better to open up a new place. I suggested that the interior should be opened up instead of seeking new places for the purpose of improving trade; that the merchants should assist the natives in developing the country by making railways into the interior; and that Lagos might be connected with the mainland both coastwards and towards the interior by bridges. The reply I met with was, \'Let the natives do it themselves.\' I said that they could not, but that they expected the English Government to do it—at least, to make the railways. On this point, no doubt, many of those who read this letter will remember the reply of Lord Derby to the deputation of West Coast merchants on this subject; and I certainly agree with his lordship that it is not the duty of the English Government to make railways for the benefit of the merchants. It is no secret that the trade in Manchester and district is about as bad as it can well be; hence the desire to open up new places for trade. But I do think that those connected with the West Coast trade would do well to give a little closer attention to the trade by assisting in developing the country, instead of abandoning a place which is capable of doing so much. Nothing that I can say on the subject, notwithstanding a two years\' residence on the Coast, will have so much effect as the figures showing the imports and exports at Lagos alone, which port could easily', 'last_edit_date': '1884-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1884#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Exploration in Central Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"My Lord,—Since I last wrote from here I have made a successful voyage round the southern part of the Tanganyika, and have discovered its outlet in a river named the Lukuga, a little to the south of the group of islands visited by Captain Speke in 1859. I think, also, from what I have heard from the Arabs here, that the Lualabas is the Congo. My reasons for saying this are fully stated in the letter and journal I am now sending to the Royal Geographical Society, who will no doubt afford every information on the subject. One important fact (if true) mentioned by my Arab informant requires looking into. He said he met no English merchants, although he heard of them and of our men-of-war, as all the white merchants he met traded in slaves. This, if true, would point to the Spanish and Portuguese merchants on the Congo. Of the vast importance to the trading community of England of the Congo and Lualaba proving one, there is little for me to say, but I will glance over the principal articles of export. The Guinea palm extends, I believe, from the West Coast to here; india-rubber is abundant in Manyema; sem sem (from which much so-called olive oil is extracted) grows well wherever cultivated; the castor-oil plant grows almost wild; ground nuts the same; copper and gold are found in Katanga; cotton grows well, and of two or three kinds; coffee is reported to grow wild; ivory, it is well known, mostly comes from this portion of Africa; there are many sorts of fibrous substances which might be exported with advantage, and the various millets and maize grow in such abundance that they would form a profitable export; rice also grows most luxuriantly wherever cultivated. The only obstacles to a free water communication of which I know are the Yellala Falls and the rapids on the Lualaba, a short way above the Nyangwé; the Lukuga is at present obstructed with grass, but a way might easily be cut through that. The trade at present is, about here, entirely in the hands of Arabs, who, when in Manyema, live nearly entirely by plunder, and who take the wretched inhabitants as slaves to carry their ivory and other goods. The efforts of England will, I trust, be successful in putting down the slave trade by sea, but at present they leave untouched an equally crying evil, the internal trade, which is rapidly depopulating vast districts. In going round the lake I was constantly shown places where villages had been, and when I asked where the former inhabitants were, invariably received the same answer, \'Killed or carried off for slaves.\' The price of a slave is only 5 dolis (20 yards) of calico, while the hire of a passage is 5l from Unyanyembe here; so that it is far cheaper to buy slaves than to hire porters; besides which, no porters are obtainable in Manyema, and the whole trade there is carried on by means of slaves. The Arabs take with them a horde of Wangwana, or freed men, armed with muskets, and carry a few stores by means of domestic slaves; and the ivory, of which they obtain large quantities, is all brought by fresh-caught slaves to Ujiji. The numbers of Arabs settling in the country is constantly increasing, and they all have large numbers of slaves for domestic purposes, for cultivating their gardens, and for porters. Many of those employed as porters only receive rations whilst on journeys, and when not travelling have to live by plunder. Of the relations between the various tribes there is little to be said; the agricultural people seldom make war on each other, unless they get mixed up with the quarrels of the Arabs, to any great extent; the predatory tribes prey on all others indiscriminately, carrying off slaves, and murdering all who attempt to resist. The cattle they slaughter at once, and find a ready market for their slaves among the Arab traders and tribes with whom they are not actually warring. I am afraid that stopping the export of slaves, although it will diminish the evil in the districts round the Nyass, from whence Kilwa draws its principal supplies, will only exacerbate it elsewhere by causing many now engaged in that trade to settle in the interior, where they will become slave-holders and traders afresh. In conclusion, let me add that, in my belief, this internal slave trade will continue to increase until proper means of communication are opened up, and the country brought under the influence of civilization and legitimate commerce.', 'last_edit_date': '1874-05-14', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/31_12_1874#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '2. Every effort should be made to open commercial relations with tribes hitherto inaccessible, either by inviting the visits of caravans from a distance, as a recent Governor of Sierra Leone did, or by encouraging exploring expeditions by British officers and others, as has been done in Ashanti and the countries beyond, from Cape Coast, or by attempting to arbitrate between contending tribes in the interests of commerce, as has been done in the Yoruba territory from Lagos. During the last decade, the Church, Scotch, and London Missionary Societies have shown themselves more enterprising on the east of Africa than on the west; and yet in the rivers of Western Africa there are better highways to the interior than the caravan route into the Galla and Wagogo countries. The physical difficulties which exist, together with the political subdivision of the country, ought not to prevent direct communication with the potentates of Senegambia, Gando and Sockatu on the west any more than with Uganda and Unyamiwezi on the east. As the Germans seem determined to invade commercially the countries on the great branch of the Niger called the Binué Chadda, it is time that the British Missionary and Trading Societies should open up the countries in the Upper Niger and the Gambia to the Christian religion, commerce, and freedom.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The River Gambia as a Trading Route to the Interior of North-west Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"We have pretty well worked up about three-fourths of the markets of the world and glutted them, leaving the remainder, Africa, almost untouched; for, as yet, except in South Africa, our trade has but barely penetrated beyond the coast line, and our merchants remain at the outposts competing with each other and over-working the local markets. Expeditions are rapidly following one another and giving us full information about the interior of Equatorial Africa. Railways and canals are proposed for the opening up of that part of Africa, and they will, years hence, no doubt, prove an incalculable benefit; but why should we wait for these costly works? Why not utilize the arteries already provided by nature for traffic with the interior? Northwest Africa is a market to a great extent as yet unworked. The markets of Sego and Timbuctoo, Hamdallahi, and other large towns on the Upper Niger are most inadequately supplied with British goods by caravans from Tunis, Tripoli, Mogador, and Senegal, and the carriage is so expensive that none but the lightest and most valuable can be imported across the desert. Now the French river, Senegal, though it drains the country for over 700 miles, is practically useless as a channel of commerce. It has a bad and dangerous bar. Ships have often to lie outside weeks, and even months, waiting to enter the port of St. Louis. Its channel into the interior is full of sand bars and rocks, obstructing navigation by even small craft for most of the year; and the tribes to the north-east of its head-waters, of Arab origin, are ferocious and predatory, living by plunder; therefore, commerce meets with danger and difficulty in their neighbourhood. About 180 miles to the south is the Gambia, which seems intended by nature to be the main road for commerce, civilization, and religion into North-west Africa. At all states of the tide, at all seasons of the year, you have a deep and safe channel over the bar; vessels of 2,000 to 3,000 tons can come in and anchor off Bathurst, and discharge and load. The traffic up the river is carried on by large cutters and schooners. Even oceangoing vessels of large tonnage go up to M\'Carthy Island, 185 miles from the mouth, and load. Lately, an ocean steamer, of about 900 tons, went there direct from Marseilles, and loaded there; and at the present moment, a French firm trading in Gambia is building a 1,200-ton steamer to run between Marseilles and that island every season, and discharge and load there, instead of breaking bulk at Bathurst. At M\'Carthy Island there are five fathoms of water in mid-channel. Then, vessels drawing ten feet of water can go up to Yarbutenda, 160 miles further; so that had we steamers suited for the trade, like the French vessels I have mentioned, they could load at Liverpool or London, reach Bathurst in twelve days, M\'Carthy Island in twenty-four hours, Yarbutenda in twenty-four hours more, making fourteen days in all."', 'last_edit_date': '1879-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The River Gambia as a Trading Route to the Interior of North-west Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following communication has been sent to us. We believe it has also appeared in a Manchester journal. It is written by one who has a practical knowledge of what he is writing about, and is valuable in showing what opportunities there are in that part for the extension of British commerce, and, by its aid, the introduction of Christian civilization into North-west Africa.—Ed. A.T.\n\n**TRADE WITH THE INTERIOR OF AFRICA.**\n\nWe have received the following from a correspondent on the subject of the opportunities for commercial enterprise which Africa presents:', 'last_edit_date': '1879-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.718, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'RAILWAYS FOR WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Mr. Hutton, of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce, said that this subject had always been of the greatest interest to the Manchester Chamber, for they were deeply impressed with the necessity for new markets and of the extension of our old ones in order to provide employment for our growing population. For a long time the interests of West Africa had been much neglected, which makes it the more necessary now to miss no opportunity of preventing any further alienation of trade. If railways are laid into the interior the existing trade will be attracted to the cheapest route, and in this way we shall be able to counteract the efforts the French are making to divert the caravans from the interior to French ports. Although we have now been trading with West Africa for over a century we have hardly done more than touch the fringe of the Nigerian Soudan, and the reason is that the roads into the interior are little more than wide ruts through the bush and forest. This is particularly the case on the Gold Coast, where duties were increased, with the object of improving these so-called roads. If railways were constructed these difficulties would disappear, and we should soon see a large and substantial increase in our trade. Had railways been in existence the Jebu and Ashanti expeditions would have cost very much less, and probably there would have been no necessity for them, for with good means of communication it would be easier to maintain friendly relations with the interior chiefs, who would soon recognise that their interests were identical with ours in promoting trade with the Soudan. If the merchant could take his goods into the interior at a reasonable rate, he would find an unlimited demand for his manufactures, and the Native could cultivate his soil to its full capabilities. In this way a new market of enormous possibilities, would be created for British trade. We cannot hope for any great extension of our West African trade under present conditions, but with railways the possibilities of an increase are enormous, as we should then be put in connexion with an industrious race of people and systematic cultivation. He could not speak too strongly about the urgency of the question, for if they delayed too long France or Germany may step in, and one of the best markets in Africa would be lost to this country.\n\nMr. R. C. N'Kinnon, of the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, also emphasised the importance of the subject.", 'last_edit_date': '1895-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1895#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Spirit Trade with West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A report has lately been drawn up by the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, and forwarded to the Secretary for the Colonies, in compliance with his request in August last for information on the subject and for suggestions to aid him in dealing with the matter, in view of statements made, to the effect that the promotion of trade in West Africa meant the promotion of trade in liquor. Under the head of remarks and recommendations the report says:—', 'last_edit_date': '1895-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1895#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: The financial world only recently recognized Africa's potential for profitable trade beyond the slave trade, with much of the continent's interior remaining untapped due to limited knowledge outside trade circles.
result: The observations from the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a comprehensive view of the claim that the financial world only recently recognized Africa's potential for profitable trade beyond the slave trade. The General History of Africa offers a nuanced perspective, acknowledging that Africa's economic potential was recognized earlier than the claim suggests, particularly with the shift to export agriculture and integration into the capitalist world-economy around 1750. This period saw the development of new trade routes and export-oriented production, although Africa lagged in technological advancements compared to industrialized Europe. The commercial unification of Africa in the nineteenth century and the expansion of intra-African trade networks further indicate that the continent's interior was not as untapped as the claim implies. European commercial firms played a significant role in connecting Africa with global markets, suggesting that its economic potential was recognized well before recent times. In contrast, The African Times articles support the claim by highlighting the recent awakening of the financial world to Africa's vast resources, including its rich agricultural, natural, and mineral wealth, which had been previously overlooked due to the focus on the slave trade. The articles emphasize the untapped potential of Africa's interior, noting geographical and logistical challenges, such as dangerous caravan routes and the need for improved infrastructure. They also point out the slow development of trade, with British merchants being slow to seize opportunities, while German, French, and Belgian merchants actively expanded their operations. Together, these observations illustrate both the historical recognition of Africa's trade potential and the contemporary challenges and opportunities in accessing its interior markets.
gha: The paragraphs from the General History of Africa textbook provide a nuanced view that both supports and refutes the claim. The text acknowledges that Africa's economic potential beyond the slave trade was recognized earlier than the claim suggests, particularly with the shift to export agriculture and the integration of Africa into the capitalist world-economy starting around 1750. This transition marked a significant change in Africa's economic relations with the wider world, leading to the development of new trade routes and the rise of export-oriented production. However, the text also highlights that this transformation was not accompanied by technological advancements, leaving Africa at a disadvantage compared to industrialized Europe. Furthermore, the commercial unification of Africa in the nineteenth century and the expansion of intra-African trade networks suggest that the continent's interior was not as untapped as the claim implies. The text also notes the role of European commercial firms in connecting Africa with global markets, indicating that Africa's economic potential was recognized well before recent times. Therefore, while the claim that Africa's potential for profitable trade beyond the slave trade was only recently recognized is partially refuted by historical evidence of earlier economic integration, the text does acknowledge the limitations and challenges that persisted in fully realizing this potential.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that the financial world only recently recognized Africa's potential for profitable trade beyond the slave trade. The articles highlight the awakening of the financial world to Africa's vast resources, emphasizing the continent's rich agricultural, natural, and mineral wealth that had been previously overlooked due to the focus on the slave trade. They also discuss the untapped potential of Africa's interior, noting that much of it remains unexplored and underdeveloped, with limited knowledge outside trade circles. The articles mention the challenges of accessing the interior markets due to geographical and logistical obstacles, such as dangerous and tedious caravan routes across the Sahara and the need for improved transportation infrastructure like railways and canals. Additionally, the articles point out the slow development of trade in Africa, with the British public and merchants being slow to grasp the opportunities, and the competition from German, French, and Belgian merchants who are actively expanding their operations. These observations align with the claim, highlighting both the recent recognition of Africa's trade potential and the challenges in accessing its interior markets.
