As E. A. Alpers has noted, 'What Africans received in exchange for ivory, even though it had little intrinsic value in their own societies, were goods that in no way equalled the value placed on ivory by the merchant capitalists of India, Europe and America.' 65 This discrepancy was particularly acute in the sale of captives. In return for the lost labour power, the Central African societies received a variety of inexpensive perishable commodities and weapons of destruction, neither of which compensated for the depletion of the work force. Similarly, when Africans hunted ivory they were exhausting a limited resource and were not receiving capital goods that expanded the productive base of their societies. Recent research suggests that they were not only distorting their economies but also destroying the ecology.
As the region was becoming progressively impoverished, disparities in wealth and social equality became more pronounced. Although more detailed research is needed to determine the character of the production systems and the allocation of surplus in specific Central African societies, it is clear that the dominant aristocracy, often allied with all or a fraction of the merchant class, was the principal beneficiary. The emergence of the powerful Yao chiefs, Makanjila and Mataka, testifies to the growing political and social differentiation within these societies, as do the desperate efforts of the Makua rulers to remain in power.$^{66}$ A similar phenomenon occurred in the sultanates of Angoche and Quitanghona and in the Chikunda and Arab-Swahili conquest states, where a small political-commercial class prevailed despite growing opposition and periodic revolts. The extent to which popular discontent surfaced more frequently during the second half of the century suggests growing class antagonisms as did slave uprisings in Lozi society and on the prazos."
In other instances trading interests, independent of the rulers, were able to dominate commerce and undercut the position of the political authorities.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.636, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig:
[{'id': 252, 'article_title': 'General Observations', 'full_section_title': 'General Observations', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_11_1863', 'content': 'THERE is likely to be great suffering from drought on the Gold Coast. The rainfall during the wet season, which is now over, has been smaller than known for many years. The gross neglect of the British Government in not making the effort to obtain water by boring at Cape Coast—neglect which we denounced two years ago—may be the cause of fatal disasters there in this otherwise unusually healthy season.

Captain Burton, who is charged with a mission to Dahomey, not being at Lagos when the mail from England arrived there with the presents sent from England by Her Majesty's Government for the King, a steamer was sent down to the Bight to bring him up, and convey him, with the presents, to Whydah. We wait the intelligence of his arrival there with great interest, as our readers will remember that he has instructions not to go up to the capital, unless he receives a promise that there shall be no human sacrifices during his stay there.

We have accounts of additions to the mass of misery shipped off the Dahoman coast for Cuba. 1,200 slaves have been got off safely from Popo.

Our readers will perceive that there is promise of great progress at Sierra Leone.

---

The merchants trading between London and Lagos seem to be unanimous in their condemnation of the Government, in allowing Mr. Stanhope Freeman to resume the duties of Governor of Lagos.

The privilege of prepaying letters, &c., by postage stamps is loudly called for, and with reason, by the Gold Coast people. And Lagos, although now two years a British colony, remains without colonial postage privileges.

Porto Novo, under French direction, is working great damage to the trade of Lagos, now burdened with duties, from which that of Porto Novo is exempt.

It is believed that the Ashantees will soon resume the offensive and recross the Praah.

African coffee realised lately the highest price of the day in Mincing-lane—78s. per cwt. for 150 bags.

"Wanderings in Western Africa," by an F.R.G.S., is much spoken of. We hope to review it in our next.

The daily press, in August last, was prolific in letters and papers on Dahomey and Ashantee, among which the letters of "An African" in the Times were conspicuous. We thought our real African friends would demolish such fables. We think it will be admitted that the letter of "Tom Coffee" in this number has done so most effectually.

The Government of Lagos is not in future to have a consulate attached to it, as heretofore. The Governor will be Governor of Lagos, and nothing more.

We hear that the West African Company have purchased the small steamboat made some years since for the King of Calabar, and that she is to navigate the Cradu waters and Lagos River as a passenger boat. We think she may be very useful to the colony in that capacity.

The value of export produce, chiefly cotton and palm oil, shut up in Abeokuta, is estimated at from sixty to eighty thousand pounds.'}, {'id': 5346, 'article_title': 'Produce Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Produce Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1886#article-24', 'issue_date': '01_03_1886', 'content': "**COCOA** is a slow sale, and the transactions are limited to 125 bags African at 67s. to 69s. per cwt.

**GAMBIER.**—Block dull at 21s. 9d. to 21s. 10¼d. per cwt.

**GUM.**—Orders continue very scarce, and no business of moment reported, but an improved inquiry may be looked for, as consumers are evidently allowing their stocks to run very low.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—There has been more doing in Para within the range of the quotations; African quieter, but holders very firm.

**EBONY.**—90 tons Old Calabar at £7 to £10 15s. per ton.

**CAMWOOD.**—About 15 tons sold at £27 5s. to £28 10s. per ton.

**PALM KERNELS** steady, with a continued fair inquiry on the spot.

**PALM OIL.**—The market has been depressed, and the business is only small at prices marking a decline of 10s. to 20s., closing very flat. 400 tons sold; Cameroons and New Calabar at £21, Bonny at £21 15s. to £21, Old Calabar at £22 to £21 10s., and Lagos at £24 10s. per ton.

**TALLOW** quiet and only a moderate business passing at the quotations.

**OLIVE OIL** in limited request, and sales include Spanish at £38 to £39, Lisbon at £38 to £38 5s., and Mogadore at £35 per tun.

**SEED OILS.**—Linseed: Firm at 20s. 9d. to 21s. per cwt., in export casks; Rape, slow; English Refined 26s., and Refined Stettin 28s. to 28s. 6d. per cwt.; Cottonseed—Liverpool Refined, 18s. 6d. to 19s.; small sales of American at 21s. 6d. to 22s. 6d. per cwt., as in quality.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19.**

**SUGAR.**—The market opened dull, and a further decline of 3d. to 6d. was submitted to; there has been no material change since. Beet has been flat, with a drooping tendency, and closing sales show a decline of 1s.

**MOLASSES.**—American grocery Treacle remains very quiet on the spot at 6s.; sales have been made for April shipment at about 5s. 6d., and further business is pending.

**RUM.**—There has been rather more disposition shown to operate at the present low currencies, and 588 puncheons Demerara have been sold.

**COFFEE.**—The market generally is inanimate, and, with the exception of African, which is 6d. dearer, prices are unchanged. 250 bags African, bold berry, at 28s. 9d., 90 bags Ceara at 38s., and 54 bags Rio at 35s. to 36s. 9d. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—The demand has been very limited, and the little business done is not sufficient to test prices. 50 bags African at 71s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Market very firm; Para rather dearer.

**LINSEED.**—The demand for spot parcels continues very good; prices have further advanced fully 1s. to 1s. 6d., and, at the close, there is little offering. There has also been a good inquiry for arrivals, but, sellers being indisposed to operate, business is only small at 6d. advance. The sales include 400 bags Turkish at 42s. 6d.

**BENNISEED.**—Small sales of Sierra Leone at 38s. per 384 lbs.

**PALM KERNELS** are quiet, and prices are the turn in buyers' favour."}, {'id': 5522, 'article_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS', 'full_section_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1887#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_04_1887', 'content': 'LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 4.**

**SUGAR.**—The business was only small during the early part of the week, but there has been rather more doing the last day or two, without, however, any change in prices.

**MOLASSES.**—American grocery Treacle idle. American Syrup sold at steady prices.

**RUM** quiet, but steady, dealers having supplied their immediate wants out of the recent large business; holders are firm in declining any further concession, and the sales are limited to 86 puncheons of Demerara.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been very inanimate, and there is no business to report, beyond small sales of Jacmel at 65s. 6d. per cwt.

**COCOA** continues to be neglected, the only transaction to notice being 50 bags Guayaquil at 62s. 6d. per cwt.

**GAMBIER.**—Block firm at 22s. 6d., on spot; about 70 tons sold, to arrive, January steamer at 22s. to 22s. 3d., and January-February steamer at 22s. 3d. per cwt.

**GUM.**—The market is steady, but rather inanimate; 20 bags Ghezirah sold at about late rates, with sales of Senegal at 125s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER** remains quiet; if anything, the turn easier.

**CAMWOOD.**—About 25 tons at £21 to £27 per ton.

**PALM KERNELS** have been rather quiet, with a fair demand at about late rates.

**LOCUST BEANS.**—242 bags sold at £5 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market opened quietly, but, importers showing more disposition to meet buyers, a considerable business has been done, chiefly for the Continent, on the basis of £18 10s. for hard oils, and Bonny at £19 5s., with Brass at £18 15s., ex quay, Old Calabar at £19 15s. to £19 10s., Lagos at £21 to £21 5s., in transit, Opobo at £19 15s. to £19 5s., New Calabar at £18 10s., and Irregular at £17 5s. to £18 per ton.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 11.**

**SUGAR.**—The market has been quietly steady throughout the week, and a fair amount of business done on the spot at full prices. There is more inquiry for distant arrival, and a considerable business has been concluded, the particulars of which, however, are not allowed to transpire.

**MOLASSES.**—American grocery Treacle meets with slightly more inquiry at late rates.

**RUM.**—No change to notice; 116 puncheons Demerara sold at steady prices.

**COFFEE.**—There is rather a steadier tone in the market, and business is restricted, owing to the firmness of holders. 53 bags African sold at 59s. 3d., 350 bags Ceara at 62s. to 65s., 73 barrels, 5 half-barrels, and 20 bags Jamaica at 64s. to 81s., 160 bags Jacmel at 65s., and 82 frazils Savanilla at 71s. to 76s. per cwt.

**COCOA** remains very quiet.

**SPICES.**—Ginger: 82 robbins Cochin at 37s. to 37s. 6d. per cwt. Pimento: 150 bags at 2¼d. per lb.

**GAMBIER.**—50 tons Block sold at 22s. 9d., and now 22s. 9d. to 23s. is asked on spot; and, to arrive, 100 tons, per steamer, sold at 22s. 6d. to 22s. 7¼d. per cwt., ex quay.

**GUM.**—Egyptian descriptions have been quiet, without change, and the only business to notice is 5½ tons Brazilian on private terms.'}, {'id': 5522, 'article_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS', 'full_section_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1887#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_04_1887', 'content': '**PALM OIL.**—A moderate business has been done at about late rates for hard oils, whilst other descriptions are about 5s. easier. 500 tons sold; Old Calabar at £19, in store, Benin at £18 5s., ex quay, and Brass at £18 2s. 6d., New Calabar at £18, Bonny and Opobo at £19 2s. 6d., Old Calabar at £19 5s. to £19 7s. 6d., and Lagos at £20 15s. to £20 5s. per ton, all in transit, with Irregular at proportionate prices.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 25.**

**SUGAR.**—There has been a moderate demand throughout the week, at fully previous prices, the firmness of holders having checked business. The market, however, closes with a quieter tone.

**MOLASSES.**—No material alteration to notice.

**RUM** continues quiet, but steady, at late rates.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been firm, and a good business concluded at an advance of 9d. to 1s. per cwt. all round. 4 tierces, 256 barrels, &c., Jamaican sold at 49s. to 88s., 232 bags Port-au-Prince at 68s. to 69s., 74 frazils Savanilla at 75s., and, to arrive, 600 bags African at 60s. to 60s. 6d. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—The trade having supplied themselves to a fair extent last week, there has been a pause in the demand, but prices remain quite steady. 75 bags Guayaquil sold at 60s. to 65s., and 75 bags Samana at 58s. per cwt.

**SPICES.**—Ginger: 29 cases of fine-cut Cochin sold at 40s. 6d. to 80s. 6d., and 20 bags of washed at 33s. per cwt. Pimento: 18 bags at 2¼d. per lb.

**CUTCH** is quiet, and about 350 boxes sold at 28s. 6d. to 32s. 6d. per cwt.

**DIVI DIVI.**—A good business done on private terms.

**GAMBIER.**—Small sales of Block at 22s. 6d., ex quay, and 25 tons, March-April shipment, per steamer, at 21s. 7¼d. per cwt.

**GUM.**—The market remains very quiet, with retail sales of Senegal at steady prices, and further sales of Syrian Tragacanth at £10 per cwt. 23 barrels Sierra Leone Copal sold at 3¼d. to 6¾d. per lb., from store, as in quality.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—The market continues firm, though not much business passing.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—5,400 bags at 4s. to 8s. 9d. per cwt.

**PALM KERNELS** dull, without change in value.

**PALM OIL** continues in moderate demand, and 500 tons sold at late rates to 5s. per ton decline, including Benin at £18 5s., transit, and Lagos at £20 5s. to £20, transit, Old Calabar at £18 15s. to £19 5s., and Irregular at £16 12s. 6d. to £17 per ton.

**THE RELIEF OF EMIN BEY.**—A message from Mr. H. M. Stanley has been lately received by Mr. Mackinnon announcing the arrival of the Expedition at the Congo on the 18th of March, the date which had been fixed by Mr. Stanley, the arrangements so far having been carried out exactly according to programme.'}, {'id': 5801, 'article_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS.', 'full_section_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-12', 'issue_date': '04_02_1889', 'content': '**PALM OIL.**—Soft oils are firm, but hard oils have been neglected all week, though at the close there is more doing at easier rates. 900 tons sold, chiefly irregular, at late rates, Benin at £23 15s., Bonny at £24 12s. 6d. to £24 15s., and Lagos at £26 5s. to £26 10s. per ton.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 25.**

**SUGAR.**—There has been a fair demand, more especially for the lower descriptions, which have commanded full prices, but fine qualities are about 3d. to 6d. per cwt. easier.

**RUM** continues firm, and about 230 puncheons Demerara sold.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been very quiet during the week, and the small business reported in export qualities is without material change; the Jamaicas were taken by the trade at full rates. 280 bags African sold at 71s., ex quay, 41 bags Guayaquil at 80s., 150 bags Jacmel at 78s., from the quay, and 2 tierces 161 barrels, &c., Jamaica at 70s. to 115s. per cwt.

**COCOA** quiet, without any material change, and the sales include 175 bags Jeremie at 46s., and 34 bags Guayaquil at 64s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—There has not been much doing in either African or Para, and the market closes with a rather quieter tone.

**MYRABALAMS.**—1,770 bags sold at 4s. 11d. to 10s. 9d. per cwt., as in quality.

**LOGWOOD** is in moderate request at full prices; 80 tons Jamaica sold at £6 12s. 6d. to £6 17s. 6d. per ton.

**FUSTIC** steady, with a limited stock; sales of Vera Cruz at £4 17s. 6d. per ton.

**LIMAWOOD.**—Sales of Tehuantepec at £9 5s.; £10 per ton, the price of Piastla.

**PALM KERNELS.**—A good business done, chiefly on spot, at an advance of about 5s.; 7,150 bags sold at £8 5s. to £11 3s. 9d. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—Only a moderate business done at a decline of 2s. 6d. to 5s. on all descriptions except Lagos, which is about 10s. to 15s. per ton easier. 600 tons sold; hard oils at £23 10s., Old Calabar and Bonny at £24 12s. 6d., Benin and New Calabar at £23 15s., and Lagos at £25 15s. to £26 10s. per ton.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 1.**

**SUGAR.**—The market has been languid throughout the week, but holders have refrained from pressing sales, and only a small amount of business has been done, without material change in prices.

**RUM.**—The market remains steady, and during the week 80 puncheons Demerara have been sold at full prices.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been firm during the week, and closes strong on confirmed news of drought in the Brazils, which it is reported has done serious harm to the growing crops. 800 bags African on the spot, at 70s. 6d. to 70s. 6d., with 160 bags, to arrive, at 70s., tel quel, ex quay, 25 bags Aux Cayes, on the spot, at 78s., and 460 bags Jacmel, on the spot and to arrive, at 79s. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—There has been a little more disposition shown to operate, and a moderate business done at steady prices. 80 bags fermented Bahia sold at 63s., and 320 bags African, inferior at 45s. up to 60s. per cwt. for fine.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'LIVERPOOL MARKETS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**GUM** remains very strong; about 50 serons sold; good Ghezirah at 80s., and Arabic sorts at 112s. to 112s. 6d. per cwt.

**INDIA RUBBER.**—Para dull; African sorts in fair demand at recent quotations.

**EBONY.**—144 tons Gaboon at £7 2s. 6d. to £13 per ton, as quality, ex quay.

**COTTONSEED CAKES.**—620 sacks American at £6 2s. 6d. to £6 7s. 6d. per ton, ex quay.

**PALM KERNELS** continue firm at full rates—viz., £14 to £15 15s. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—388 bags and 4 tons loose at £8 2s. 6d. per ton.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—Sales at 27s. 6d. per cwt.

**PALM OIL.**—Market firm, with moderate business in some instances at slight advance. 500 tons sold; Congo at £36 15s., in transit, Cameroons at £38 10s. to £38 12s. 6d., Bonny at £38 10s. to £38 15s., Old Calabar at £38 15s., and Lagos at £39 15s. to £40, with Irregular at £35 10s. to £37 per ton.

**FEBRUARY 16 TO FEBRUARY 22.**

**RUM** is barely steady, and 162 puncheons Demerara sold at about late rates.

**COFFEE.**—Market quiet, only business of importance is in African, which has been in good demand, but closes quietly at 6d. advance. 69 tierces 48 barrels Jamaica at 41s. to 85s.; 270 bags St. Domingo, old crop Cape Hayti at 49s. to 50s., and new crop Port-au-Prince at 50s.; 470 bags Ceara at 51s. to 52s.; 2,300 bags African at 40s. 6d. to 41s. in store; and 1,870 bags African at 39s. 6d. to 40s. per cwt., tel quel, ex quay.

**GINGER.**—39 bags African at 42s. to 44s. per cwt.

**INDIA RUBBER.**—Para very dull, and nominally lower, but no business done to test prices. African sorts in good demand at prices in buyers' favour.

**CAMWOOD.**—5 tons at £26 per ton, ex quay.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been a moderate business done on the spot at steady prices. 500 tons sold. Congo at £37 2s. 2d. to £37 5s.; Benin and New Calabar at £38 5s.; Bonny at £38 15s.; Old Calabar at £39; Lagos at £40; and Irregular at £36 15s. to £38 10s. per ton.

**FEBRUARY 23 TO FEBRUARY 29.**

**COFFEE.**—Good business done in African at full prices, but other kinds continue to be neglected, and rather easier in price. 2,550 bags African, small berry at 39s., bold berry at 40s. to 41s. in store, 40s. tel quel ex quay.

**COCOA.**—Medium sorts are steady at late prices; 88 bags African at 64s. to 65s., and 30 bags Jerimie at 50s. per cwt.

**GINGER.**—103 bags African at 48s. 6d. per cwt.

**INDIA RUBBER.**—African and sorts selling fairly at prices favouring buyers.

**BENNISEED.**—1,134 bags Niger at 44s. to 48s. 6d. per 384 lbs.

**PALM KERNELS** very firm, with a fair business at £13 10s. to £16 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—Only moderate demand, and the sales reach 400 tons, without material change, Bonny at £38 15s. to £38 10s., Cameroons at £38 10s., Loanda at £38 5s., Old Calabar at £39 to £38 15s., Lagos at £40 to £40 15s., and Irregular at £36 to £36 15s. per ton; but, at the close, prices are the turn in buyers' favour.", 'last_edit_date': '1884-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1884#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, NOV. 4.**

**SUGAR.**—There has been a good demand, and large business done, prices of fine and medium showing an advance of 6d., whilst low sorts may be quoted 3d. per cwt. dearer, and transactions would have been more extensive but for the limited selection offering.

**COFFEE.**—The market for African closes quieter, and late rates are with difficulty obtainable. About 350 bags African, medium at 63s. to 63s. 6d., in store, bold (at auction) at 63s. 9d. to 64s. 3d., ex quay, and elephant berry at 78s. to 82s. per cwt.

**CHILLIES.**—70 bags of Sierra Leone have been sold at 45s. per cwt., ex quay.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—20 bags at 1¾d. per lb.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—There has been a fair amount of business done in fine Para, of recent import, during the week at again rather easier prices, closing with sellers at 2s. 9¾d., being a decline of ¼d.; scrappy negroheads are firmly held for 2s. 2d., and Island negroheads for 1s. 10½d. per lb. There has been a good business done in African during the past week at prices showing a decline of ¼d. to ½d. per lb. The sales, which amount to about 60 or 70 tons, include thimbles at 1s. 6½d., Loango ball 1s. 6¾d., Cameroon ball 1s. 6d., Old Calabar 1s. 4¾d., Manoh twists 1s. 10d., Sierra Leone niggers 1s. 6d., Accra and Cape Coast biscuits 1s. 8d. to 1s. 9d., Grand Bassam 1s. 2½d. to 1s. 4¾d., and soft Cape Coast at 1s. 2¼d. per lb.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—About 1,500 bags sold at 5s. 3d. to 8s. 6d. per cwt., as in quality.

**EBONY.**—About 30 tons Old Calabar at £6 2s. 6d. per ton, ex quay, being steady prices.

**BENNISEED.**—1,540 bags Akassa at 40s. per 384 lbs., ex quay.

**PALM KERNELS.**—350 bags Cameroon at £10 17s. 6d. per ton.

**GROUND NUTS.**—100 bags common undecorticated Bathurst at £11, and 270 bags fine at £14 per ton, ex quay.

**COPRA.**—Small sales of African at £11 10s. per ton.

**PIASSAVA.**—About 2,000 bundles of African sold at £25 10s. to £27 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market continues steady, with a limited quantity offering on spot and near at hand, and values in these positions are again about 5s. dearer on the week; distant arrivals quiet and unchanged. The sales include Benin, Cameroon, and New Calabar at £20 10s., Accra-Addah at £20 10s. to £20 15s., Bonny at £20 15s., and Lagos at £23 5s. per ton, all in transit.

---

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, NOV. 11.**

**SUGAR.**—Fair inquiry, but only a moderate amount of business reported at full prices, and transactions would have been more extensive but for the limited quantity offering.

**COFFEE.**—The market is only poorly supplied, and the moderate sales reported are at about steady prices. 67 barrels Jamaica at 85s. to 127s., and 112 bags African, on spot, at 57s. for low, 63s. 6d. for medium, in store, and 80s. for elephant, ex quay, with 350 bags bold berry, to arrive, at 63s. 6d. per cwt., tel quel, in transit.

**CALABAR BEANS.**—23 bags at 1¾d. per lb.

**GUINEA GRAINS.**—18 bags at 22s. 6d. per cwt.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1892#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LIVERPOOL MARKETS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**LIVERPOOL MARKETS.**

**COFFEE.**—African, 235 bags, at 38s. 6d.  
**CAMWOOD.**—Small parcel, 29l. 10s. per ton.  
**BENNI SEED.**—522 bags at 47s. to 47s. 6d. per 384 lbs.  
**PALM KERNELS.**—3,440 bags at 12l. to 15l. 7s. 6d. per ton.  
**PALM OIL.**—In the absence of supplies on the spot, the business has been chiefly to arrive, at extreme prices. 500 tons sold; Congo at 35l. 12s. 6d., Niger at 36l. 5s., New Calabar at 36l. 5s. to 36l. 12s. 6d., Benin at 36l. 12s. 6d., Old Calabar at 37l. to 37l. 10s., Lagos at 40l., and Irregular at 34l. to 36l. 10s. per ton.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-04-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_04_1883#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'SUGAR.—The market has been without animation, and only a moderate amount of business is reported, generally without change in value, excepting Java, for which an easier price has been accepted.

MOLASSES.—American Treacle remains steady.

RUM.—Considerably more business has been done at steady rates, and 570 puncheons Demerara sold.

COFFEE.—The market has been quiet, without change in prices. 22 bags of Liberian sold at 80s. per cwt., with small sales of African, to arrive, at the same price. The Dutch sale, on Tuesday, passed off irregularly from ¾ cent to 1¼ cents under valuations, averaging ¾ cent below.

COCOA continues very quiet, with only retail sales at late rates.

GUM.—The business is rather limited, owing to the small supply offering, and includes Amrad at 92s., 9 barrels African Copal at 36s. per cwt., and 36 barrels Sierra Leone at 4d. to 7¾d. per lb.

INDIA-RUBBER.—Market for Para kinds continues very slow, and quotations nominal; rather more doing in African kinds at slightly easier prices.

MYRABOLAMS.—430 bags at 8s. 6d. per cwt.

CAMWOOD.—25 tons of Grand Bassa at £16 10s. to £22 5s. per ton.

PALM KERNELS.—200 tons sold at £8 7s. 6d. to £10 5s. per ton.

PALM OIL.—The market has been very quiet, with only a retail business passing at easier prices, including Lagos at £20 to £20 5s., and Accra at £18, both transit, and Irregular at £16 15s. per ton.

LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23.

SUGAR.—A dull tone has prevailed throughout the week, the transactions have only been to a limited extent, prices at the close showing a reduction of fully 3d. on fine qualities, whilst low kinds are 1½d. per cwt. easier.

MOLASSES.—American Treacle remains very steady.

RUM.—Further sales of Demerara descriptions have been made at previous prices; 150 puncheons sold.

COFFEE.—Qualities suitable for the trade continue in good demand at full prices; other kinds quiet, without material change. 112 bags African sold at 80s., 28 bags Liberian at 80s. 6d. to 84s., 1 tierce 61 packages Jamaica at 88s. to 140s., and, to arrive, 100 bags African at 80s. per cwt., tel quel, ex quay.

COCOA.—The lower prices accepted have induced the trade to operate, and a good business has been done, the sales including 1,600 bags fermented Bahia at 66s., and 90 bags Semana at 60s. per cwt.

GINGER.—50 bags of African sold at 20s. per cwt.

GUM.—All descriptions continue to be firmly held, and the actual transactions are only retail at steady prices.

INDIA-RUBBER.—The market for Para kinds continues dull, but there is a better demand for the lower African sorts.

MYRABOLAMS.—Only small sales at 6s. 3d. per cwt.

PALM KERNELS.—79 tons and 4,895 bags sold at £8 to £10 2s. 6d. per ton.

PALM OIL.—We have experienced a quiet market all week, with a fair business passing at slightly easier prices; Lagos, £19 5s., quay, £19 10s. to £20, transit; Benin, £18, transit; New Calabar, £17 15s. to £18; Accra and Addah, £17 15s.; and Irregular, £16 to £16 5s. per ton, transit.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1887#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**PALM OIL.**—There has been a good business done during the week at steady rates. About 800 tons sold; Bonny at £18 15s. and Lagos at £19 10s. to £19 15s., both ex quay, and Accra Addah at £17 15s., Bonny and Old Calabar at £18 12s. 6d., Cameroons at £18 10s. to £18 12s. 6d., and Lagos at £19 17s. 6d. to £20, all in transit, with Irregular at £16 17s. 6d. per ton.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 20.**

**SUGAR.**—The market has been depressed, and, to effect sales from the quay, a further decline of 6d. to 9d. per cwt. has been submitted to.

**MOLASSES.**—American Treacle without change.

**RUM** firm, and about 100 puncheons Demerara sold at full prices.

**COFFEE** continues very quiet, and the only business reported is in African, which shows a decline of 1s. to 1s. 6d. per cwt.

**COCOA.**—A little more doing, without any alteration to notice in value; 150 bags African sold at 56s., 220 bags fermented Bahia at 66s., and 186 bags common red at 58s., 120 bags Cape Haytian at 55s., and small sales of Caraccas at 77s. per cwt.

**CUTCH.**—200 boxes reported at 32s. to 32s. 3d. per cwt.

**GAMBIER.**—Small sales of Block at 23s., on spot and in dock, ex quay, and 75 tons, to arrive, per St. Dunstan, at 23s. per cwt., with further sellers thereat.

**GUM.**—Business in better kinds continues rather retail, small lots of Arabic Sorts selling at 300s., and 5 cases Turkish Tragacanth at £10 10s. In the lower descriptions, Brazil is attracting considerably more attention, and fair sales made at 55s. to 60s. per cwt., according to quality.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Market has been very dull for Para kinds. A moderate business in African at steady prices. Ceara kinds neglected.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—1,250 bags at 3s. 9d. to 5s. 3d. per cwt., part ex quay, the former price for common.

**PALM KERNELS** remain firm, whilst parcels for arrival sell readily at full prices; 5,442 bags sold at £8 7s. 6d. to £10 11s. 3d. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—There is a strong market, with an active demand at prices showing an advance of from 15s. to 20s. per ton. 1,000 tons sold; Benin at £18 10s., and Lagos at £19 15s. to £20 5s. both ex quay, and Irregular at £16 5s., Salt Pond at £16 10s., Accra Addah at £18 5s., New Calabar at £18 7s. 6d. to £18 10s., Benin at £19 5s., Old Calabar at £19 10s. to £20, Cameroons at £19 10s., Bonny at £19 10s. to £19 15s., and Lagos at £20 5s. to £20 10s. per ton, all in transit.

**LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JANUARY 27.**

**SUGAR.**—The market opened dull, and prices further gave way, which, towards the close, induced a better demand, chiefly on speculation, and a good business has been done at prices not obtainable during the early part of the week.

**MOLASSES.**—American Treacle continues quiet.

**RUM** remains firm, and 40 puncheons Demerara have been sold at full prices.

**COFFEE** has been dull and depressed, and the sales made are at prices again in buyers' favour; 1,735 bags African sold at 68s. to 69s., and 55 bags Bahia at 70s. per cwt.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1888#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Decade of the Trade of Hamburg with West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Consul-General points out that the trade in palm kernels, which has hitherto been accepted as the basis of the West Coast import trade of Hamburg, only came into existence in the decade of 1860-70, and that india-rubber, now the main article of import, was of a much later date, and he infers that Africa, which has barely been tapped, may yet yield a trade "beyond the dreams of the most enterprising." The trade so far is confined to the districts adjoining certain parts of the coast; and mainly to such products as grow naturally, but the increasing imports of coffee, cocoa and tobacco show what may be obtained if planting becomes more general.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN PRODUCTS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Thirty tons of clean cotton! Four hundred and twenty-five bags of coffee! We noticed briefly last month the receipt of the above from West Africa—the former in various shipments from the Gold Coast, the latter by one ship, from one purely native port. Small as these quantities are—insignificant indeed as they are when compared with the wants and demands of civilized Europe—they are nevertheless calculated to afford encouragement to those who, with ourselves, look to the spread of civilization in Africa by means of an increased production of these articles.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**GUM.**—There is rather more disposition to meet buyers of quantity; cheap qualities are inquired for, but no supplies are available. Small sales of Brazilian and Egyptian Amrad reported on private terms.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—A fractional decline in the value of Para has caused more demand for the article, and about 85 tons sold at 2s. 8¾d. to 2s. 8¾d. per lb. for fine. Only a small business done in African at late rates.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—200 bags sold at 4s. to 11s. 3d. per cwt.

**LOGWOOD** is in steady demand at late rates.

**CAMWOOD.**—Sales of Grand Bassa at £14 10s. per ton.

**PALM KERNELS** steady; 2,967 bags sold at £7 2s. 6d. to £10 per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—The market opened flat, but sellers having met buyers freely, a large business has been done, about 2,000 tons; soft oils at £19 to £19 10s., Lagos at £21 to £21 5s., New Calabar at £18 5s. to £18 10s., Benin at £18 to £18 10s., hard oils at £18 to £18 5s. per ton, and Irregular at proportionate prices, the market closing with a firmer tone.

#### LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 22.

**SUGAR.**—There has been an active demand throughout the week, both on the spot and for arrival, and a large business concluded at prices showing an advance of fully 3d. per cwt.

**COFFEE.**—The market has ruled very quiet, and, to effect sales, easier prices would have to be accepted. 92 bags African, Elephant berry, sold at 81s., 200 bags Aux Cayes at 82s. 6d. to 83s., and 150 bags Jacmel at 85s. per cwt.

---

**COCOA.**—The market is quiet, with little disposition to operate, the only sales reported being 20 bags African at 57s. 6d. to 59s., with small sales of Para at 63s. per cwt., ex quay.

**CHILLIES.**—100 bags African at 25s. 6d. to 26s. 6d. per cwt.

**GUM.**—The business continues very limited, and the sales are chiefly confined to Brazilian at 40s. to 72s. 6d., as in quality, with 60 bags Lagos Copal at 22s. 6d. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—Para is quiet, and prices slightly in buyers' favour.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—500 bags at 7s. 9d. per cwt.

**BENNISEED.**—100 bags at 37s. per 384 lbs.

**PALM KERNELS** steady; 3,600 bags sold at £9 7s. 6d. to £10 1s. 8d. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—There has been a good demand, and, with only a moderate supply offering, an advance of 5s. to 10s. has been obtained. 1,100 tons sold; Benin at £19, soft oils at £19 10s. to £19 15s., Old Calabar and Bonny at £19 15s. to £20, Cameroon at £19 12s. 6d., and Lagos at £22 5s. with Irregular at £17 12s. 6d. to £18 per ton.

#### LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 29.

**SUGAR.**—There has been a strong market throughout the week, and a large business done, both on the spot and to arrive, at prices showing an advance of 6d. to 9d. per cwt.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been very quiet during the week, and the small business done shows a decline of 6d. to 1s. per cwt. 100 bags African sold at 75s. 6d., ex quay, 51 barrels and bags Jamaica at 84s. to 92s., and 190 bags Aux Cayes at 82s. 6d. to 83s. per cwt.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1889#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PRODUCE MARKETS', 'section_title': '', 'content': "LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MAY 4.

SUGAR.—Medium qualities have met with a good demand, and realized 3d. advance, whilst other descriptions have only been in moderate request, without change in value.

MOLASSES, &c.—American Treacle continues steady, with a moderate business passing.

RUM.—There is no change to report in the market during the week.

COFFEE.—Considering the firmness of the terminal markets, the spot demand has been disappointing, with the exception of Jamaica at auction, which went off readily at full rates. Small sales of African small berry at 54s., 150 bags Ceara at 58s., and 6 tierces, 278 barrels, 20 half-barrels Jamaica at 60s. to 98s. per cwt.

COCOA in moderate request at about late rates, excepting low kinds, which are rather easier; 569 bags of Jeremie sold at 46s., and about 40 bags of African at 59s. to 62s. per cwt.

COCHINEAL.—Small sales of rosy black at 11d. to 1s. per lb.

DIVI DIVI.—500 bags at £12 5s. to £12 15s. per ton.

GUM.—Holders of Brazil have advanced their prices, and business therefore is rather limited; there are inquiries for other descriptions, but the only sale reported is in Amrad at 85s. per cwt. 10 barrels African Copal sold at 8¾d. per lb., in store.

HONEY.—Some business passing in Chilian and Californian at steady prices, and higher rates are now asked for the better qualities of the latter.

INDIA-RUBBER.—Para: Market dull. Ceara and Peruvian quite neglected. African in moderate demand at slightly easier prices.

MYRABOLAMS.—1,350 bags and 360 tons sold at 4s. to 9s. 6d. per cwt.

EBONY.—42 tons sold; Old Calabar at £4 5s. to £4 17s. 6d., Gaboon at £5 to £5 5s., as in quality, and Victoria at £5 15s. per ton.

PALM KERNELS are in fair demand at steady prices.

PALM OIL.—There is a steady market, with only a limited quantity offering, which has been sufficient for the demand, and the sales, about 500 tons, include Benin at £17 10s. to £17 15s., Cameroons at £18 5s., Bonny at £18 5s. to £18 10s., and Lagos at £18 15s. to £19 5s. per ton.

LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MAY 11.

SUGAR.—The market has been very quiet, refiners having shown little disposition to operate, and prices close 3d. to 6d. per cwt. easier.

RUM steady, and the business restricted to 140 puncheons Demerara at previous prices.

COFFEE.—The market has been slow all week, but, at the close, there is rather more inquiry. 29 bags African, Elephant berry, sold at 65s. per cwt. The stock of available Coffee is but limited and well held. The world's visible supply on May 1 was 161,336 tons, against 179,796 tons on April 1, a decrease of 18,460 tons on the month. Last year's visible supply on May 1 was 227,788 tons, so this year's shows a shortage of 66,452 tons.

COCOA in limited request, without change in value, and 34 bags African sold at 63s., and 300 bags St. Domingo, Jeremie at 46s., with Port-au-Prince at 47s. per cwt.

GINGER.—130 bags uncut Cochin at 23s. to 25s., and 177 bags African at 17s. to 19s. 3d. per cwt.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL INTERESTS IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "commerce if carried by steamers. The demand for kola nuts was reported to be at all times considerable in Brazil, but in view of the slowness of the passage and the difficulty of keeping them in marketable condition, the value has at no time during the past six years exceeded £3,563, while in 1877 it sank as low as £304. Shea butter also, though exported to the value of £161 in 1883, sank in 1887 to £29. Among the imports from Brazil, the most important seem to be rum, cigars, and tobacco. The depressed state of trade in 1887 affected the branches of commerce upon which the colony depended; indeed, irregularity of communication has in the past given this trade a peculiarly unstable character. Placed on a firm basis, however, there would seem to be excellent prospects of a rapid development in the imports above mentioned, especially when it is considered that the market for imports from Brazil is already established in the colony of Lagos. These facts showed that it was worth while to consider the advisability of embarking upon this enterprise, and he took advantage of this opportunity to publish the facts he had put before them, which bore upon the subject, sincerely trusting that so important an opening for British trade would not be neglected. Another inducement for the establishment of steam communication between Brazil and West Africa was that the value of our possessions, in their work of development, must depend on their trade, which meant an open and settled interior. Cut them off from the interior, and they were cramped as regarded progress, and were occupied in struggling to meet the bare cost of administration; connect them with the interior and their future would be great and far-reaching. It had been questioned why West Africa had not made more progress in the march of civilisation. In the words of Sir Thomas Fowell Buxton it was slavery that debarred them from acquiring industries; it was slavery which prevented them from exercising the virtues of foresight and prudence; it was slavery which left them nothing to care for; it was slavery that took away from them all the incentives to industrious labour, and debarred them from all the ties of social intercourse. When we remember the small percentage of people that represents owners, we had to acknowledge that these causes still opposed development. Time alone would rehabilitate the negro in his manliness. Obstacles that blocked progress were the altered relationship between owner and former slave, the independence of the latter when compared with his former grovelling position, doubt of result or use of independence secured with abolition, doubt in minds of native authorities of consequence of any action they might initiate, non-existence of free labour markets, and inter-tribal differences, jealousies and feuds. The removal of such blocks had been and was the aim of the Government, and they were gradually disappearing. In primitive countries such as within and adjoining our West African colonies, it was the duty of the Government to initiate the capabilities of the country represented by its products. The people were industrious in their own fashion, and were ready to follow examples set, and to develop industries once they learn to appreciate their value. We wanted new staples of trade and larger areas of demand for our wares. Agricultural products must long continue the most important part of the exports from tropical Africa, and the future development of Africa's commerce would depend upon the improvement in the quantity and quality of existing agricultural staples, and on the introduction of new products, which should serve as materials for manufacture and for use in industrial arts.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.649, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The actual value of imports into the Oil Rivers is not easily ascertained. For a period of three years ending 1889 they were estimated to have been £730,000 per annum, but prices have since advanced and the volume of business has considerably increased. The value of exports from the Oil Rivers in 1890 is estimated at considerably over £1,300,000, after adding freight and charges. For four months of the year prices ranged a little over the average, and they promise so far to be fully as high in 1891. The following details as to the principal exports may be of interest. Palm oil has long been the staple export of this part of Africa. According to Porter (“Progress of the Nation”) the import into the United Kingdom in 1808 was 200 tons; 1836, 13,850 tons; 1844, 20,732 tons. It is now (1890) 43,696 tons. These figures, however, are for the United Kingdom only. Formerly the whole went to the British Isles, but now some 8,000 to 10,000 tons annually go to Marseilles, Havre, and Antwerp direct from the Oil Rivers. Of the United Kingdom import, only about 25,000 tons were actually from the Oil Rivers, the balance being from the Niger and Congo, Cameroons, Lagos, and other West African Ports. Palm kernels are rapidly increasing in importance. About 20,000 tons annually go from the rivers to Continental ports alone, and about the same quantity to the United Kingdom. The growing importance of the trade is shown by the fact that the Oil Rivers kernel imports into the United Kingdom only commenced about the year 1860, and in most of the rivers no kernels at all had been shipped before 1875.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, MARCH 7.**

**SUGAR.**—A steady demand has been experienced, and a fair amount of business done in refining as well as export descriptions, prices showing an advance of fully 3d. per cwt. on the week.

**RUM.**—A fair amount of business doing at slightly easier rates, and 220 puncheons Demerara sold.

**COFFEE.**—The market has been very firm, but business is restricted, owing to the small quantity available; sales at the close show an advance of 1s. to 1s. 6d. per cwt. 88 packages Jamaica at 85s. to 109s.; 505 bags Hayti, Jacmel at 90s. to 92s., the former price ex quay, with a small lot of fine hand-picked, for the home trade, at 97s., and Aux Cayes at 88s. to 89s. 6d.; and, to arrive, 100 bags African at 78s. 6d. per cwt., tel quel, ex quay.

**GUM.**—A very fair business done, and the sales include Niger Arabic at 75s., and about 500 bags Brazilian (during last fortnight), at steady prices, with 15 packages African Copal, Lagos at 28s. to 33s., the latter price for selected, and Accra at 34s. per cwt.

**INDIA-RUBBER.**—About 17½ tons African, part of 35 tons offered, sold yesterday at auction at 1s. 6d. to 2s. 1d. per lb., being a further advance for most descriptions, whilst a fair business is doing privately at full prices. Business in Para only to a moderate extent during the week at prices favoring sellers up to 3s. 3½d. per lb. for fine quality.

**LOGWOOD.**—Is in steady demand, and prices have a rather hardening tendency. Sales of Jamaica and root at £5 10s. to £6 10s. per ton.

**FUSTIC** is in limited supply, and sales made at full rates.

**PALM KERNELS** have been in fair demand during the week, and prices are from 2s. 6d. to 5s. in sellers' favour; 2,455 bags reported at £9 to £10 15s. per ton.

**PALM OIL.**—Only a limited inquiry has been experienced, and about 500 tons sold at prices in buyers' favour; Accra at £20 15s., Benin at £20 15s. to £21, soft oils at £21 5s. to £21, and Lagos at £22 12s. 6d. to £22 10s. per ton, all transit.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-03-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**Gum.**—There is some inquiry for different descriptions, and the sales include 60 packages Amrad and Brazilian at 40s. to 66s., sales of Ghezirah Siftings at 73s. to 80s., and 35 packages Brazilian Copal at full prices.

**India-rubber.**—Market very quiet, but Para holders are firm. Ceara and Peruvian still neglected. African only in very retail demand.

**Myrabolams.**—1,465 bags at 3s. to 7s. 6d. per cwt., as in quality.

**Logwood** meets with rather more inquiry.

**Camwood.**—Sales of Grand Bassa at £11 5s. to £15 10s. per ton, as in quality.

**Palm Kernels** have been irregular, low and medium qualities being 5s. to 10s., and fine descriptions about 5s. cheaper on the week; 7,070 bags sold at £7 10s. to £9 12s. 6d. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—There has been a good demand during the week, and all regular oil offering at current rates cleared, with buyers over at the close, whilst sellers are asking, and in some instances refusing, 5s. per ton advance. The sales will reach nearly 1,500 tons, including Operta at £17 10s., Bonny and Old Calabar at £17 5s. to £17 10s., Benin at £16 7s. 6d. to £16 15s., Brass and New Calabar at £16 5s. to £16 15s., and Lagos at £18 to £18 10s. per ton, with Irregular and others at proportionate prices.

**LIVERPOOL, Friday, June 29.**

**Sugar.**—Fine descriptions have been in good request, and realized rather higher prices; medium qualities are unchanged, but low kinds continue difficult of sale at slightly easier rates.

**Molasses, &c.**—American Treacle steady.

**Rum** has been quiet, and 70 puncheons of Demerara sold at late rates.

**Coffee.**—There has been rather more disposition on the part of buyers to operate, but at prices below the views of holders, and the business is restricted to 40 barrels Jamaica at 67s. to 84s., and 100 bags African at 52s. per cwt., in store.

**Gum.**—Brazil continues in request, and a fair business is doing at previous rates; small sales of common Amrad at low prices, and 21 barrels Sierra Leone Copal at 44d. per lb.

**India-rubber.**—Small sales of fine Para during the week at 3s. Ceara and Peruvian continue in disfavour, and African only meets a very limited demand.

**Myrabolams.**—2,030 bags at 6s. 6d. to 7s. 9d. per cwt.

**Logwood** is steady, with a fair demand.

**Palm Kernels.**—2,311 bags at £7 10s. to £9 5s. per ton.

**Ground Nuts.**—155 bags hand-picked, in the shell, at £15 to £15 2s. 6d. per ton.

**Palm Oil.**—The demand has been good; the sales during the week will not be far short of 2,000 tons, and, arrivals being inadequate, a large business was concluded at the close yesterday at fully 10s. per ton advance. The transactions include hard regular oils at £16 5s. to £16 15s., Benin at £16 12s. 6d. to £17 5s., soft oils at £17 10s. to £17 15s., and Lagos at £18 5s. to £19 per ton, with Irregular at proportionate prices.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1888#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: In the 19th century, West African regions and ports like Lagos, Bonny, Old Calabar, and Accra were key centers of commerce and trade, playing significant roles in regional cooperation and the global trade network, as evidenced by their frequent mention in trade reports and commercial directories.
result: In the 19th century, West African regions and ports such as Lagos, Bonny, Old Calabar, and Accra played pivotal roles in commerce and trade, significantly contributing to regional and global trade networks. The General History of Africa textbook underscores the importance of these ports, highlighting Lagos as a key coastal town that evolved into a political capital and port due to European interest and the shift from the slave trade to legitimate trade. Bonny is noted for its involvement in the slave trade and later in the palm oil trade, a major export following the abolition of slavery. Old Calabar is recognized for the Efik's role as middlemen in the slave trade, further emphasizing its commercial significance. However, the textbook does not specifically mention Accra, which contrasts with the claim. In contrast, The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence of these ports' prominence, frequently mentioning them in trade reports and detailing the commodities traded, such as palm oil, palm kernels, and cotton, along with specific prices and quantities. These articles highlight the active commercial activities and the involvement of European merchants, particularly from Liverpool, underscoring the global connections of these ports. While the articles align with the claim regarding the ports' commercial significance, they do not explicitly address regional cooperation, focusing instead on trade dynamics and economic activities. Together, these sources corroborate the claim about the commercial importance of West African ports in the 19th century, despite some differences in emphasis and specific mentions.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that support the claim regarding the significance of West African regions and ports like Lagos, Bonny, and Old Calabar in the 19th-century trade network. The text highlights Lagos as a key coastal town that took on new responsibilities as a political capital and port due to European interest and the transition from the slave trade to legitimate trade. Bonny is mentioned as a port where Igbo slaves were sold, indicating its role in the slave trade, and later in the palm oil trade, which was a major export product after the abolition of the slave trade. Old Calabar is noted as a location where the Efik served as middlemen in the slave trade, further emphasizing its commercial importance. However, Accra is not specifically mentioned in the provided paragraphs, which is a notable difference from the claim. Overall, the text supports the claim by illustrating the involvement of these ports in regional and global trade, although it does not provide specific references to Accra or frequent mentions in trade reports and commercial directories.
tat: The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that West African regions and ports like Lagos, Bonny, Old Calabar, and Accra were key centers of commerce and trade in the 19th century. These locations are frequently mentioned in trade reports, indicating their significant roles in the global trade network. The articles detail various commodities traded, such as palm oil, palm kernels, cotton, and other goods, with specific prices and quantities listed for each port. This highlights the active commercial activities and the importance of these ports in regional and international trade. Additionally, the articles mention the involvement of European merchants, particularly from Liverpool, in trading activities, further emphasizing the global connections of these West African ports. The frequent mention of these locations in commercial directories and trade reports aligns with the claim, showcasing their prominence in the trade network of the time. However, the articles do not explicitly discuss regional cooperation, focusing more on the trade dynamics and economic activities. This absence of information on regional cooperation is a notable difference from the claim. Overall, the articles corroborate the claim regarding the commercial significance of these West African ports in the 19th century.
topic2: Global Economic Integration of African economies
