[{'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'But whether these extreme results be induced by the late defeat or not, Abeokuta will feel a security on the side of Dahomey to which she has been hitherto a stranger. All that she now requires for a great prosperity—for an indefinite extension of her palm-oil and cotton culture—is to make peace with the Ibadan and their allies. She may then safely extend her farms and plantations far beyond the limits within which, as a matter of precaution, they have hitherto been confined. We earnestly hope that the visit of Governor Freeman, of Lagos, to Abeokuta, will lead to the complete restoration of tranquillity to the Egba and Yoruba countries, and of the amicable relations which ought to exist between Abeokuta and Lagos, and which are indispensable to the prosperity of both places. 1864 bids fair to become a year memorable in the annals of Western Africa for events conducing to the spread of civilization in her long-suffering countries.

BANKING AT SIERRA LEONE.

We were enabled last month briefly to announce that the Company of African Merchants were about to commence banking operations at Sierra Leone, under the auspices of the authorities and at the solicitation of some of the most influential persons there. It has been long felt that banking operations had become necessary on the West Coast; while at the same time there was not a field large and rich enough to justify the establishment of a banking company for such operations alone. But for the formation of a powerful company such as that of "The African Merchants," the want, therefore, must have remained unsatisfied; and an important stimulus to industrial development being absent, the progress of industry on the West Coast would have had still to struggle on with all the difficulties to which it has hitherto been subject. The large capital of this company offers an ample guarantee for its banking transactions, while the fact that it is not dependent on them alone for profits for its shareholders, will enable it to offer greater advantages to its customers than any mere bank could have given.'}, {'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'To say that we rejoice at this new boon to Africa would but feebly represent our satisfaction. As we behold one after another our hopes and projects for the industrial development, and consequent advancement of civilization in Western Africa, realised, we gain new strength for the difficult, arduous, and too frequently ungrateful task that we have undertaken. Sierra Leone claims for so many reasons a large share of our anxiety, that we congratulate her in especial on this new element of prosperity within her borders. In any undertaking of this kind on the West Coast, she was clearly pointed out by position and circumstances as the great centre and focus in and from which all the monetary transactions of the West Coast with England and America should radiate and converge. The selection of Sierra Leone, therefore, in preference to any other point, must have been a necessary decision of the Board of Directors, and not a matter of favour to the colony. Nevertheless, we congratulate the latter on this desirable addition to its mercantile facilities and importance, and hope that the advantages to be derived from the bank will

be so felt by the general population, that this necessity of every small town in Great Britain will in Sierra Leone be universally acknowledged also. The risks of fire and of robbers to which coin in private receptacles is exposed has conduced to the prosperity of banks of deposit everywhere; and we know of no part of the world where the inducement to seek the accommodation and security of a bank against such casualties can be greater than on the West Coast of Africa.

LAGOS.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Lagos, April 9, 1864.

Sir,—The most important intelligence from here this month is the recent attack on Abeokuta by the King of Dahomey, and his complete defeat. Early on March 15, the field piece at Aro gate gave the alarm to Abeokuta; and at about seven a.m. the Dahomans attacked. The battle appears to have lasted until about eleven in the morning, but the Dahoman attack was weak and badly supported. The Dahomans were soon put to the rout, abandoning everything in their retreat, the King himself narrowly escaping capture. The Egbas pursued beyond Ishagga, killing many and making a great number of prisoners. The Dahoman loss in killed, wounded, and prisoners is said to amount to four thousand, which statement is probably not exaggerated. The Egbas only acknowledge a loss of fifty killed and double that number wounded; this is probably very far under the mark, but so far as I can learn they lost no man of note.'}, {'id': 354, 'article_title': 'Banking at Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Banking at Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-19', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'We were enabled last month briefly to announce that the Company of African Merchants were about to commence banking operations at Sierra Leone, under the auspices of the authorities and at the solicitation of some of the most influential persons there. It has been long felt that banking operations had become necessary on the West Coast; while at the same time there was not a field large and rich enough to justify the establishment of a banking company for such operations alone. But for the formation of a powerful company such as that of "The African Merchants," the want, therefore, must have remained unsatisfied; and an important stimulus to industrial development being absent, the progress of industry on the West Coast would have had still to struggle on with all the difficulties to which it has hitherto been subject. The large capital of this company offers an ample guarantee for its banking transactions, while the fact that it is not dependent on them alone for profits for its shareholders, will enable it to offer greater advantages to its customers than any mere bank could have given.

To say that we rejoice at this new boon to Africa would but feebly represent our satisfaction. As we behold one after another our hopes and projects for the industrial development, and consequent advancement of civilization in Western Africa, realised, we gain new strength for the difficult, arduous, and too frequently ungrateful task that we have undertaken. Sierra Leone claims for so many reasons a large share of our anxiety, that we congratulate her in especial on this new element of prosperity within her borders. In any undertaking of this kind on the West Coast, she was clearly pointed out by position and circumstances as the great centre and focus in and from which all the monetary transactions of the West Coast with England and America should radiate and converge. The selection of Sierra Leone, therefore, in preference to any other point, must have been a necessary decision of the Board of Directors, and not a matter of favour to the colony. Nevertheless, we congratulate the latter on this desirable addition to its mercantile facilities and importance, and hope that the advantages to be derived from the bank will

be so felt by the general population, that this necessity of every small town in Great Britain will in Sierra Leone be universally acknowledged also. The risks of fire and of robbers to which coin in private receptacles is exposed has conduced to the prosperity of banks of deposit everywhere; and we know of no part of the world where the inducement to seek the accommodation and security of a bank against such casualties can be greater than on the West Coast of Africa.'}, {'id': 4740, 'article_title': 'Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_12_1883', 'content': 'Death, the common enemy of man, has snatched from our midst one who had reached the acme of fame and fortune by dint of that indomitable perseverance, energy, and fortitude by which men have always risen from the ranks to the highest position in the circle of their profession. Prince Surgeon-Major Horton, of the "Commercial Bank of West Africa," is no more. Alas! "what dying worms are we!" He quickly passed away at about 9 o'clock p.m., of Oct. 15, after a short illness of about eight days, in the 49th year of his age. Truly, "in the midst of life we are in death"!

In his death Sierra Leone has lost another of its great men—a class not so common amongst us that we can afford to be indifferent to those we have or are losing. He would be a rash prophet indeed who will undertake to say when Providence will again vouchsafe us such men as the late M. P. Horton, W. Grant, J. Quaker, and Prince Horton, and their compeers of active, pushing, and aspiring talent and genius. The interest he recently manifested in the welfare of the Church Native Pastorate, his recent election on the Church Council, and the position he held as Treasurer of the Institute, and the warm interest he displayed in going about to collect for the Church Endowment Fund, are indications that he was not wholly engaged in the things of time and sense, but that whilst "not slothful in business, he was diligent in spirit, serving the Lord."

Dr. Horton was one of the only two Africans that have the privilege of holding Her Majesty's commission to serve on the Army Medical Staff, and by their exemplary conduct and capacity for the position they hold, have demonstrated the capacity of the Negro to hold any important position. After a successful career of twenty-four years in the Army, he retired on a well-earned pension, with the rank of Surgeon-Major. His recent efforts to establish a Bank at Sierra Leone, though of yesterday, and yet in its infancy, had begun to make steady progress and to become appreciated, though the establishment is scarcely a year old.

Dr. Horton's work on "Political Economy for Western Africa" and his other work on the medical aspect of diseases peculiar to the African climate, are matters of history, and require no brushing up at our hands. Viewed from many standpoints, his death is an irreparable loss, and more so to his widow and two daughters, and a large circle of friends and acquaintances. We truly sympathize with his bereaved family, and hope his end was peace.'}, {'id': 5340, 'article_title': 'An Indian Journalist upon the Congo Free State', 'full_section_title': 'An Indian Journalist upon the Congo Free State', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1886#article-18', 'issue_date': '01_03_1886', 'content': 'be seldom criticised impartially. Some persons pronounce him the most extraordinary man of his time, others an American empiric and the modern Ananias. Probably the happy medium is the truth here as in most other matters, and Mr. Stanley may well rest satisfied if the world and future historians give him his meed of praise as a great traveller and explorer without accepting him in his would-be *rôles* of state organizer, railway constructor, and pioneer of commerce and trade in Africa. The Congo basin is probably no more fertile than many other parts of Africa, and the labour question is as important and difficult a factor there as in the other portions of the Dark Continent. A hotel is being erected at Banana. It may pay eventually, but at present I cannot see any possibility of its proving a financial success. The telegraph cable is to be extended here during the coming year, when the Congo will be in direct communication with all parts of the civilized world.'}]

[{'document_title': 'Bank of West Africa Ordinance', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the thirty-fifth year of the reign of Her Majesty Queen Victoria. John Pope Hennessy, Administrator of the Government of the West African Settlements. March, 1872.

At a Legislative Council held on the day of March, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and seventy-two.

An Ordinance for the Incorporation of the Bank of West Africa.

Whereas the several persons hereinafter named and others have agreed to form a Joint Stock Company, under the name or style of "The Bank of West Africa," for the purpose of carrying on the business of banking and for conducting all business usually transacted by bankers.

And whereas for the purpose of establishing and carrying on the said undertaking, they have agreed that a capital of two hundred thousand pounds, divided into twenty thousand shares of ten pound each, shall be raised in the first instance, with power to increase such capital to the extent and in manner hereinafter mentioned.

And whereas for the better accomplishing and carrying into effect the objects and purposes of the said Company, they have applied to His Excellency the Governor and the Legislative Council of the Settlement of Sierra Leone to grant to them and all other the subscribers of such capital an ordinance of incorporation which the said Governor and Council have consented and agreed to do, under and subject to the conditions, restrictions, and provisions hereinafter contained.

Be it therefore enacted by the Governor, with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council thereof, as follows:—

I. This ordinance may be cited for all purposes as "The Bank of West Africa Incorporation Ordinance."

II. In the interpretation of this ordinance, the expression "The Governor," shall mean and include the officer for the time being administering the Government of the Settlement of Sierra Leone; and the expression, "The Company," shall mean the Bank of West Africa; and the expression, "The Court," shall mean the Supreme Court of the Settlement of Sierra Leone.

III. John George Thomas Child, Geoffrey Hornby, Henry Farnsby Mills, together with such and so many other persons as may become, proprietors of any share or shares of or in the capital for the time being of the said Company, shall be one body politic and corporate in name and in deed, by the name of "The Bank of West Africa," and by that name shall and may sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded in all courts in this settlement, whether of law or equity, and shall have a common seal, which may be by them altered, varied, and changed at their pleasure.

IV. The said Company is and shall be established for the purpose of carrying on the business of banking in manner aforesaid, in the Settlement of Sierra Leone, but subject, nevertheless, to the conditions, restrictions, regulations, and provisions hereinafter contained or to be contained in any supplemental ordinance hereafter to be passed for that purpose.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1872#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE BANK OF WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are quite sure that many of our readers will have looked with delight at the advertisement on the front page of this June number of our journal. That a "Bank for West Africa" should have left the realms of imagination for those of fact will have surprised some of them, but gratified still more. It is now not far from twenty years since we began to urge, both publicly and privately, the advantages and necessity of such an institution; and in our number of February 1st of this present year we announced by a leader that arrangements were in progress, of such a nature as gave us the conviction that the time of realization was at hand. Now, we have advanced another stage, and the "Bank of West Africa" is an established fact—a reality—and we congratulate our West African friends in especial that it is so. It had become monstrous that West Africa was not allied with Great Britain in banking operations; that with commercial relations of magnitude between the two, with weekly steam mail communication between Liverpool and all the West African ports, and a constantly increasing intercourse, West African commerce with Great Britain, and through the latter with European Continental ports, should still be left without any of those aids which independent capital was giving to merchant and trader in almost every other part of the world. Thanks chiefly to the indomitable persistence of Mr. C. Rosenbush, who appears in the prospectus as manager of the bank, this great reproach of West Africa is now to cease. Yet once again the old French proverb, "Everything comes to him who knows how to wait," has received justification. For seventeen long years, to our personal knowledge, Mr. Rosenbush has been endeavouring to endow London and West Africa with this financial bond. His father having been the first to introduce banking operations on the West Coast of Africa, at Sierra Leone, Mr. Rosenbush has an hereditary claim to the position he holds in this new institution; which, if successful, as it ought to be, and we believe will be, will, we are convinced, owe no small portion of its success to his management; for the duties attached to which we know that he has been assiduously preparing himself throughout the long years of probation above mentioned. In our leader of February 1st last we entered so fully upon the enumeration of the benefits that ought to flow to West Africa, and its now important interests by the establishment in London of a bank for that portion of the world of commerce, that it is not necessary we should do so here. There is, indeed, an ample field for safe and lucrative banking operations, within the limits to which they should be strictly confined; and we ought not to be in error when we anticipate for the bank a degree of success commensurate therewith. As with all kindred institutions this bank will, no doubt, be subject to strong temptations to action beyond those limits; but with directors, most of whom have had West African experience, and especially with a manager so intimately acquainted with the trading life of Sierra Leone, we hope and believe it will never fall into them. The line, the safe line, between commercial transactions and banking business is very clearly defined for those who choose to see and regard it, and no just ground of complaint ought to be given by the bank to the large mercantile houses doing business on the Coast, who will, we believe, find that the bank may render them a very valuable aid. This bank is not established with the view of adding one more competitor in the field of African trade and commerce, but as an auxiliary to all who are engaged therein. What are the facilities which it is believed the bank will especially offer? They are, if we do not understand the real position, to enable the West African trader who has a capital of £100 to quadruple his engagements, and do as much business as he could do with £400 unassisted by the bank. At present the trader with his £100 who desires to obtain his legitimate amount of gain by his business purchases produce and sends that to England, waiting for the proceeds of the produce to reach him in the shape of goods he has ordered. In this case it is quite clear he loses all the time between the date of his shipment on the Coast and that on which he gets the return goods into his possession. By the action and assistance of the bank, however, he may obtain on his verified shipment and deposit of bill of lading a portion of the money value of that produce in silver. Silver coin is now much esteemed by the native producers, as they can exchange it at will for the British manufactured goods—rum, gin, beads, powder, &c.—at the stores of the large importing merchants. With that portion of the money value thus obtained he can trade again, while his original £100 investment is on its way to Liverpool; and may, perhaps, be making a second shipment before his first reaches that port. It seems to us that this will be the legitimate working of the system of bank facilities on the West Coast, and that if the large import houses be reasonable in their scale of profits, they may consequently do, by this indirect aid of the bank, a much larger business than they have ever hitherto done. It is quite clear that the £100 man would not benefit much by the aid of the bank if he were to wait the receipt of goods purchased by the proceeds of his produce in England, and that he is therefore not likely to be an importer for anything more than what can be purchased by some commercial agent in England with the balance which the bank, acting under the consignor's orders, will hand over to him, after having satisfied its claim for the advances made by its establishment on the Coast, with expenses, &c. We are very anxious that the bank shall obtain a very great success; and this not only without injury to any existing interests on the West Coast, but by conferring benefits upon it. In the establishment of banking operations there we always calculated on the bank branches becoming the receivers and depositories of the colonial revenues, as pointed out in our leader before referred to. This will, of course, only be realised by the bank being conducted with so much prudence and wish such an entire absence of commercial risks and commitments as shall justify the Government authorities in placing full confidence in the institution. This is a matter of considerable importance. Not only are the revenues of good amount—Sierra Leone, £100,000; the Gold Coast, £100,000; Lagos, £50,000; the Gambia, £25,000; but the bank, having the confidence of the Government, will inspire confidence in the general population, so necessary to its becoming a trusted bank of deposits and issue; putting an end to the native custom of hoarding coin under the soil of their habitations. But to be this "trusted bank" it must keep its resources well in hand, and not make too many advances on real property. We must be excused for pointing out this danger to a bank. It is not necessary, nor would it be becoming in us, to do more than merely mention it. A word to the wise is as good as a volume; and, moreover, we feel confidence in Mr. Rosenbush in this matter. And now we have only to wish the bank "good speed." We shall watch it—its operations and its progress—with a deep, true interest in its welfare and prosperity. All West Africa is interested in that prosperity. Almost everything that can be accomplished by capital has yet to be effected there. We made this statement in our February number, adding further, "All the aids and appliances of civilization for facilitating communications between the Coast and the interior, for economising labour, for the transport of goods and produce, and for the development of the abounding natural and mineral resources, have yet to be introduced; and a well-established bank, giving large dividends to its shareholders, will surely...', 'last_edit_date': '1881-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1881#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.757, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BANK FOR BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "extensive. Every year the missionary schools discharge a number of educated men and women who almost invariably embark in trade. Most of them have some small capital, which they use to trade with the interior natives, and the produce they thus obtain they either ship on consignment to England, to obtain the proceeds in British and other goods and silver coin, or sell it to the large British and foreign mercantile houses on the Coast, receiving goods from them in exchange for a renewal of operations with the producers in the interior. These native traders almost universally prefer to remit their produce to Europe for sale; but in this they labour under the great disadvantage of having their capital locked up until they obtain from Europe the proceeds of the sales, in goods or money. They estimate their loss through such delays at something like 25 per cent., and there can be no doubt that the facilities a bank might safely afford would be productive of great gain, both to the traders and the bank; while, if the limits of our article would permit, we could point out how the European mercantile establishments may also be largely benefited thereby. To every one acquainted with the business of the West Coast, and the mode in which it is conducted, it is patent that the establishment of a well-conducted bank, with adequate capital, will lead to a greatly increased production on the West Coast—in a few years, it may be, to 100 per cent. increase. A bank, moreover, that is capable of offering ample guarantees for the safety of moneys deposited with it, cannot fail of being highly useful to the public service as bankers to the several Administrations, receiving from the Colonial Treasurers the proceeds of the Customs' duties and other sources of revenue, and holding them at the disposal of the Government in the shape most convenient to the latter. Such a bank will link West Africa, now isolated, with the great financial system of the civilized world, giving her a recognized position therein—a fact of enormous importance for the British West African Settlements, when we consider that almost everything that can be accomplished by capital has yet to be effected there. All the aids and appliances of civilization for facilitating communications between the Coast and the interior, for economizing labour, for the transport of goods and produce, and for the development of the abounding natural and mineral resources, have yet to be introduced; and a well-established bank, giving large dividends to its shareholders, will show European capital the way to further profitable investment in those too long neglected countries. We have always steadfastly maintained that ere many years the West Africa Settlements will take rank among the most valuable colonial possessions of Great Britain, and every fresh step towards the realization of this prediction is to us a source of real delight. The bank is such a step, and we shall welcome it with all our heart. We can assure it, too, a welcome all along the West Coast, to which it cannot fail to prove a benefactor. Our only regret at this moment is, that it will not be brought before the public in time for us to advertise it more fully in this number of our journal. But we have sounded the note of preparation, and our readers may confidently await its beneficial advent.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1881#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.734, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE BANK OF WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Bank of West Africa! Such, we are informed, is the title of a projected bank, for which an Ordinance of Incorporation has been obtained from the Legislative Council at Sierra Leone. So badly had we been served by our friends in Sierra Leone in this matter, that the first intimation of such a banking project having passed through the preliminary Sierra Leone stage, was made casually to us in London on the 17th inst. We felt immediately that it was a matter which, in the interest of the people of West Africa, and of those connected with trade and commerce there, would demand our close attention. Messrs. Child, Mills, and Co., of Manchester, were named to us as the organizers of the project, demanders of the Incorporation Ordinance at Sierra Leone, and now of the approval of Her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies, without which the project must fall to the ground. But this, with even a little more which we shall presently mention, was not by any means that full information which, in justice to the parties concerned, and at the same time to the West African interests and people we ought to be possessed of. It seemed to us that the proper course was to write to Messrs. Child, Mills, and Co. for that full information which, as it was no doubt a honest project, they would only be too happy to bring fully under public notice, through the medium of our journal. We regret to have to state that this idea of ours, as to their readiness to give information, was not a correct one; and that we were doomed to disappointment and mystification. We have no secrets, and can have no secrets in this matter. It is essentially one of such vast and vital importance for good or evil to the West African countries and their peoples, and to all connected by trade and commerce with that part of the world, that we have only one course to pursue, and that is thoroughly to ventilate it. Of course we can only do so at present to the extent of the partial information we possess; and if we fall into any error prejudicial to the project or the interests of the promoters of the bank, they can have only themselves to blame for it. This position is fully established by the following correspondence, which it becomes thus our duty to publish. Here it is:—

_African Times_ Office, London, 121, Fleet-street, E.C.,  
April 16, 1872.  
*Messrs. Child, Mills, and Co., Manchester.  
Gentlemen,—I shall feel obliged by your having the kindness to forward me per return of post copy of the Ordinance passed by the Legislative Council of Sierra Leone for the establishment of a bank of deposit and issue at that place, with branches, &c. The...", 'last_edit_date': '1872-04-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1872#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE BANK OF WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In our June number we published the prospectus of the Bank of West Africa, and congratulated our native readers on the prospects of increased facilities for trade which such an institution, if properly conducted, would supply. At the time we wrote we believed a much larger amount of the capital had been secured by applications for shares than proved to have been actually the case. We had been so far misinformed. Nevertheless, the amount of capital subscribed would have been sufficient for commencing operations, and proving by results whether banking institutions on the West Coast of Africa would, or would not, pay. Our own convictions on the subject are well known. We believed that by a supply of banking facilities at the Gambia, Sierra Leone, Cape Coast, Accra, and Lagos, as was contemplated, the operations of native traders would be greatly extended, perhaps doubled or trebled, and this without injury to the large European firms established in those places, who would continue to be the great importers of European and other goods, provided they sold them to the traders at reasonably remunerative prices. This, however, is well known not to be the opinion of those firms, who regarded a bank as a direct attack on their trade. Opposition, covert and open, met the bank on the publication of the prospectus. It was spoken against by them in no measured terms, and denounced in the public press by one of their agents as a monstrous conception that could only end in total failure. This opposition, which naturally enough interfered with the application for shares in the proposed bank, seems to have been too much for the moral courage of the Directors. Disputes and differences, we are told, arose among them, and so many of them resigned their seats at the Board before the day of allotment of shares, that the allotment made has been declared illegal by a competent judicial tribunal, with the result that the money paid on application for shares has been returned to the subscribers, and the projected bank has been judicially interred. We are greatly sorry for the just disappointment which the untimely fate of this infant bank will give rise to. The native traders everywhere down the West Coast have sufficient intelligence to comprehend the great benefits such an institution would have conferred, and we sympathize heartily with them under the injury they have thus sustained. Nor can we encourage any hope of a renewed effort, for, at least, some considerable time to come, to establish a Joint Stock Bank for banking operations on the West Coast of Africa. The failure of such an effort as that which has been lately made, closes the market for a time against any similar operation for the West Coast, the traders on which must resign themselves to the actual, and endeavour to be the best they may be able through the great facilities now afforded by weekly steam communication with Europe. At the same time everything must be done, and if we continue the publication of this paper, we will do our part in the work, to prove to the monied people in Great Britain that there is a wide and constantly expanding field on the West Coast for the profitable employment of capital, the judicious application of which is alone wanting for developing natural and mineral resources which will at no very distant period cast those of other tropical possessions of Great Britain deeply into shade. We shall not live to see this; but many of our younger readers will probably live to remember that we have held out this promise to Africa, and to the world at large. By our mental vision we behold in the not remote future a West Coast Africa, with which the actual one can only compare as a dwarf with a giant. Its proximity to Europe, the fertility of its soil, the variety of its rich and valuable products, insure this result. We can therefore conscientiously preach patience, but patience with exertion. Every educated African ought to regard himself as one of the appointed workers for bringing about this result. We rejoice to think we see reason to believe that those who have now the benefits of advanced education are comprehending this. A few years ago and those who obtained that advantage seemed to think that its only value was to enlarge the sphere of their personal enjoyments, and the circle of their pleasures. But now there is evidence of expanding ideas. We have before us at this moment a pamphlet, printed at Liverpool by George Philip & Son, for the author, Samuel Lewis, B.L., of Sierra Leone. It is the substance of a lecture delivered by him at the Wesleyan High School, on "The Agricultural Position of Sierra Leone." It gives a good and luminous account of the progress of agriculture in Sierra Leone, from the period when Granville Sharp and Wilberforce raised the Sierra Leone Company. Until within the last two or three years the progress had been slow and fitful, the easily cultivated root ginger being almost the only exportable produce. More strenuous efforts are now, however, being made. Sugar, coffee, and cocoa plantations have been commenced. This has been Sierra Leone's great need if she could ever expect to rise to eminence. The concluding paragraphs of Mr. Lewis's lecture give evidence that the author fully comprehends the need, and the only true way of supplying it. He says: "To succeed, agriculture must be taken up as a serious undertaking. The purpose of this paper will have been served if it succeed in inducing the conviction that the true causes of our backwardness in agriculture are remediable, and not inherent evils; capable of being cured by knowledge, assiduity in business, and a careful but not grudging economy of time, labour, and money, which only constant supervision can secure." With every advance in agriculture at Sierra Leone, with every step in the progress of development of natural resources in the other colonies and West Coast Settlements, the want of banking institutions will be more and more felt, and a more successful effort will no doubt then be made to establish a "Bank of West Africa."', 'last_edit_date': '1881-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1881#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.739, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Parcel Post with the Oil Rivers Protectorate', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"It is evident that in a trade which has its foundation on the barter system the value and quantity of the imports must vary directly with the exports. There is of late years a growing tendency on the part of the native, even in the remote interior, to employ silver currency for his transactions in place of direct barter or the cumbrous method of transporting vast quantities of cowrie shells from market to market. Hitherto the carrying powers of a slave and his intrinsic value have been in strict relations, but it is probable the less perishable metallic currency will oust him from the commercial field. In other ways the gradual adoption of specie payments has modified the methods of trade in the Colony, and such firms as have adhered to the old barter system have had to remove to less civilised regions. This is very noticeable in the case of the French firms, who were at one time the leading merchants of Lagos. There are at present few traces of their existence in the Colony, except the large factories which were built by them in the days of their prosperity. The establishment of a branch of the African Banking Corporation Limited, which took place towards the close of the year, will have a very remarkable effect on trade by increasing specie transactions, and even more by encouraging shipments by small traders, to whom money is advanced on the security of insured produce or invoiced European goods. The attention of the natives has been directed lately to the importance of developing minor industries. Among these may be mentioned the cultivation of cocoa and coffee, which has been taken up both by the natives and, in one', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BANK FOR BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "That banking facilities foster and aid the development of production, trade, and commerce, is a fact so abundantly established, and so universally admitted, that it would be almost an insult to the understandings of our readers for us to insist upon it, or adduce evidence in proof. Not the least important among the benefits that such facilities afford is the anticipatory realization of values, by which capital comes in to assist the operations of industry at the price of a share in its profits. By the discount of bills of exchange drawn by importers, manufacturers, and other producers on their customers for the value of commodities transferred, the working capital of the importer, manufacturer, or other producer or trader, is set free a certain number of days or months before it would otherwise be so, and made again available for other operations. A mutual benefit is thus conferred—a benefit that has not unfrequently made it possible to realize a fortune where, otherwise, a mere hard subsistence only might have been obtained. That such facilities are occasionally abused, in times of speculative mania, by being made instrumental to an illegitimate increase in the value of commodities, to be followed by subsequent ruinous depression, merely affords an additional evidence of a fact universally known, that a good instrument may be, and is, often used for a bad purpose. The instrument is not to be blamed, but only the improper use made of it. Thus, many drugs which are a great boon to suffering humanity when properly and carefully administered, may become instruments of death in inexperienced or wicked hands. A system by which 100l. sterling may be made to do the work of 400l. or 500l., ought to be, and must be when only legitimately employed, exceedingly beneficial to an honest and prudent manufacturer or trader of limited means, giving a fair chance of success in the world's strife where, but for it, there could not be any possibility of such success. It may not enable the trading dwarf to rise to the height of the giant, but it may prevent the giant from crushing him to death under his feet. Penetrated by this truth, established by experience, we, nearly twenty years ago endeavoured to obtain banking facilities for the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa. It is not necessary to enumerate here the various difficulties that suggested themselves, and which, at that period, and at later periods, were insurmountable; nor shall we enter upon any details of the Banking Scheme of 1872, which it became our duty to denounce and oppose, as being fraught with extreme danger to the legitimate trading interests in those settlements, as well as to those who might have been induced to invest their money therein. There were two points on which we insisted then, as we insist now, and the difficulty of obtaining a full satisfaction on which deterred us on subsequent occasions. Those two points are, a perfect security for the banking capital employed, and that the bank should not be instrumental to the establishment of a commercial monopoly. This latter it would have become in the hands of any one of the large European trading firms established on the Coast, and we could not see our way clear to obtaining adequate guarantees for the former. The ultimate failure of any banking operations undertaken in the British settlements, owing to the want of adequate security, would have been an evil of such magnitude that we felt it was better for the Coast to struggle on without banking facilities than that there should be danger of such a result; and we felt, moreover, that in the course of events the time would come when our reasonable demands as regards a bank could be satisfied. That time, it seems to us, has now arrived. We see no reason to doubt that a perfect security for banking capital may now be obtained without the bank being made the instrument of commercial monopoly. A weekly steam communication between England and all the settlements on the West Coast, with telegraphic communication with Madeira, distant only four or five days from Sierra Leone, will enable the Board of Directors in London to maintain a constant and efficient control over the African establishments; while the facility it offers for a change of climate in the event of sickness removes any difficulty that may have been previously suggested as regards the health of European bank officials there. There is also a higher class of native Africans now capable of furnishing adequate guarantee for their honesty and fidelity than existed a few years ago. The fuller the consideration we give to the subject, the more firmly convinced are we that the bank now about to be established, if properly conducted—as, from the constitution of the Board of Directors which has been submitted to us, we have no doubt it will be—may be expected within a few years to rank as one of the most successful of British Colonial banks having their seat of Direction in London. The elements of success that the bank will command are now very considerable, and becoming year by year more", 'last_edit_date': '1881-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1881#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.717, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "RIVERS NUNEZ, PONGAS, MELLICOURIE, SCARCIES, AND SHERBRO'.", 'section_title': '', 'content': "We are glad to see that the two Steam Companies, the African and the British and African, have made arrangements for regular communications, by branch steamers, in connection with the weekly Liverpool steamers, between Sierra Leone and the above-mentioned rivers; the hope also being held out of the Branch steamer calling at other rivers in the neighbourhood if adequate inducement be offered. This arrangement can scarcely fail to increase the trade and revenue of Sierra Leone. It had become particularly necessary, indeed indispensable, as regards the Sherbro', which has so very considerable a trade, and which has so often suffered vexatious and hurtful delays in the transmission of letters, owing to official caprice at Sierra Leone. The regularity and certainty derived by steam communication is so beneficial in commercial affairs, that there is little, if any, room for doubt that within a very few years steam will have almost entirely superseded sailing craft in the commerce of the West Coast of Africa. The weekly steamers are continually adding new ports of call to their lists, evincing a praiseworthy desire on the part of the two Steamship Companies to aid the development of West African resources.", 'last_edit_date': '1879-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1879#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Question of a Bank for Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Ought not an important place like Lagos, and doing a trade of such magnitude, to have a savings or deposit bank?" is the question asked at the beginning of a letter in our last number. We inserted that letter with the intention of referring to it this month, because we deem it better that no vain illusions should prevail on a question of so much importance. We begin by asking another question, What is there to pay for the accommodation to be offered by a bank in Lagos? This is the consideration that lies at the very root of the matter; but which we fear has been very little thought of by those who desire the advent of such an institution. There can be no doubt that banks offer great facilities to commerce. But banks are not philanthropic institutions. They are simply establishments that trade in their own and other people's money, deriving their profits from the employment of that money. When the magnitude of the trade of Lagos is put forward as the reason why there ought to be a banking institution there, it becomes necessary to inquire what the nature of that trade is; whether it is such as requires, and would reward banking facilities. There can, we believe, be no doubt that since the ruin that fell upon native traders in Lagos by the closing of the interior markets (caused by the very gross error committed by the British Government and the local British authorities) in 1872-3, the great bulk of the Lagos commerce is carried on by a few opulent European houses; and others who have European agents in Lagos. Now these houses and people, instead of looking for or desiring banking facilities in Lagos, are the very parties who would most strenuously oppose their introduction. A bank that would advance money, as suggested in the letter alluded to, on the security of bills of lading for produce sent to England for realization, would interfere in no small degree with their business, one of the elements of which is the purchase of that produce. There is nothing, therefore, to be hoped or looked for by a bank, in the shape of co-operation or support in that quarter. Is the residue of the trade, that which is carried on by native import and export traders, at present of sufficient magnitude—or if doubled or quadrupled, would it then be of sufficient magnitude—to support a bank? because those who desire and advocate the introduction of a bank, must bear in mind that a bank must be itself supported, as well as support others by its operations. A bank, to be of any real utility, must possess a considerable capital. This capital would require guardianship and administration of a special and expensive character; since only in such could it find security. The profits made must therefore be large, even merely to pay the current administrative expenses of the bank. There is no loose unemployed money lying about in Lagos, that would insure to the bank a large dependable average of other people's money, in current account,—no large estates to administer,—nothing in fact to bring in profits; but only that residue of trade with Europe above referred to. We say, without hesitation, that alone the', 'last_edit_date': '1877-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1877#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The present commercial depression upon the West Coast is a matter of serious import to the majority of our readers. From Lagos, Accra, Sierra Leone, and Bathurst, the complaint is the same—a depression in all branches of commerce which is altogether unparalleled in the history of our trading stations. In an article upon this subject, in our September number, we endeavoured to lay before our readers some of the causes—those especially which admit of remedy—which led to this distressing state of things. We say especially those admitting of remedy, for it must be conceded that much of this depression arises from causes entirely beyond our control, and the effect of which is felt more or less acutely in all our great commercial centres. In the first place, then, we have undoubtedly the apathy of the Government, to whom, it is to be feared, Africa, being out of sight, was very often "out of mind." But let us hope we shall soon see an improvement in this respect, now that direct telegraphic communication is at length established between London and the West Coast. Next we have to consider the unfair competition to which the genuine trader or merchant finds himself subjected by his dishonest rival, who, having no intention of paying for the goods he has succeeded in obtaining, can very well afford to undersell him who purposes to meet his engagements. Undoubtedly, this is fostered by an undue extension of the credit system. Upon another page will be found some correspondence upon this subject which goes to show how vast is the injury worked by the credit (!) system when not properly safe-guarded. One of our correspondents—"A Patriot"—observes, quoting from the Lagos Times of four years ago: "It would be difficult, and it is altogether unadvisable, to abolish the credit system, root and branch, from the trade, as sometimes there may be very deserving cases that may be properly helped with a credit; but it is most certainly undesirable that the system should rule trading relations altogether, as it has done." This, we must say, appears rather too severe upon credit as a system. Without credit there would be little or no room for commercial enterprise; but credit overdone, which fosters dishonesty, or even that carelessness which is so closely allied to it, is sure to damage both him who gives and him who takes. Another correspondent—"R. W."—points out that the commerce of Africa is at present in a transition state, and, like all transition, has some of the evils of both the old and new systems. He goes on to argue, very reasonably, that the local Government authorities might do much to improve the present condition of things by initiating improvements in the country by forming new roads and bridges, and possibly, where needed, harbours. He points out that things were much better ten or eleven years ago, after the conclusion of the Ashanti War, even in spite of the consequent loss of the interior trade; and this he attributes to the facility for purchasing goods which was a consequence of the Government paying so much to those engaged in the war operations. As to the enforcement of a better system of education, the desirability of which our correspondent alludes to, the conditions of life vary so much in each of our West Coast colonies, and from that in England, that it is impossible to see how any universal system of national education is to be maintained; and this much is certain—the effect of an improved education would only be shown very gradually, and as the present generation passing away would leave room for the fuller development of its successor. The formation of a bank, under Government auspices, would doubtless act as a great incentive to an improvement in commerce, for one of the chief difficulties of the smaller African trader at the present time is in obtaining drafts upon London and Liverpool merchants to enable him to settle claims in England. There may be many other causes more or less answerable for this very unsatisfactory state of things, but there can be no doubt that honesty and integrity will go far towards bringing back to the British colonies on the West Coast that commercial prosperity which is so essential to the improvement of the African peoples.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE BANK OF WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'P.S.—Since writing the above, we hear that another effort is being made to establish a Bank for West Africa, and there is a strong probability of the effort proving successful.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1881#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL DEPRESSION ON THE WEST COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The most unpleasant side of the question to me is that, after these inexperienced European merchants have so imprudently supplied goods to adventurous traders without securities, or worthless securities (and many a time without any reference to the Coast respecting the pecuniary status or reputation of the consignee), they are only too ready to brand all Africans as a race of dishonest robbers. A certain Manchester merchant, in writing to a friend on this subject, lately said, "I have lost £60,000 on the coast of Africa, £30,000 of which I have lost in Lagos." Now, Mr. Editor, the class of men this particular merchant credited is almost beyond belief. One of the effects of this system which have to be deplored is the serious and unwarrantable competition that follows, to the detriment of capitalists. The debtor merchant being sure that he would never possibly pay his creditor in full, for the purpose of giving temporary impetus to the trade, will undersell capitalists and over-top them in buying produce, and with these large shipments or remittances generally baffle their unwary creditors, and secure more confidence and larger credits. They are spoken of as big traders, enterprising men, and such like; it matters not whether the produce shipped has been surreptitiously received and not paid for. The result is that the honest capitalists are threatened with ruin, as they cannot come into open conflict with the fraudulent merchants in their ruinous competitive undertakings, as the latter have nothing to lose. The *Lagos Times*, in its issue of the 10th August, 1881, in inveighing in strong terms against the credit system of Lagos, says: "There is a great facility afforded by it (the credit system) for dishonest and dishonourable transactions. Distance between here and Europe enables one who solicits credit to exaggerate the market value of the property he tenders to a creditor for security, and thus obtains a considerably larger supply than the true value of his property would have warranted; and there are never wanting those who are ready to swear anything, who would solemnly affirm to the alleged estimated value being a fair and just one. They are anxious, perhaps, to help their friend, and this they scruple not to do at the expense of their own better convictions, and of the wholesome advice that we should be just and true to all men alike; and so it has often come to pass that properties are encumbered with debts three times their market value at the time those debts were contracted. . . . Further, the system opens a way for extravagance, and renders it easy for those who are not careful to get into debt. It cannot be denied that men are generally more careful of that which they have earned by their own independent honest industry than of that which is left to them by others, or is given them on credit; and that they would sometimes have dispensed with that which they readily take on credit if they had had to pay for it at once out of their savings. Often upon the receipts of large credits new modes of living are at once adopted; artificial wants rapidly increase; the luxuries, the expensive, and perhaps not innocuous pleasures of European life, and the extravagance of foreign fashions, become at once indispensable; large houses are built and furnished, perhaps in very expensive style. . . . It has sometimes been to us a question whether these persons did ever really intend to repay the loans they so freely squander away when they sought for them."', 'last_edit_date': '1885-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}]

hh: The global cotton market in the late 19th century was shaped by the interconnectedness of American and African economies, with increased American cotton production impacting African cotton prices and demand amid competitive pressures from producers in India, Brazil, and Egypt.
result: The interconnectedness of the global cotton market in the late 19th century is highlighted by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook notes that the American Civil War stimulated Egyptian cotton production and exports, leading to a significant increase in output. However, post-war, cotton prices fell, indicating a direct connection between American and Egyptian cotton markets. While the textbook supports the idea of interconnectedness between these two regions, it does not provide comprehensive details on the broader global cotton market dynamics, particularly the competitive pressures from India, Brazil, and Egypt, as mentioned in the claim. In contrast, The African Times articles provide detailed insights into the impact of increased American cotton production on African cotton prices and demand, highlighting a direct link between American production levels and African market conditions. The articles also emphasize competitive pressures from producers in India, Brazil, and Egypt, aligning with the claim that these regions were significant players in the global cotton market. Additionally, they discuss challenges faced by African cotton producers, such as high freight rates, which hindered their competitiveness. Although the articles focus on specific years like 1864 and 1871, they offer a nuanced view of the global cotton market's dynamics, supporting the claim's emphasis on interconnected economies and competitive pressures. Together, these sources illustrate the complex interplay of regional markets and the global cotton economy during this period.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides some insights that are relevant to the claim about the global cotton market in the late 19th century. It mentions that the American Civil War stimulated the production and export of cotton in Egypt, leading to a significant increase in output. However, after the war, cotton prices fell, and the rise in production was insufficient to offset this decline in prices. This suggests a connection between American and Egyptian cotton markets, as the American Civil War had a direct impact on Egyptian cotton production and prices. The text does not explicitly discuss the impact of American cotton production on African cotton prices and demand, nor does it mention competitive pressures from producers in India, Brazil, and Egypt. Therefore, while the textbook supports the idea of interconnectedness between American and Egyptian cotton markets, it does not provide comprehensive details on the broader global cotton market dynamics involving other regions like India and Brazil. This absence of information on the competitive pressures from these regions is a notable difference from the claim.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim about the interconnectedness of the global cotton market in the late 19th century. The articles highlight the impact of increased American cotton production on African cotton prices and demand. For instance, the abundance of the American cotton crop is noted to affect the price of African raw cotton, suggesting a direct link between American production levels and African market conditions. Additionally, the articles mention competitive pressures from other producers, such as India, Brazil, and Egypt, which align with the claim that these regions were significant players in the global cotton market. The articles also discuss the challenges faced by African cotton producers, including high freight rates, which hindered their ability to compete effectively. This reflects the competitive pressures and interconnectedness described in the claim. However, the articles do not explicitly mention the late 19th century, focusing instead on specific years like 1864 and 1871, which may not fully encompass the entire period suggested by the claim. Overall, the articles provide a nuanced view of the global cotton market's dynamics, supporting the claim's emphasis on interconnected economies and competitive pressures.
topic2: Global Economic Integration of African economies

[{'document_title': 'The colonial economy: North Africa', 'section_title': 'Part II: Libya, Egypt and the Sudan > Egypt > Exported-oriented economy > Investment pattern', 'content': "It was also argued by the Egyptian administration that the encourage› ment of cotton and its export was necessary to increase the country's revenues and to enable Egypt to repay its debts. The accumulation of a huge public debt begun in 1858 was to finance the infrastructural projects as well as the extravagances of some of the monarchs. The law of liquidation of 1880 had fixed Egypt's public debt at £98.37 million and during the next twenty years a further £18.2 million was borrowed. Egypt's liabilities to foreigners had reached £E 8.5 million per annum by 1914.$^{a5}$ Establishing export surplus was vital to meet those liabilities.
The American Civil War stimulated the production and export of cotton in Egypt. Output increased from a little over half a million kantärs in i860 to over 2.1 million in 1865, to 4.1 million in 1890 and to 7.7 million in 1913. However, after the rapid increase in the price of cotton caused by the American Civil War, prices continued to fall until the end of the century and the rise in production was insufficient to offset the fall in prices. During the first decade of this century, cotton prices more than doubled, and the value of the crop rose to over three times what it had been at the beginning of the occupation. In 1916 cotton prices rose to an average of US $38 and again to US $90 per kantär in 1919; exports jumped to £E 88 million in 1920 and a large export surplus was built up. 56 The financial achievement of the British administration was to ensure the proper collection and administration of the increased revenues accruing to the government out of this surplus. Fiscal reform in the form of reducing expenditure, except those considered remunerative like irrigation works, was undertaken. Increasing revenues from exports repaid all loans con› tracted during the occupation as well as reducing Ismail's debt by some £10 million by 1913.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'New trends and processes in Africa in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'New economic trends', 'content': 'In the economic as in the other fields, some new trends became discernible during our period. The most radical change was the well-known one of the abolition and suppression of the slave trade and its replacement by export agriculture which has wrongly, but in a typically Eurocentric manner, been termed legitimate trade. Radical in its impact as it was, this change was rather slow in coming. Indeed, in East and Central Africa, as will be seen below, the first six decades of the century saw the expansion and intensification of that inhuman traffic.$^{61}$ It was not until the very end of the period under review that export agriculture completely replaced the slave trade.
Very well-known as this change was, its real significance has been lost on many scholars. It was not the change-over from the so-called illegitimate to the so-called legitimate trade but, rather, the fundamental shift in the distribution of incomes from the ruling aristocratic elite to the ordinary people that was significant. Since the slave trade, which constituted the principal source of income, was a monopoly of the kings and their military leaders and advisers, the bulk of the income went to them. But with its replacement by natural products such as palm oil, groundnuts, cotton, gum, honey, beeswax, kola nuts, etc., which could be produced or collected by the ordinary people, and especially those living in the rural areas, a steady redistribution of income ensued, leading to the rise of a new set of rich people in not only the urban and market centres but also in the rural areas. The roots of the present-day phenomenon of rural capitalism can be traced to this period.
Another consequence of the development of this export agriculture was the steady integration into the capitalist world-economy not only of the external economy of Africa, but also its internal or rural economy. In other words, the change to export agriculture was not accompanied by a technological change in the means of production nor in the industrial processing of the products prior to exportation. Gen› erally speaking, the difficulty and cost of transport restricted trading transactions for a long time to a few major products that were much in demand, such as salt, iron, prestige goods (copper, raffia fabrics, etc.), whereas agricultural produce was rarely carried over great distances.
The rise of a world-wide market economy, which began in the sixteenth century, gradually affected the organization of economic life in everwidening areas of Central Africa. Here again, the nineteenth century is part of a continuous process, that of unequal trade relationships with the capitalist world. However, from the 1850s, great changes began to take place. Slaves gradually ceased to be Central Africa's principal 'export' to the outside world. Trade expanded in the main products obtained from a gathering-based economy: ivory, wax, copal, oil and coffee. The growth of this market economy is undeniable: the value of goods passing through Angolan ports increased sevenfold between 1844 and 1881; the cash turn› over of the Luanda branch of the Banco Nacional Ultramarino increased tenfold between 1865 and 1876. In the early 1870s, however, the value of exports derived from these products was still only twice that derived from the export of slaves in the 1820s. 14 The volume of these major African products reaching world markets was dependent on the way in which communications and trade networks functioned within the continent. These networks, with their staging posts, trade conventions and currencies, in turn defined the major economic zones on the nineteenth-century map of Central Africa, amounting to new 'frontiers' that overlaid and modified the former political and economic divisions of the region.
These new economic zones were dominated by the demands of the nerve centres of the nineteenth-century world economy. Besides, immediate interest on the part of European monopoly capital was low. Africa commanded high priority during the mercantilist era of accumulation, but the relative obscurity of the nineteenth century persisted into the early years of colonialism, in spite of the increase in politico-economic control which followed upon partition and conquest. Viewed in terms of the global investment drive of monopoly capitalism up to the First World War, figures concerning the growth of the African colonial economy are unimpressive. The most relevant of these figures concerned imports and exports, since the import/export sector was the central feature of the colonial economy. The volume of goods imported into Africa rose sluggishly. With the exception of South Africa, import lists were not headed by machinery, plant or high-quality consumer items. Trade growth usually meant the extension of product lines characteristic of the mid nineteenth century, and those had not departed radically from the patterns of the slave trade era. Cotton piece-goods continued to dominate European exchanges with Africa, and in many places the import of cotton cloth never lost its priority throughout the period in question, although other items of domestic consumption, such as kitchen utensils, radios, bicycles and sewing machines were later to gain in popularity.
