**DISINFECTING SANITARY FLUID AND CLEANSER**

**FOR USE ON BOARD STEAM AND SAILING SHIPS AND HULKS, AND IN HOSPITALS, CHURCHES, STORES, FACTORIES, AND PRIVATE RESIDENCES.**

Our *Disinfecting Sanitary Fluid* is at once an Antiseptic and powerful Detergent. As an *Antiseptic Agent*, it will be found invaluable for preventing the development of the germs of the low forms of Animal life which give rise to putrid and infectious diseases—such as Scarlet Fever, Measles, Small-pox, &c.; and is fatal to those which may have developed in process of putrefaction of dead Animals and Vegetable matter. As a *Detergent*, it has a greater affinity for Grease than the most perfect Soap. This property, combined with its strong disinfectant power, renders it a very efficient agent on Shipboard, and in Hospitals, for Sanitary and Cleansing purposes. As a *Vermicide*, it destroys all parasitic forms of insect life which infest Bedrooms, Ships, &c., and are the cause of so much discomfort and annoyance. A few drops put into hard water previous to being used for domestic purposes, as well as into the toilette jug or ewer, will give great satisfaction. After use, a pleasant odour remains.

Put up in Export Drums of about 1 cwt., to suit African Market.

*Price 8s. per Gallon, free alongside Ship (Full Instructions sent with Consignments).*

---

**PATENT PAINT REMOVER COMPOSITION.**

This is a Compound which far supersedes anything yet introduced for removing Old Paint from Plain or Moulded Surfaces; cleaning Stained or Smoked Marble Chimney-pieces, Tables, &c. There is not any smell, as with Irons, Lamps, &c., and it does its work infinitely better. (*Full Instructions sent with Consignments.*)

Put up in Drums of about 1 cwt. each, to Suit African Market.

*Price 30s. per Cwt., free alongside Ship.*

---

**BOILER COMPOSITION.**

MANUFACTURED SPECIALLY FOR USERS OF STEAM POWER, MARINE, LAND, & LOCOMOTIVE.

The four most desirable qualifications in a Boiler Compound are—Efficiency, Economy, Simplicity, and Harmlessness; and these qualifications we claim our Composition possesses to an exceptional extent. It removes and prevents Incrustation and Corrosion in Boilers where Sea Water is used, and its effect is the same where fresh or hard Calcareous Water is used. It is quite free from Solids, Mineral or otherwise; it is also free from Acids.

Put up in Drums of about 1 cwt. each, to suit African Market.

*Price 8s. per Gallon, free alongside Ship.*

---

tat_extra:
[{'document_title': "GERMANY'S TRADE WITH ITS AFRICAN COLONIES", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The business Germany has been doing with the colonies in Africa shows a pretty considerable increase, as may be seen by the following figures, which were lately published by the Commercial Office in Hamburg, from which place most of the goods are shipped to the colonies. There were imported from German West Africa, in 100 kilos:—

|          | 1894   | 1893   | 1892   |
|----------|--------|--------|--------|
| Togo and Camerun | 109,296 | 96,719 | 85,495 |
| German South-West Africa | 15     | —      | 1      |
| German East Africa | 3,651  | 3,188  | 2,415  |

Among the goods imported from West Africa, palm kernels take the principal place, 89,586 having been imported in 1894; next comes palm oil, with 13,660 and caoutchouc with 3,259. German East Africa supplies sesame-seeds, 1,487; caoutchouc, 1,104; ivory, 257. Of all other articles only small lots of less than 10,000 kilos, were imported. Export to East Africa is considerably higher than import, being in 100 kilos:—

|          | 1894   | 1893   | 1892   |
|----------|--------|--------|--------|
| Togo and Camerun | 101,569 | 78,124 | 88,615 |
| German South-West Africa | 5,370  | 2,373  | 211   |
| German East Africa | 45,189 | 35,513 | 22,457 |

The different articles sent to these Colonies consist of almost all the products of Germany, such as raw materials of all kinds, victuals, arms and ammunition, hardware, soaps, &c.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1895#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The West African Colonies at the Colonial Exhibition', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The data for Lagos are for 1862. Going back fifty years ago, to 1836, we find no definite statistics for the Gold Coast; while Gambia exported no less than in 1875—£147,000. The exports of Sierra Leone, on the other hand, were valued at only £71,900. A large share of the West African trade is with Great Britain. In 1884, of the total exports, about £1,100,000, or nearly two-thirds, were sent to the Mother Country, while British produce counted for £93,000 among the imports into the West African Settlements, just more than one-half. Next to England, Germany seems to do the largest trade with these colonies. Indeed, in two of the colonies Germany seems to hold a higher place in exports than the Mother Country. In 1884, exports to the value of £283,500 were sent from Lagos to Germany, while only £249,000 in value were sent to Great Britain, according to local returns. The entire exports to foreign countries in 1884 amounted to £324,620. The imports from Great Britain were nearly double those from foreign countries. We find a somewhat similar state of things on the Gambia, in 1883. The exports to Great Britain were valued at £46,232; to foreign countries £160,487. The imports from the United Kingdom in the same year amounted to £90,000, from British colonies £37,000, and from foreign countries £71,680.

In all the West African colonies, except the Gambia, palm oil and palm kernels figure as the staple exports. The great exports from Gambia at the present time are ground nuts, which are largely used for the manufacture of French salad oil; these, with bees-wax, rubber, and hides, are now almost the only exports. In the exports for 1883 we find no mention of ground nuts, the chief exports of that date being wax, gum, ivory, gold, and rice. In 1836 the export of ground nuts was valued at only £838, and in 1852 had reached £153,000, in 1882 £230,000, falling to £170,000 in 1883. In 1836 four leading articles of export, gold, gum, ivory, and teak wood, were valued at £45,000, and twenty years later had sunk to £632. That these and other resources of the colonies, especially rubber, are capable of considerable development is maintained by those acquainted with the colony. The value of the rubber exported is about £6,000 annually. Nearly three-fourths of the ground nuts exported go to France.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1886#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL COMPANIES FOR AFRICAN TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will be annihilated by an European desire for legitimate commercial advantage. Human interest, resting in Europe upon the strong fulcrum of human wants, is the mighty lever that God has clearly ordained for lifting the great continent of Africa to the position she has been endowed for. She has passed rapidly, though it may seem to have been slowly, through the earlier stages of her elevation. The epoch of more potent effort has now arrived. Combined mercantile energy enters the rich field where legitimate individual enterprise has been preparing the way for it. Just as powerful European organizations prosecuted the slave-trade in Africa which individual cupidity desultorily commenced, and thus gave to that accursed traffic the enormous development to which it attained, so will powerful European organizations now take the field in giving development to that legitimate commerce for which Africa possesses so many rich and copious elements. A century and a-half ago English African companies were erecting their fortified slave factories along the Western Coast of Africa. Now English African companies are holding out their peaceful hands to the African people, to tempt them onward in the path of agricultural industry. There are large fields for legitimate commercial action in Africa, and large profits to be obtained there, if they be honestly, actively, and intelligently sought by organizations of practical experienced men, with such sufficient capital as shall enable them to plant firmly where they trade, the standard of their peaceful industrial array. Companies with too restricted capital can only do the same sort of work that individual merchants have been and are performing. This was and is useful enough for Africa, and beneficial to the merchant, as far as it can prudently go. But Africa now wants more than this. She wants powerful companies, that shall prudently but boldly stimulate and assist her to a much higher and more extensive industrial development. The Company of African Merchants is, and is intended to be, such an one. That it will open to England the great national storehouses of African cotton, we have no doubt; while it will be at the same time be helping forward and reaping other portions of its harvests in the long-opened fields of oils, gums, and other such articles of African produce. We long to see it, and we hope that we shall see it and kindred efficient organizations, take hold of certain richly-endowed districts of Africa with a firm and solid grasp—with a determination to squeeze from them their abundant natural stores, enriching them and elevating them morally and socially in the process—with a firm resolve to employ all those wealth-creating means which advancing civilization in Europe has gradually discovered and applied for stimulating industry and diffusing wealth, comfort, peace, and happiness, among mankind.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The actual value of imports into the Oil Rivers is not easily ascertained. For a period of three years ending 1889 they were estimated to have been £730,000 per annum, but prices have since advanced and the volume of business has considerably increased. The value of exports from the Oil Rivers in 1890 is estimated at considerably over £1,300,000, after adding freight and charges. For four months of the year prices ranged a little over the average, and they promise so far to be fully as high in 1891. The following details as to the principal exports may be of interest. Palm oil has long been the staple export of this part of Africa. According to Porter (“Progress of the Nation”) the import into the United Kingdom in 1808 was 200 tons; 1836, 13,850 tons; 1844, 20,732 tons. It is now (1890) 43,696 tons. These figures, however, are for the United Kingdom only. Formerly the whole went to the British Isles, but now some 8,000 to 10,000 tons annually go to Marseilles, Havre, and Antwerp direct from the Oil Rivers. Of the United Kingdom import, only about 25,000 tons were actually from the Oil Rivers, the balance being from the Niger and Congo, Cameroons, Lagos, and other West African Ports. Palm kernels are rapidly increasing in importance. About 20,000 tons annually go from the rivers to Continental ports alone, and about the same quantity to the United Kingdom. The growing importance of the trade is shown by the fact that the Oil Rivers kernel imports into the United Kingdom only commenced about the year 1860, and in most of the rivers no kernels at all had been shipped before 1875.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE OIL RIVERS COMMISSIONERSHIP', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Messrs. J. Irvine & Co.'s Palm Oil Report for November", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. The average prices in Europe of the more important native products have stood even lower than during the previous twelve months, while the prolonged continuance of low prices in Africa has apparently disheartened the native producer, and tended to diminish the quantity as well as the value of his out-turn. In Europe and America an improvement has, it is true, occurred in the prices of a few leading articles of commerce, but no sign of such revival extending to the products of West Africa has yet been vouchsafed; and, while it is not forbidden to hope for better things in 1888, it would be imprudent of our readers to base their calculations on any material rise in prices, or, indeed, not to make the necessary provisions for a possible—though, let us hope, improbable—further fall. While this condition of business is doubtless felt more or less even by the wealthy European merchants trading to West Africa, the most deplorable results of the depression occur in the colonial centres, such as Sierra Leone and Lagos. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.

To these communities 1888 will probably bring good tidings. It has been stated, on apparently good authority, that early in the new year the so-called "oil rivers"—now under intermittent Consular jurisdiction—will be formed into a Colony. The experiences of Lagos and the Gold Coast enable us to predict, with tolerable certainty, the results which will follow from this policy. These valuable regions will be rapidly settled and opened up to trade. Hitherto, owing to the prevalence of the barter system, the unsettled condition of the tribes, and the absence of order and justice, only wealthy European houses have been able to make the necessary provisions.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Latest from Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. These valuable regions will be rapidly settled and opened up to trade. Hitherto, owing to the prevalence of the barter system, the unsettled condition of the tribes, and the absence of order and justice, only wealthy European houses have been able to make the necessary provisions.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Decade of the Trade of Hamburg with West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'An interesting report from the British Consul-General at Hamburg on the growth of the trade of that port with the West Coast of Africa during the past ten years has lately been issued. The main features of this increase are the establishment of direct and regular steam communication, a fourfold increase in the shipping, an increase in imports of more than sixfold, while exports have doubled.

In the imports of Hamburg the West Coast of Africa now ranks fifth, and in exports fourth. First, as to shipping—in 1878, 25 vessels, of which 10 were German, with a total tonnage of 8,054 tons, arrived in Hamburg from the West Coast, and 98 vessels, of which 48 were German, of 25,674 tons left Hamburg, and none were steamers. In 1888 there were 63 vessels inwards, 34 being German, of a gross tonnage of 67,446 tons, and 89 outwards, 59 being German, of a gross tonnage of 72,885 tons. Of the inward vessels 54, and of the outward 59 were steamers. Thus in ten years the tonnage increased by about 400 per cent. Imports have increased far more than exports, because Hamburg has now become the centre of distribution for West African products.

The chief article of import is palm kernels, of which there were 973,405 cwts. in 1888, against 106,453 cwts. in 1878; in palm oil the quantities for the same years were 121,884 cwts. and 29,036 cwts., respectively; coffee, 11,109 cwts. and 96 cwts.; dyewood, 20,668 cwts. and 6,094 cwts.; india-rubber, 13,679 cwts. and 3,142 cwts.; and so on for less important articles. The total imports for 1888 amounted to 1,168,783 cwts., and the exports 1,121,605 cwts.; in 1878 the imports were 182,399 cwts., and the exports 495,660 cwts. The chief article of export is alcohol in one or other of its forms. The export of spirits in 1888 was 652,130 cwts., against 314,120 cwts. in 1878; the exports of the other principal articles for the two years were as follows: Rice, 90,778 cwts. in 1888 and 5,053 in 1878; beer, 16,479 and 2,919 cwts.; gunpowder, 86,320 and 10,844 cwts.; iron ware, 20,478 and 4,559 cwts.; tobacco, 12,048 and 2,784 cwts.; cotton goods, 11,053 and 3,110 cwts. In the non-European trade of Hamburg, West Africa comes sixth in imports, before Mexico, Singapore, Japan, China, &c., and next after British India. Indeed, it is nearly equal to the latter, which includes considerable imports of jute and rice. In exports the West Coast is fourth, coming next after the Argentine Republic.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The trade between this country and West Africa is capable of almost infinite development. It is now announced that the British Government will recommend Parliament to grant a subsidy to a contractor who is prepared to lay and work a cable between St. Vincent and the chief places on the West Coast. We are sure our readers will rejoice at this further step towards bringing West Africa into closer connexion with England. At present, the three weeks taken by even the fastest postal communication is a serious drawback to the commerce of Lagos, Sierra Leone, and the other West African ports, and the proposed cable will do much to simplify and develop commercial relations between Great Britain and the ports and towns in her West Coast possessions. Further south, we have the still more important district of the Congo. Mr. H. M. Stanley, than whom no greater authority upon the subject exists, seems never to tire of pointing out the advantages which must result from the formation of new markets in the Congo territory; and the decision of the European Powers at the Berlin Conference that Free Trade principles should be established at least for a term of years in the territory of the African International Association will do much towards the development of trade with parts not hitherto reached by commerce. The British Congo Company (Limited), the prospectus of which our readers will find in another column, which may be aptly described as the practical outcome of the Conference's decision, is now announced, with a capital of £500,000, divided into shares of £5 each. The Board of Directors contains many names well known in the African trade. Even under no very favourable circumstances a considerable trade has been for the past few years conducted between this country and the Congo. Last year, the imports into this district amounted to considerably over £880,000, and the exports to nearly £2,000,000—so that in round numbers the present trade may be roughly estimated at between two and a-half and three million pounds per annum. Though only just formed, the British Congo Company (Limited) will scarcely commence as an entirely new undertaking, for, in order to avoid the delays and disadvantages inseparable from an entirely new business, a provisional agreement has been made with the Congo and Central African Company (Limited), of Liverpool, which possesses several factories and stations along the river, and at Ambriz and Ambrizette on the coast, by which the Congo and Central African Company agrees to transfer its stations, factories, and buildings, stores and plant, its steamers, cargo, surf and other boats, to this Company at a valuation, to be paid for by fully paid-up shares in this Company, and to sell its stock of goods, merchandise, and produce to this Company at cost price. No payment will be made for goodwill, the shareholders in that Company being satisfied that they will make a larger profit by becoming interested in a more powerfully-constituted undertaking. This agreement will provide the new Company at once with a favourable basis for its operations, and enable it to enter immediately upon a profitable business in the Lower Congo district, and give great facilities for opening up trade as communications with the Upper Congo are established. Thus we are assured of a speedy increase of an already existing trade in the districts placed under the International African Association, and the British Congo Company (Limited), by possessing stations upon the coast as well as along the course of the river, will be well prepared to participate in the trade which is constantly developing among the peoples in the interior.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Parcel Post with the Oil Rivers Protectorate', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"It is evident that in a trade which has its foundation on the barter system the value and quantity of the imports must vary directly with the exports. There is of late years a growing tendency on the part of the native, even in the remote interior, to employ silver currency for his transactions in place of direct barter or the cumbrous method of transporting vast quantities of cowrie shells from market to market. Hitherto the carrying powers of a slave and his intrinsic value have been in strict relations, but it is probable the less perishable metallic currency will oust him from the commercial field. In other ways the gradual adoption of specie payments has modified the methods of trade in the Colony, and such firms as have adhered to the old barter system have had to remove to less civilised regions. This is very noticeable in the case of the French firms, who were at one time the leading merchants of Lagos. There are at present few traces of their existence in the Colony, except the large factories which were built by them in the days of their prosperity. The establishment of a branch of the African Banking Corporation Limited, which took place towards the close of the year, will have a very remarkable effect on trade by increasing specie transactions, and even more by encouraging shipments by small traders, to whom money is advanced on the security of insured produce or invoiced European goods. The attention of the natives has been directed lately to the importance of developing minor industries. Among these may be mentioned the cultivation of cocoa and coffee, which has been taken up both by the natives and, in one', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Decade of the Trade of Hamburg with West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Consul-General points out that the trade in palm kernels, which has hitherto been accepted as the basis of the West Coast import trade of Hamburg, only came into existence in the decade of 1860-70, and that india-rubber, now the main article of import, was of a much later date, and he infers that Africa, which has barely been tapped, may yet yield a trade "beyond the dreams of the most enterprising." The trade so far is confined to the districts adjoining certain parts of the coast; and mainly to such products as grow naturally, but the increasing imports of coffee, cocoa and tobacco show what may be obtained if planting becomes more general.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GERMAN ANNEXATIONS IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The newly-formed African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce has been considering the question of the recent annexation by Germany of ports in Africa where British trade is largely carried on, and the following letter was signed and forwarded to Earl Granville:

"**Liverpool, October 8, 1884.**', 'last_edit_date': '1884-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1884#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]
